PHR: Project Narrative The Minnesota Department of Agriculture (MDA) Food and Feed Safety Division (FFSD) seeks to maintain full conformance with the Manufactured Food Regulatory Program Standards (MFRPS) and promote continuos improvement of the standards along with maintaining a Minnesota Food Protection Task Force (FPTF) that provides a forum for all stakeholders of the state food protection system and maximize the protection of public health through integration activities. The MDA-FFSD will initiate a dietary supplement inspection program and complete special projects that support the Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA) mission and vision for building mutual reliance in an Integrated Food Safety System.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mount Sinai Health System has created a successful model of primary-care integrated care for Long COVID patients but it has limited reach into low-income communities of color hard hit by COVID-19. We propose a Long COVID specialty practice integrated in a Mount Sinai primary care practice in East Harlem that will engage socioeconomically disadvantaged patients through partnership with community-based service providers and deliver comprehensive, up to date, highly coordinated and patient-centered multidisciplinary Long COVID care. We will then extend access to this high quality care to more communities by equipping other primary care practices with the requisite tools, resources and training.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Primary care-integrated Long COVID care to improve outcomes for minoritized adults in New York City

ORG_NAME: HUGO W. MOSER RES INST KENNEDY KRIEGER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children, initially thought to be at lower risk for severe COVID-19, are not resistant to long COVID. Long COVID is a significant public health concern and can negatively impact the quality of life and functioning of children. Despite critical need for care of children with long COVID, patient volume far exceeds current capacity; thus, in this proposal we will expand services and capacity by identifying barriers, adapting our clinic to provide resources to mitigate these barriers, and educating primary care providers and community partners on the diagnosis, care, and management of children with long COVID.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The Comprehensive Long COVID Care for Underserved Communities: Innovative Delivery and Dissemination Models (COMUNIDAD) project is a 5-year program with 3 aims: 1) in collaboration with patient representatives, to expand and coordinate holistic, patient-centered multidisciplinary Long COVID care at UT Health San Antonio; 2) to disseminate information among clinicians in South Texas rural clinics on conducting a 15-minute, low-tech evaluation of patients presenting with Long COVID symptoms; and 3) to partner with community members in the largely Hispanic/Latino and rural South Texas region to increase health literacy and disseminate up-to-date information about Long COVID and access to Long COVID care.

PHR: Narrative Tumor associated myeloid cells within the tumor microenvironment play critical roles in suppressing adaptive immunity and stimulating tumor cell proliferation, invasion and survival. Our studies have shown that phosphatidylinositol-4,5-bisphosphate 3-kinase gamma (PI3Kg) and the pathways it controls drive lung cancer immune suppression; inhibitory targeting of this kinase stimulates anti-tumor immune responses that synergize with checkpoint inhibitors and chemotherapy. The overall goal of the proposed research is to delineate the mechanistic roles of PI3Kg in the regulation of lung tumor inflammation, growth and metastasis and to use these discoveries to develop novel therapeutic strategies to treat lung cancer.

PHR: Narrative The Milk and Dairy Food Safety Branch (MDFSB) of the California Department of Food and Agriculture (CDFA) is charged with the mission and responsibility of ensuring that California's milk, milk products, and products resembling milk products are safe and wholesome, meet microbial and compositional requirements and are properly labeled. To fulfill this mission, MDFSB conducts regulatory food safety activities at all sectors of the dairy industry from farm to table, including inspections of dairy farms, bulk milk tanker trucks, milk processing plants, industry milk testing laboratories and manufacturers of single-use dairy containers. MDFSB also collects regulatory samples of milk, milk products and water supplies for laboratory testing, responds to consumer complaints and food safety incidents, and initiates impounds and product recalls to protect public health as warranted. In addition, sanitation ratings by MDFSB personnel certify milk supplies and milk plants for U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approval to ship Grade-A milk and milk products in interstate commerce. MDFSB as part of the AHFSS Division of CDFA, relies on the ET database to manage daily business activities such as licensing, registration, certification, permitting, inspection, traceability, compliance, and enforcement. ET is also integrated with the California Animal Health and Food Safety (CAHFS) Laboratory System to electronically submit and receive testing results for dairy samples. A 2016 analysis of ET, performed by the California Department of Technology (CDT) Data Management Consultant, found that ET's current data model no longer represents the business need of AHFSS. The report also identified that the means to ensure reliable shared data, necessary for key management decisions, are not fully implemented, resulting in duplicate information and orphaned records (not linked to a parent record). The following data quality issues are just a few of the concerns identified in the CDT report: duplicate farm records (over 3,000); incomplete data (59,380 active operation records with no date); and invalid data issues (street number, street name, and street suffix are all in the same field and are not uniform, making it hard to search for existing premises). Since this report, these numbers have increased with the adoption of mobile devices to capture activity. Accurate information is essential to a rapid and effective response during an animal health or food safety incident and any delay increases the potentially negative effects and hinders control measures. The ET 2 database will help CDFA, including the Milk and Dairy Food Safety Branch, to respond efficiently and effectively to future food safety incidents, disease outbreaks, and natural disasters. This project is in accordance with the purpose of special projects outlined in the RFA to develop and implement special projects that support innovation and integration in a nationally Integrated Food Safety System (IFSS) using the MFRPS framework. This track will also support other emerging food safety priorities that develop over the lifespan of the project. CDFA is responsible for supporting the responsible jurisdiction and coordinating activities during and immediately following a disaster impacting the agriculture and food industry and supporting the recovery of impacted industries and resources post disaster. The plan specifically references AHFSS as a resource to protect public health, the health of California's livestock and poultry, and to provide safety of food at animal origin. This would include manufactured dairy products.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: California Milk and Dairy Food Safety Manufactured Food Regulatory Program Standards Maintenance and IT Development

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Long COVID impacts millions of people worldwide and has disproportionately impacted vulnerable populations such as communities of color and low-income persons. Comprehensive, coordinated, and person-centered care is needed for Long COVID patients but is difficult to access especially for these populations. The purpose of this project is to expand access to care for vulnerable patients with Long COVID through a partnership model that engages and empowers community primary care clinicians at federally-qualified healthcare centers to identify, care for, and refer patients with Long COVID with the support and collaboration of a multidisciplinary specialty team at an academic Long COVID center and community partners.

ORG_NAME: WEST VIRGINIA STATE DEPT HLTH/HUMAN RSCS
PHR: WV DHHR Manufactured Food Regulatory Program and Food Protection Task Force  Project Narrative In 2019 West Virginia Department of Health and Human Resources (WV DHHR), Oﬃce of Environmental Health Services received their ﬁrst full conformance audit for the Manufactured Food Program Standards. Since then, WV DHHR has held conformance through the hybrid audit performed in 2021 and conƟnues to work to maintain conformance with the new 2022 MFRPS. WV DHHR is invested in the Manufactured Food Program Standards because it allows us to maintain a program that puts a priority on protecƟng public health through evaluaƟng and monitoring risk, by maintaining inspecƟonal standards and training, and by sharing data with partners. WV DHHR is working to maintain and advance our framework for mutual reliance by ensuring our staﬀ are trained according to Standard 2. As an example, WV DHHR has one inspector fully qualiﬁed to conduct process controls inspecƟons, acidiﬁed inspecƟons, Juice HACCP, and low acid canned food inspecƟons, and plans to have a second trained in all these areas prior to the conclusion of 2025. WV DHHR works with FDA to conduct work planning for the FDA contract and shares noncontract state inspecƟon data with the FDA Liaison. Our standards require the program to assess areas of weakness and idenƟfy gaps in standards on a rouƟne basis and at a minimum annually. WV DHHR MFRPS Self-Assessment has idenƟﬁed areas for improvement in the past that resulted in working to add ﬁeld staﬀ to the manufactured food program speciﬁcally. It has idenƟﬁed areas that were weak regarding policy, like adding informaƟon about when samples could be released for validaƟon tesƟng and who could request their release. WV DHHR has also adopted 21 CFR 117 by reference as part of our Food Manufacturing FaciliƟes Rule W.Va. 64 CSR 43 in 2022. This change, along with modeling our standards based on the naƟonal program, helps reduce foodborne illness risks by allowing WV DHHR to focus on the hazards that cause illnesses during inspecƟons. WV DHHR has also maintained a Food ProtecƟon Task Force for as long as the organizaƟon has been enrolled in MFRPS and VNRFRPS. Our Task Force has maintained meeƟngs during the pandemic by meeƟng virtually and returned to hosƟng in-person in November of 2022. Moving forward the Task Force will host two in-person meeƟngs. One to set projects for educaƟon and goals speciﬁcally and the other will focus on updaƟng missions, vision, and governance. The Task Force will conƟnue to uƟlize virtual meeƟng space to conduct business between in-person meeƟngs for things like commiƩees and variance review. Our Task Force is instrumental in garnering input and feedback relaƟng to draŌing legislaƟon, creaƟng policies and procedures, providing guidance for variance reviews, and serving to communicate updates to consƟtuents and partner organizaƟons. The Task Force membership consists of local health department inspectors, state agency representaƟves (DHHR, Department of Agriculture, Department of EducaƟon), FDA, Food Manufacturers, Restaurants, Grocers, Academia, and ciƟzens.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: West Virginia DHHR Manufactured Food Regulatory Program and Food Protection Task Force

PHR: Project Narrative For Colorado Department of Public Health & Environment Flexible Funding Model –  Maintenance for State Manufactured Food Regulatory Programs Colorado’s proposed project and work to remain in full conformance and fully implementing the 2022 MFRPS will ensure that trained, qualified staff will hold food manufacturers in the state to national food safety standards and food products are safe for consumption. These activities will provide FDA the foundation for pursuing regulatory action when deemed necessary and improve domestic mutual reliance.

PHR: ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION PROJECT NARRATIVE: OVERALL COMPONENT Alaska's manufactured food regulatory program protects the safety of food manufactured in Alaska through inspections, education, intervention, compliance and enforcement tasks, research, collaboration, outreach, and the implementation of new or updated systems and technologies. Proposed projects fall into three areas of this funding opportunity: maintaining conformance with the Manufactured Food Regulatory Program Standards (MFRPS), growing partnerships through the Alaska Food Protection Task Force, and a special project to implement a new information management system. The projects detailed in this funding proposal are strategically situated to strengthen and support Alaska's manufactured food regulatory program in working with Alaskan facilities so that they manufacture food safely for consumers inside and outside of the state of Alaska.

PROJECT_TITLE: ADEC- FSS MFRPS Maintenance and Program Infrastructure Improvement

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Long COVID has adversely impacted the health and emotional well-being of millions of people in U.S. communities. Access to Long COVID care can be limited and disconnected and often fails to address patient and family needs. The Atlanta Long COVID Collaborative leverages the city’s coordinated COVID-19 and Long COVID response, and brings together major academic and healthcare centers in the Atlanta metro area to improve person-centered care by expanding in-person and virtual visit options, adding care coordination staff, growing our multidisciplinary network and case conferences, expanding mental health services and group sessions, and engaging community support systems and patient advocacy groups to ensure Long COVID viewpoints are at the forefront of our patient-centered care delivery.
PI_NAMEs: HAN, JENNY ELIZABETH;TRUONG, ALEXANDER D.;WALKER, TIFFANY  (contact)
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: The Atlanta Long COVID Collaborative: A Multi-Health System Long COVID Coordinated Care Model Serving a Diverse Metropolitan Population

PHR: Kentucky Department for Public Health-Division of Public Health Protection & Safety  Food Safety Branch Flexible Funding Model-Infrastructure Development and Maintenance for State Manufactured Food Regulatory Programs (U2F) Clinical Trials Not Allowed (Funding Opportunity Announcement (FOA) Number RFA-FD-23-027). Project Narrative: The intended outcome of this Cooperative Agreement Funding Application for the 2023-2026 Period of Performance is to maintain and further advance efforts for a Nationally Integrated Food Safety System (IFSS) by utilizing available FDA funding assistance to allow The Kentucky Department for Public Health-Division of Public Health Protection and Safety-Food Safety Branch’s Manufactured Food Regulatory Program to maintain full conformance with the Manufactured Food Regulatory Program Standards (MFRPS). This funding will allow the MFRPS program to maintain current staffing levels (including a MFRPS Coordinator), recruit and retain a highly trained/qualified inspection team, review and update program SOPs, assist our federal (FDA) partners in establishing a uniform basis for measuring and improving the performance of manufactured food regulatory programs, and enhance our Regulatory Foundation to ensure that Kentucky’s Manufactured Food Regulatory Program develops and maintains best practices for a high-quality regulatory program. Kentucky’s continued with these program standards will help Federal and State programs better direct their regulatory activities at reducing foodborne illness hazards in plants that manufacture, process, pack, or hold foods.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Kentucky's Application for MFRPS, Dietary Supplements, Food Protection Task Force, and Special Projects

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project narrative Alcohol use decreases skeletal muscle strength and function. A clinical study among older people will investigate the effect of alcohol use on frailty risk, and the role of alcohol mediated muscle mitochondrial dysfunction as a contributing factor in chronological aging. The expected results will inform targets amenable to interventions to reduce risk, delay onset, or improve management of frailty.

PHR: Personalized cancer treatment is becoming a reality with the real-world adoption of broad genomic profiling (BGP), which has enabled the simultaneous testing of hundreds of potentially targetable genetic alterations in patients with lethal cancer. The implications of BGP for cancer treatment, outcomes, and costs represent a substantial yet moving target in oncology that requires clinicians and policy makers to make decisions in the face of uncertainty. In this proposal, we address the critical need to understand real-world 1) BGP use and its impact on 2) clinical decision-making, 3) treatment outcomes and costs and 4) the value of additional research studies in uncertainty regarding BGP by leveraging the strengths of multiple complementary, real-world datasets.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will transform our understanding of APOBEC3A-induced genetic intra-tumoral heterogeneity as a driver of targeted therapy resistance in bladder cancer. Successful completion of this project will 1- Identify targetable kinase hubs downstream of APOBEC3A-induced intra-tumoral heterogeneity to treat advanced bladder cancers that developed FGFR3 inhibitor resistance 2- Define novel synthetic lethal strategies to eliminate cancer cells with APOBEC3A activity. These advances will increase cure rates for patients with advanced bladder cancer.

PHR: MoTrPAC Narrative While there are many important health benefits of physical activity, how exercise exerts its effects is not fully understood. A more comprehensive understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying the responses to exercise would significantly impact public health. Continuation of the Molecular Transducers of Physical Activity Consortium (MoTrPAC) will achieve its objective of generating a comprehensive map of the molecular responses to acute exercise and exercise training, with a long-range goal of elucidating the mechanisms by which exercise improves health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: Persistent accumulation of DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) in neuronal DNA is one of the early pathological features of Huntington’s disease (HD), a terminal neurodegenerative disease, suggesting that DSB repair is compromised in HD. We have discovered that huntingtin forms a specialized DNA repair complex, and that this novel complex maintains neuronal genome integrity and function. The proposed research will test whether there is a link between disruption of the activity of this complex and compromised neuronal genome integrity and neuronal gene expression in the presence of the mutant Huntingtin protein, which could inform strategies to target early processes to slow the progression of the disease.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over one third of patients treated in the emergency department (ED) are discharged without a definitive diagnosis, leaving patients with unaddressed fear regarding their symptoms and minimal assistance in their transition home from the ED. We developed tools to address uncertainty at the time of ED discharge in prior research and we now propose to leverage the electronic health record to implement a multifaceted strategy to facilitate higher quality discharge transitions for patients discharged from the ED with diagnostic uncertainty. Data on efficacy and implementation resulting from this trial will inform refinement of our implementation strategy as we work to disseminate the strategy widely with the goal of improving quality of care transitions for the one third of patients discharged from the ED with diagnostic uncertainty.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Targeted EHR-based Communication of Diagnostic Uncertainty (TECU) in the ED: An Effectiveness Implementation Trial

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis is a leading cause of death in children, and an early diagnosis that improves outcomes is less likely in children who are treated in general Emergency Departments (that treat adults and children) compared to pediatric Emergency Departments. In this study, we will adapt, implement, and evaluate tools that have improved diagnosis: a pediatric sepsis diagnostic checklist and diagnostic work system improvements to the consultation phone calls that occur among a general emergency physician, a transfer nurse, and a pediatric emergency physician. This research will improve early pediatric sepsis diagnosis in general EDs where most children receive their first critical hours of care, and it will identify approaches to improving diagnosis in that can be used in other high-risk conditions in emergency settings.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: The Right Call: Implementing a Sepsis Diagnostic Safety Toolkit in a Pediatric Transfer Call Center to Improve Diagnosis of Children in General Emergency Settings

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Long COVID encompasses a wide range of persistent symptoms and complications that impair quality of life and functioning of affected individuals with few disease-specific treatment options available, and evidence- based guidelines and comprehensive care models lacking. To address this need, we will partner with UPMC Family Medicine Academic Clinic Practice and the Black Equity Coalition (BEC) to establish the Pitt IMProving Access to Culturally relevant long COVID care and Treatment (IMPACCT) Program in order to train the next generation of community providers in long COVID care and improve access to both primary and specialty care for long COVID patients from minority and rural populations. We anticipate that our approach will lead to improved recognition, diagnosis, and management of long COVID, especially among underserved populations, as our proposal offers an innovative model to address health inequities and improve patient outcomes in our community and beyond.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: The Pitt IMProving Access to Culturally relevant long COVID care and Treatment (IMPACCT) Program

ORG_NAME: NY STATE DEPT OF AGRICULTURE/ MARKETS
PHR: Project Narrative: The New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets has a comprehensive food safety and inspection program. Support from FDA has enabled the Division of Food Safety and Inspection (FSI) to reach full implementation and conformance with all ten of FDA’s 2019 Manufactured Foods Regulatory Program Standards (MFRPS), and expand the capability of inspection staff, support training, provide additional staff resources to support the Standards, and improve systems for auditing, data capture, and reporting. Conformance with the MFRPS has placed the Department in a better position to share inspection information and data with FDA and other States, which will improve our response to, and help to prevent the incidence of food borne illnesses and food recalls.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: MFRPS Maintenance NYSAGM

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project seeks to expand the existing UW multidisciplinary long COVID clinic (the Post COVID Rehabilitation and Recovery clinic) to improve access and coordination of care for patients with long COVID, particularly for underserved patients including patients in rural communities, Alaska, and in Latinx, Native American and SE Asian communities. We will also extend our community engagement and primary care training efforts across the WWAMI region to improve the care for patients with long COVID in a large geographic region with unmet needs.

PROJECT_TITLE: Improving Access to Multidisciplinary Care for patients with long COVID

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals diagnosed with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) are at a greater risk for developing an alcohol use disorder, especially if they initiate alcohol drinking during early adolescence. In this study, we will use a mouse genetic model of ADHD to determine if alcohol use during adolescence exacerbates ADHD-like symptoms using techniques to measure neural activity, alcohol self-administration, and cognition. The goal of this study is to better understand the specific neural mechanisms that promote excessive alcohol use in ADHD individuals and develop strategies to treat this unique and susceptible population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: We propose a new ribonucleoprotein (RNP)-gRNA CRISPR genome-editing strategy that will significantly increase efficiency of genome-editing clinical trials for neurogenetic diseases. We will specifically target two neurogenetic diseases with our RNP-based platform: Angelman Syndrome (AS) and H1-4 syndrome. Based on strong proof-of-concept and IND-enabling data and our extensive experience with clinical treatment and trials relating to these diseases, we propose a Phase 1/2a clinical trial to assess safety and tolerability in adults and children.

PHR: Project Narrative A significant proportion of patients with cancer are using medical cannabis, and limited data exists regarding the potential benefits and harms of this use during active treatment. PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD), the most common form of dementia, is increasingly appreciated as a mechanistically heterogeneous condition in which variations in the accumulation of amyloid beta, alpha-synuclein and TDP-43 may define pathophysiologically distinct subsets of patients. Creating new diagnostic modalities to measure these biomarkers in CNS tissue is critical to developing novel, disease-modifying therapeutics for AD and applying them with precision in the AD population. The proposed study is the first clinical step in leveraging the eye as a “window to the brain” by advancing a novel retinal tracer that can image these biomarkers in retina for non-invasive, affordable and widely accessible diagnostic assessment of heterogeneity in the Alzheimer’s spectrum.

PHR: Narrative Peripherally inserted central catheters (PICCs) are widely used to provide life-sustaining intravenous therapies, where placement navigation through the venous system is typically performed blind, or without navigation guidance. Commercially available navigation systems for peripherally inserted central catheters (PICCs) can be effective, but have limitations that have impeded adoption into the clinic. Piccolo Medical has developed the Smart PICC™ system, an inexpensive, easily operated catheter system for real-time vascular access guidance that addresses the limitations of current systems. In this Commercialization Readiness Pilot (CRP) project, we propose to refine our Smart PICC™ system such that it is designed for manufacturing and to submit a 510(k) application to the FDA.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project evaluates the interactions between flooding, migration, and psychosocial health in coastal communities in the US, with a particular focus on the impacts of frequent, smaller floods caused by rising sea levels. Drawing on a combination of large-scale administrative records and a detailed representative household survey, I will quantify the relationship between residential migration and flood experience, examine how health, economic resources, and flood exposure interact to shape migration intentions, and evaluate the health and economic wellbeing of current residents of and recent out- migrants from areas exposed to sea level rise. The outcomes of this research will generate new empirical evidence on the impacts of coastal flooding on migration and psychosocial health and will enable the development of public policies and programs that address both chronic stresses imposed by rising sea levels and extreme events to better support communities at risk.

PHR: Project Narrative The study will advance HIV science by showing the adaptability and preliminary efficacy of an HIV status-neutral intervention to reduce intersectional stigma and discrimination at the intrapersonal, interpersonal, and organizational levels. It will demonstrate ways to leverage assets such as GBSMSM+NURSES to build capacity, reduce stigma, and increase HIV testing, PrEP, and ART uptake among YGBMSM from resource-limited settings. The study will also show the feasibility of scaling up status-neutral intervention and implementing a clustered randomized control trial for YGBMSM and slum communities in Ghana, West Africa, and other stigmatized and marginalized communities, and its utility to continue to positively influence behavioral change among GBMSM across the lifespan and geographical setting.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Imaging biomarkers must be complex enough to represent the relevant features of aggressive breast cancers, but straightforward enough to be applicable at many sites for broad adoption. This project will target the balance of these two needs with a study of advanced imaging (intravoxel incoherent motion (IVIM)) at multiple sites in a cohort of breast cancer patients. The outcome of the study is expected to identify noninvasive imaging biomarkers that not only relate to tumor biology but can be broadly applied for prediction of response to pre- surgical (neoadjuvant) therapy, one of the crucial ingredients of breast cancer survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: The new recreational marijuana markets are contributing to polysubstance-impaired driving and other harms, especially when marijuana is used in combination with alcohol, by selling marijuana to obviously-intoxicated customers. In this study, the effectiveness of an intervention to reduce the risk of marijuana sales to obviously- intoxicated customers will be tested in the state-licensed recreational marijuana market in Oregon, one of the first states to ban such sales. The intervention will combine efforts by state regulators to increase deterrence of the state law prohibiting marijuana sales to obviously-intoxicated customers with training of store personnel to recognize signs of intoxication and refuse sales.

PHR: Black/African American (Black) young adults have among the highest prevalence of cigarillo smoking. Although cigarillo smoking is associated with multiple cancers and pulmonary and cardiovascular diseases, some Black young adults’ have low harm perceptions associated with their uptake and escalation of cigarillo use. This project will address gaps on how to effectively communicate the harms of cigarillos to Black young adults to inform FDA’s communications research priority, and ultimately reduce racial disparities in cigarillo smoking affecting Black young adults.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The zebrafish is well established and accepted as a scientific model system for studying vertebrate development and as a model to study human disease and disorders, including alcohol and drug abuse, cancer, infectious disease, and neurodegeneration. The long-standing Strategic Conference of Zebrafish Investigators (SCZI) brings principal investigators from all scientific disciplines together to exchange ideas, share new methodologies, form collaborations, foster resource development, and draw strategic plans for the optimal use of the zebrafish model in basic and biomedical research. This proposal seeks support for five future SCZI conferences as a successful annual series to allow principal investigators to strategically discuss current research, approaches, and challenges, to integrate new members of the zebrafish community, and to promote coordinated advancement of research using the zebrafish model system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: MoTrPAC Narrative While there are many important health benefits of physical activity, how exercise exerts its effects is not fully understood. A more comprehensive understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying the responses to exercise would significantly impact public health. Continuation of the Molecular Transducers of Physical Activity Consortium (MoTrPAC) will achieve its objective of generating a comprehensive map of the molecular responses to acute exercise and exercise training, with a long-range goal of elucidating the mechanisms by which exercise improves health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative A common and successful treatment for long bone fractures is the implantation of a stiff metal rod, or intramedullary (IM) nail, through the center of the bone which is then fixed to the bone with screws. To anchor the nail securely, the surgeon must accurately drill pilot holes through both the bone and locking holes in the nail, while the nail is hidden from view. This challenging task and often results in longer surgery time, additional blood loss and radiation exposure and a risk of malrotation of the extremity. In this SBIR, Eclipse Orthopaedics will develop a device to significantly improve the freehand targeting of IM nails based on Eclipse’s patented technology.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative: In Training for Health Professionals (THP-1), we demonstrated that a sexual health curriculum tailored to the challenges in Africa is effective short-term in training students in sexual health. In THP-2, we will study the medium to long-term effects, pilot a program to train faculty to deliver the curriculum, and then study if the curriculum produces the same results in “real world” conditions as it did in the rigorously controlled study. Successful completion of this grant will provide us with the evidence and tools needed to disseminate this intervention across Tanzania, to other parts of Africa, and to other LMICs.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurodevelopmental disorders and conditions are common in the population, representing a significant burden in all aspects of life and society. Many variants and genes are still left undiscovered and may reside within complex parts of the human genome. Studies aimed at identifying underlying genetic causes and mechanisms of these disorders will lead to a better understanding of the underlying biological mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to understand the neural and functional basis of verbal working memory (vWM) for speech production. The dysfunction of vWM has been implicated in both stroke related and developmental language disorders. Understanding the neural and functional basis of verbal working memory for speech production would greatly advance the knowledge of how memory processes support language in the brain, in the hopes that this will lead to more targeted rehabilitation from stroke, better surgical approaches to language mapping, and insight into new therapeutic strategies for speech and language disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Rising rates of alcohol-associated liver disease are a public health emergency in the United States, and though alcohol cessation saves patients’ lives, few patients have access to evidence-based alcohol interventions. Smartphone applications hold potential to improve outcomes for patients with alcohol-associated liver disease by overcoming barriers to evidence-based alcohol treatment. The investigators will perform a randomized controlled trial testing the effect of a proven smartphone application for alcohol cessation (called CHESS Health Connections app) on alcohol cessation among patients with alcohol-associated liver disease at two medical centers in Michigan and Wisconsin.

PHR: Despite the success of interventions for increasing physical activity among cancer survivors, many survivors return to inactive or insufficiently active behaviors after the intervention ends. To facilitate long-term maintenance of physical activity, we propose to test an adaptive intervention approach, which allocates additional support and resources to those who are having difficulty maintaining physical activity following the completion of an exercise program. The results from this study will inform the development and implementation of strategies to help cancer survivors maintain sufficient levels of physical activity.

PHR: Project Narrative Each year in the United States, an estimated 10,000 individuals are bitten by venomous snakes, resulting in severe pain, disability, and occasionally death. There is an urgent need for effective treatments to prevent disability and death from snakebite in the U.S. and abroad, where more than 500,000 people are killed or disabled each year. Ophirex is a Public Benefit Corporation developing new intravenous and oral treatments for snakebite using a potent venom antidote called "varespladib" that blocks a key toxin found in more than 95% of snake venoms worldwide--and thought to be present in 100% of venomous snakes native to the United States.

PROJECT_TITLE: Development of Intravenous Varespladib, a Phospholipase A2 Inhibitor, for the Treatment of Snakebite Envenoming

PHR: Project Narrative Dietary restriction (DR) is a potent and evolutionarily conserved intervention to ameliorate age-dependent disease and extend healthy lifespan. This proposal aims to elucidate new mechanisms of DR-mediated protection by determining how DR remodels the intracellular architecture to optimize inter-organelle interactions and metabolic efficiency. Understanding the mechanisms behind this structural remodeling will provide new therapeutic avenues in combating age-onset diseases.

PHR: PPAL® PHASE II PROJECT NARRATIVE Toileting injuries have detrimental effects on older adults and individuals with mobility disability; new, easy-to- use technologies that enable more efficient and safer toilet transfers are desperately needed. This Phase II project continues the development and testing of a novel bedside commode (the “PPAL®”) that enables care recipients to transfer themselves onto a commode to toilet, rather than wait for caregiver lift assistance. The PPAL® uniquely engages the transfer skill of care recipients to manage their own transfer onto a commode. In so doing, it advances the clinical science of fall prevention and (by reducing the manual labor required for toileting assistance), safe patient handling and mobility.

PHR: A major challenge for the organized development and homeostasis of tissues and organs is the correct  spatial and temporal distribution of signaling molecules. Achieving a correct tissue organization is critical as  defects in patterning can lead to human disorders and disease. This project will take both multi-scale  mathematical modeling and experimental approaches to investigate how the signaling receptor Notch is  distributed and activated by active cell processes during lateral inhibition-mediated tissue patterning events.

PHR: Project Narrative  The field is moving toward finding more sensitive clinical measures for early diagnosis and tracking of subtle changes over time that are associated with AD biomarkers but are easy and inexpensive to administer by primary care physicians, who are on the frontlines of the medical battle. Developing more sensitive, ecologically valid performance-based IADL tests like ASSET is vital to the goal of improving the tracking of individuals through the tipping point between preclinical AD and prodromal AD. ASSET has been designed to tap the high-level healthcare-related tasks that challenge seniors in daily life and are important to them, to serve as a clinically meaningful outcome measure for preclinical and prodromal AD trials, and to be easy and quick to administer remotely/at-home, using real-life devices.

PHR: Project Narrative: Dysfunction in the autonomic nervous system is poorly understood after spinal cord injury, leading clinicians to watch and wait for potentially devastating secondary complications to occur. The goal of this project is to characterize dysfunction in the cardiovascular component of the autonomic nervous system using a combination of lab, ambulatory, and imaging-based techniques. These results could give new insights into who will develop secondary complications and, by developing precision markers, lay the groundwork for accurately assessing future interventions to treat and prevent them.

PHR: Methamphetamine, HIV integration and latency in the brain  This project addresses a critical gap in our understanding of relationships between chromatin organization and proviral integration associated with latency in brain microglia cellular reservoirs of HIV, and particularly in the best experimental model, the SIV-rhesus macaque. While HIV integration and latency in tissues such as the brain are challenges to the cure, the relationships between HIV integration and chromatin dynamics may be drastically different in prevalent populations of HIV+ drug users, especially Methamphetamine. Following a two phase project, where a progression of models will lead to conclusions about HIV/SIV integration site frequency, location and markers, we expect to prove our hypothesis that Meth impacts chromatin structure in microglia, enhancing viral integration susceptibilities and that these effects vary between brain regions that differ in levels of dopaminergic projections, and their involvement in the addiction circuitry, leading to a paradigm shift about the role of brain regions and their heterogeneous microglia populations in the establishment of a reservoir state.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Helping people with opioid-use disorder stay on medication treatment is paramount to battling this country’s opioid crisis. This project will develop a stigma-informed recovery support intervention for people initiating buprenorphine treatment, using an embodied conversation agent delivered via smartphones. We will also conduct a clinical trial to assess this intervention’s effects on retention in treatment for opioid-use disorder over one year, so that we can adequately design a subsequent effectiveness and implementation study.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Isocitrate dehydrogenase is the most commonly mutated metabolic gene across all cancers, with a particular high frequency of mutation in cholangiocarcinoma, a deadly cancer of the liver bile ducts. Our prior studies using novel genetically engineered mouse models, patient-derived models, and patient samples showed that mutant IDH has central roles in driving immune-evasion and subverting cell differentiation. This proposal explores the underlying mechanisms and interplay of these process and determines how their reversal upon pharmacological inhibition of the mutant IDH1 contributes to biological and therapeutic response, thereby informing the improved treatment of cholangiocarcinoma and potentially the range of other cancer types harboring IDH mutations.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it accelerates the development and implementation of high-confidence predictive tools able to minimize the harm of unnecessary antibiotics on critically ill and injured children. Following appropriate evaluation of our machine learning-based predictive models and the design of model-based clinical decision support tools, we will be poised to effect significant improvement in pediatric antibiotic decision-making with reductions in antibiotic-associated harm including acute kidney injury, clostridium difficile colitis, and the development of antibiotic resistance. This project is well aligned with the missions of the NIH and NICHD given its potential to reduce illness and disability and enhance the lives of children and adolescents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative We aim to develop a bioresorbable, non-surgical and minimally invasive peripheral nerve stimulator to treat chronic pain. Once injected, the device will provide pain relief through electrical stimulation and then be safely degraded and resorbed by the body afterwards. This provides a new pain management option without the risk of opioids or high complications from the permanent and surgically implanted stimulators.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The wider application of allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT), a potentially curative therapy against many blood diseases has been limited by its most significant complication, graft-versus- host disease (GVHD). Our proposal aims to understand the role of diet on the host (patient) and their microbial metabolism in mitigating GVHD. If successful, could pave way for improving the outcomes of allogeneic HCT through rational dietary and microbial modifications.

ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Working memory is our ability to maintain important information across short periods of time, while permitting us to manipulate this information to reason through problems and solve tasks. The neuromodulator dopamine is theorized to be critical in several aspects of working memory functioning but validating these theories has been impossible prior to the methodological advances that we use in this proposal. Using machine-learning- enhanced voltammetry to measure dopamine release in the lateral prefrontal cortex, anterior cingulate cortex, and hippocampus we will acquire high temporal resolution recordings to test key theories about dopamine’s role in selecting information to store in working memory and maintaining this information across time.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this Commercialization Readiness Pilot (CRP) is to fund late stage technical assistance in the form of a complex manufacturing process and regulatory support for Briteseed’s laparoscopic vessel sealer with hyperspectral imaging based rapid ureter detection (HSI-RUD) capability. These activities will position the company to successfully partner with a major device manufacturer to co-develop a version of their vessel sealer with our HSI-RUD technology integrated into it or to bring to market a stand-alone Briteseed smart surgical device; which would be the first universal, unobtrusive and cost-effective ureter detection technology with the potential to decrease the incidence of ureteral complications during minimally invasive gynecological surgery (MIGS). Ureters are critical structures present in the same working space as many gynecologic organs of interest during MIGS procedures, and inadvertent injury to them occurs and leads major complications, costing hospitals an average of $30,000 per patient due to added hospitalization time and added procedures.

PHR: Narrative Breast cancer is the most common cancer and the second leading cause of cancer deaths in women. Triple negative breast cancer disproportionately accounts for many of these deaths. The goal of this proposal is to investigate a novel treatment strategy through a Phase I and II clinical trial involving patients with high-risk triple negative breast cancer, in which treatment resistant triple negative breast tumor cells are forced into rapid cycling, and in the process, they become sensitive to conventional chemotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Bariatric surgery is a potent treatment for obesity-related metabolic disease and improves glucose control in T2D, but some individuals develop severe hypoglycemia (post-bariatric hypoglycemia, PBH), threatening safety. PBH is linked to increased insulin and incretin secretion, reduced secretion of glucagon and other counterregulatory hormones, and altered intestinal and whole-body metabolism, but current therapies remain incompletely effective. In this study, we will (a) analyze glucose and glucagon metabolism/sensitivity in the fasting, post-meal, and post-exercise states in patients with PBH, (b) use this information to develop a new closed-loop glucagon pump system responsive to the unique pathophysiology of PBH, and (c) test the system in a pilot randomized outpatient clinical trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: This cooperative project will create a federated computer system to bring many types of complex data of the human brain together with a virtual human brain tissue bank to advance translational research for both rare and common brain disorders. A multi-institutional platform, online training program, and virtual tissue and database of rare and valuable fresh human brain samples will be linked to highly curated data. This will fill an important void in translational research, advance clinical care and help develop new treatments for brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Osteoclasts are the sole bone resorbing cells. Dysregulation of osteoclasts results in excessive bone loss. At present, available strategies for prevention and the treatment of bone loss are accompanied by significant limitations, rendering prolonged use of them undesirable. By determining a cell-specific program causing bone loss, our study will provide a new way to prevent disease development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Chronic pelvic pain is a debilitating condition affecting up to 1 in 4 women worldwide that is very challenging to treat. This clinical study will evaluate sacral neuromodulation as a treatment strategy for chronic pelvic pain, and determine placebo effect, carry-over effect and treatment durability. In addition, we will assess cost- effectiveness of performing single stage sacral neuromodulation implant versus the standard of care two-stage approach.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal addresses critical computational challenges in the integrative analysis of spatial transcriptomics, histology images, and single cells. The successful completion of this project will allow researchers to take advantage of advanced machine learning algorithms to integrate multi-modal data to gain a holistic view of the spatial organization of tissues. The companion software packages will facilitate the translation of basic research findings into clinical studies of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Cyclic peptides are an exciting class of drug molecules capable of engaging challenging biological targets, and cyclic peptide natural products have been used in the clinic as immune system suppressants, antibiotics, and antifungals. Unfortunately, it is currently extremely challenging for researchers to design new cyclic peptide drugs to treat specific diseases because it is very difficult to predict the three-dimensional structures any cyclic peptide will adopt and to optimize their pharmacologic properties. In this proposal, we develop new computing algorithms that efficiently and accurately predict structures and properties of cyclic peptides, thereby allowing scientists to much more rapidly and robustly develop novel cyclic peptide drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Macrophage-mediated inflammation is involved in the progression of many diseases, including arthritis, atherosclerosis, cancer, autoimmune diseases as well as chronic wounds. Metabolic reprogramming is a key hallmark of macrophage activation and function. The goal of this study is to gain more insight into the metabolic pathways that regulate macrophage function to better inform the development of new therapies for improved patient outcome.

PHR: Project Narrative  As the overdose crisis continues, some local prosecutors have increased their use of criminal legal penalties to address overdose deaths—despite evidence suggesting that doing so worsens public health outcomes for people who use drugs and their communities. Using a legal epidemiological framework, this study analyzes (1) the factors that influence prosecutors’ decisions to treat an overdose as a murder instead of a public health issue, (2) how such charges impact the health of people at risk of overdose, and (3) how investment in local public health efforts can decrease the involvement of the criminal justice system in addressing overdose deaths.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Exposure to chronic stress is a risk factor for neuropsychiatric disease and yields both molecular and structural changes to the brain and immune system in clinical and preclinical models. As such, elucidating the neuroimmune substrates driving neuron subtype specific atrophy in brain reward regions and associated negative affective behaviors can inform novel therapeutics and enhance our ability to treat stress-related neuropsychiatric disorders, such as major depressive disorder. Here, I will use molecular and behavioral approaches to characterize the role of vitronectin, an extracellular matrix protein and promising molecular candidate hypothesized to drive stress-induced changes in the nucleus accumbens, to characterize its role in neuron-microglia interactions, morphology, and downstream behavioral outcomes to stress.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid drugs such as morphine are effective medications in treating pain but have profound side effects, including respiratory depression and addiction, thus there is a need to develop new analgesic treatment methods as an alternative to high dose opioids. We have discovered that combining morphine with MP-III-024, a drug that affects the GABA system, produces synergistic effects in models of pain relief, but not in models of opioid side effects, opening the possibility that dual MP-III-024/opioid treatments may allow for successful analgesia with reduced side effect risks. This proposal will systematically evaluate the therapeutic potential of a dual MP-III-024/opioid strategy and will aid in the development of new and improved treatments for pain- related disorders.

PHR: Project Narrative Multiple social determinants of health (SDOH) underlie the staggering negative health outcomes among youth experiencing homelessness, including a lack of stable safe housing, income, education, food security, access to services, and intervention options, as well as high levels of discrimination, victimization and social isolation. Prevention efforts addressing these SDOH and that are embedded within systems that serve youth, such as drop-in centers, may be the most promising strategy to prevent opioid use and other substance use disorders as well as homelessness in adulthood. As such, this proposal addresses a significant public health concern, and if our hypotheses are supported, the intervention may be readily transported to communities around the country.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study aims to elucidate the neurobiology of neurocognitive symptoms associated with post- treatment Lyme disease (PTLD). Our goal is to generate fundamental knowledge about the activity and health of the brain, and to do so, this study will examine how white matter changes in structure and function throughout the course of Lyme disease. These findings may lead to the development of innovative prognostic and diagnostic tools as well as novel interventions to prevent or reduce the often significant cognitive symptom burden and functional impact of PTLD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Congenital malformations of external genitalia are among the most common birth defects in humans, affecting ~1:150 live male births in the US. Correction can require multiple surgeries, and high complication rates are associated with tissue deficiencies and poor differentiation. This project will use single cell RNA sequencing to produce spatial and temporal atlases of the diversity of cell types in male and female mouse external genitalia. We will genetically decouple hormonally- and genetically-regulated sex differences. Nanoscale 3D imaging and single molecule visualization of RNAs will identify anchor genes for specific cell types and will map them back to embryonic tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will investigate the role of small non‐coding RNAs, termed microRNAs, in the regulation of sodium (Na+) transport in the distal kidney nephron. We will investigate the hypothesis that the mineralocorticoid hormone, aldosterone up-regulates the expression of specific miR clusters in the distal kidney nephron which feedback to negatively alter Na+ transport. We will test this novel function of microRNAs in Na+ homeostasis using control mice and a nephron-specific microRNA knockout mouse model that will be subjected to aldosterone stimulation and changes to renal Na+ handling will confirm that these microRNAs are acting as a negative feedback regulators of aldosterone signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it is focused on discovering new therapies for kidney diseases affecting how much water is in the body. Sometimes this process is not balanced, leading to diseases such as hypertension (too much fluid in the body) and dehydration (too much urine production). Our work is aimed at identifying basic mechanism in kidney cells that cause these diseases in order to develop drugs to cure them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lysosomal storage diseases are caused by genetic defects leading to anomalous accumulation of metabolites in lysosomes, the degradative and recycling compartment of the cell. These toxic products, when accumulated in large amounts, can be harmful to humans. The identification of novel mechanisms that regulate autophagy and compounds that improve cellular and organ function would lead to novel treatments for several human diseases including lysosomal storage disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The kidney is a complex organ whose essential roles include filtering waste from the blood, regulating blood pressure, and maintaining electrolyte balance. This project will develop a microscopy-based technique to study the organization of the genome of kidney cells and it will use the new technique to study aging in model mouse kidney tissue. The tools and findings of this project will enable researchers to study genome organization in kidney or other tissues and will illuminate the molecular details of aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: NOVEL ROLE OF NEPHRON EPITHELIALIZATION IN NUCLEAR SIGNALING Formation of tubules is essential for the development of the kidney and urinary tract, and failure of this process results in urogenital anomalies, which occur in almost 2% of the world population and represent nearly one- fourth of all birth defects. Kidney tubule malformations result from disruption of either of two groups of proteins, the planar cell polarity (PCP) or exocyst proteins, but how they affect the formation of tubules in the developing kidney is not well understood. This study is significant because it will uncover how these protein groups work together to form the kidney tubules, improving our understanding of the mechanisms underlying prevalent birth defects involving the kidney.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs) are immunotherapies increasingly used in patients with wide varieties of cancers; however, they can also cause autoimmune toxicities affecting multiple organ systems, including the kidney. Currently, the pathogenesis of ICI-induced kidney injury is not well-understood, and epidemiologic studies suggest a high fraction of ICI-treated patients develop clinically-significant decline in kidney function over time. Using single-cell genomics and longitudinal biomarker studies, this proposal seeks to identify pathways that can help understand how acute and chronic kidney disease develops after ICIs to ultimately lead to novel diagnostic and therapeutic strategies to prevent kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Racial disparities in the incidence and treatment of end-stage kidney disease are well-documented and largely consistent across outcomes, and an emerging consensus indicates that these disparities are likely to be primarily driven by structural racism (SR). We will develop theoretically-driven, innovative measures of SR using restricted microdata and other sources, analyze the role of SR in racial/ethnic disparities in end-stage kidney disease incidence and mortality outcomes, determine how best to operationalize meaningful racial/ethnic disparities in sequences of kidney disease therapies, and work with two established community advisory boards to develop proposed interventions to ameliorate racial/ethnic disparities in kidney disease on the basis of our findings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT There are currently over 110,000 patients on the organ transplant waiting list in the US, a number that far exceeds the supply of available organs. A major reason is the limitations of our current organ preservation technology, which disallows the transplantation of marginally injured organs and limits preservation duration. This project aims to improve public health by developing a protocol to bank organs for several weeks up to a few months, enabling global organ matching and potentially utilization of organs unusable with current technology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: During obesity, visceral fat tissue expands causing oxidative stress and the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines that can cause insulin resistance and cardiovascular complications. This project explores the antioxidant bilirubin in molecular detail as a signaling molecule to reduce adiposity and insulin resistance and improve metabolic health. A comprehensive investigation of the signaling preferences for bilirubin may open new avenues for potential new therapeutics for obesity and insulin resistant diabetes, and for cardiovascular diseases in humans.

PHR: Long-acting, injectable Cabotegravir (LAI CAB) HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) has the potential to prevent HIV among those who experience barriers to effective use of daily, oral PrEP, including many adolescents and young adults (AYA) in sub-Saharan Africa who remain at highest risk of HIV incidence. Disappointing, inequitable outcomes from the initial roll-out of oral PrEP globally and limited utilization of promising injectable formulations in other disease areas demonstrate that implementation success is far from certain, however. This study will identify LAI CAB health system implementation opportunities, measure HCW and AYA implementation preferences, identify preference heterogeneity, and specify implementation strategies to optimize LAI CAB impact in Zambia and globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The origins of sex-based differences in ionizing radiation (IR) response remain unclear, potentially involving hormones, genetics, and metabolism. Preliminary mouse model studies hint at sex-specific shifts in nitro-oxidative pathways and mitochondrial superoxide dismutase activities as contributors to sex-specific IR-induced cardio-pulmonary toxicities. This proposal delves deeper into these mechanisms, providing insights into gender-specific factors and potential therapeutic approaches for mitigating IR-induced cardio-pulmonary toxicities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative HIV is a serious, chronic infectious disease, and understanding the effect of different anti-retroviral treatment strategies is critical to maintaining a person’s overall health and retention in care. Additionally, there is a growing concern that certain antiretroviral medications increase the risk of weight gain and non-communicable diseases such as hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus (diabetes), but the causal effect is not well elucidated. The goal of the proposed research aims is to better understand the effects of different treatment strategies on retention in care, viral suppression, and the risk of weight gain and developing other co- morbidities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of the ‘Cardiovascular Research and Drug Development’ (CRDD) training program at Baylor College of Medicine is to educate and train the next generation of leaders in the field of cardiovascular research and drug discovery. Our innovative program includes interactive didactic courses, individualized training plans, formal training of research mentors, mentor training of the predoctoral trainees, and an exceptional research infrastructure within the largest medical center in the world. The program emphasizes the highest standards of rigor and reproducibility, equity, and ethics, while incorporating strong translational components to allow our trainees to bridge critically important gaps in basic and translational cardiovascular research to develop future therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Improving short-term mortality and long-term morbidity from critical illness is a crucial public health priority. Glucocorticoid stress hormones play important roles in these short and long-term outcomes. This research program focuses on improving our understanding of glucocorticoid mechanisms of short- and long-term critical illness outcomes with the ultimate goal of maximizing their therapeutic potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current approaches to measuring the potency of manufactured lots of Botulinum toxin (BoT) involve laborious and ethically dubious mouse lethality assays. Organ on chip technologies based on human induced pluripotent stem cells offer an attractive solution as they can be performed rapidly and in absence of ethical concerns. In this proposal, we will develop an integrated, next-generation platform consisting of instrumentation and stem- cell based models of the neuromuscular junction that can be used for BoT potency assays.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research aims to develop a technology to enable drug development for undruggable transcription factor proteins. ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mannosemetabolism as a regulator of hepatic stellate cell activation and fibrosis Chronic liver disease can lead to irreversible scarring of the liver, which can lead to liver failure, liver cancer, and necessitate liver transplantation. Currently, there are no approved medical treatments to effectively reverse scarring. This project proposes to investigate a new pathway involved in liver scar formation that can potentially lead to new drug targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project narrative While it is known that fatty livers are particularly vulnerable to injury, incomplete understanding of the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying injury limits development of strategies for effective prevention and treatment of injury in fatty livers. This proposal will investigate the function of ATP citrate lyase, an important enzyme critical for cellular energy metabolism, in liver cells using cell biological and transgenic techniques. The information generated from this project will provide new insights relevant to prevention and treatment strategies for liver injury in patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Fibrosis (the stiffening of tissues due to collagen overproduction/deposition) and blood vessel leakage are major contributors to the deficits in ventricular function that occur in Heart Failure (HF). We have been working on novel, modified versions suitable for drug development of a biologic peptide (called CSD) that we have already shown to suppress fibrosis and blood vessel leakage and to improve ventricular function in multiple model systems for HF. In this proposal, based on its beneficial effects in two model systems, we will select a Lead Compound for further development as a treatment for HF from among four candidates that we have designed and, additionally, we will evaluate the potential toxicity of this Lead Compound in a Maximum Tolerated Dose experiment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Fatty liver disease occurs in about 25% in the general population of the United States and as high as 70% in the obese population and those with Diabetes; and in individual who consume alcohol. With the increase in obesity rate and continued excessive drinking behavior in the US population, fatty liver is in line to become the leading cause of liver transplantation in the next 10 years. This project will study the molecular changes occurring with fatty liver using mouse models. We also designed an inhibitor to block the signal that we have discovered. We expect this inhibitor to exhibit therapeutic effect at treating fatty liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Cellular crosstalk is a process through a message transmitted between cells. Intercellular crosstalk of hepatocytes and non-parenchymal cells (i.e. Mφ and LSEC) is crucial for the maintenance of liver homeostasis. Under the pathological condition, hepatocyte damage results in the activation of fibrotic Mφ and LSEC. Thereby these cells play a critical role in the control of hepatic inflammation and the development of liver fibrosis. Exosomes are small membrane-bound extracellular vesicles and serve as natural carriers of signaling molecules such as cytokines for prompting cellular crosstalk. This project will identify a major cellular and molecular mechanism for the role of exosomes released from HCV-infected hepatocytes in promoting intercellular communication with non-parenchymal cells (i.e. Mφ and LSEC), leading to the development of liver fibrosis. The findings from our proposed research will provide a rationale basis of novel immunotherapeutic strategies that target molecules inducing pro-fibrotic factors through HCV-derived exosomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The emergence of precise physical patterns during embryonic development is critical for the birth of a healthy and fully functional organism. The present application addresses this inherently multidisciplinary problem in the context of looping of the small intestine, a process driven by mechanical buckling of the initially straight tube that allows the lengthy intestine to be packaged within the abdomen. Advancing our understanding of how molecular cues control forces to shape the embryo, and the potential biological importance of the forces themselves, may shed light on the underlying causes of congenital disorders such as midgut volvulus, and provide inroads to the manipulation of forces to engineer tissues and organs in the lab.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance  Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) affects more than a million people in the United States, alone, and there is presently no cure, with limited preventive measures for this condition. We recently discovered that the inflamed mouse and human colonic epithelium produces extracellular vesicles containing IL-1 family cytokines, including IL-1 and IL-18, that exacerbate T cell-mediated colitis and cause anti-TNF therapy failure. This application aims to provide mechanistic insight into this pathogenic cross-talk between intestinal epithelial cells and T cells, and to identify potential targets to address anti-TNF therapy failure using murine colitis models and clinical specimens from IBD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Steroid sex hormones such as 17β-estradiol (estrogen) are important regulators of immune responses. Although estrogen is generally immunoprotective, our data show that it contributes to the pathogenesis of chronic inflammatory diseases such as IBD by impairing the differentiation and function of regulatory T cells (Tregs). This project seeks to identify the mechanism(s) by which altered estrogen signaling impairs Treg- mediated immunosuppression in the chronically inflamed intestine, with the ultimate goal of developing novel approaches for the treatment of IBD.

PHR: The proposed research is highly relevant to public health because defining how antibiotic-mediated microbiome disruption contributes to complications such as obesity and diabetes may, in the long run, identify ways to alleviate these conditions for millions of Americans. This work will define the impacts of antibiotics on the metabolic environment of the murine gut, host metabolite availability and weight gain. In addition to generating fundamental scientific discoveries, this research will also fulfill NIH goals by generating a mechanistic perspective on how antibiotics contribute to diabetes, digestive diseases, nutritional disorders, and obesity.

PHR: Project Narrative In the United States, millions of people use cannabis and there is now convincing evidence linking its use with depression and suicidal behavior. By combining human postmortem genomics, MPRA genetic engineering, and human induced pluripotent stem cell derived brain organoids, we propose to test the molecular and functional impact of cannabis use perturbing the genotype of MDD risk alleles. We hope to find insights into the mechanism of disease initiation and progression of MDD in people with substance use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity is a major public health concern as it increases the risk for a number of common diseases such as type 2 diabetes, heart disease, stroke and certain forms of cancer. Obesity results from the interaction of the environment with a genetic predisposition and large-scale efforts have recently pointed at regions in the human genome in which genetic variations predispose humans to obesity. Our studies are aimed at determining how these genetic variations are involved in obesity and how this knowledge could be harvested for new obesity treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Alterations in intestinal microbes are critical factors contributing to many chronic inflammatory conditions such as Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD), celiac disease, Type 1 diabetes, and rheumatoid arthritis, which collectively affect 2.01% of the U.S. population. We have discovered a completely novel role for the protein tyrosine phosphatase non-receptor type 2 (PTPN2) gene, a candidate gene for all of these autoinflammatory conditions, in restricting expansion of an IBD-associated pathobiont, adherent-invasive E. coli (AIEC). In this proposal, we will use novel in vivo and in vitro model systems to mechanistically define the cellular and molecular mechanisms by which loss of PTPN2 activity increases host epithelial cell susceptibility to AIEC invasion, and identify if clinically approved JAK inhibitors can be repurposed to alleviate this risk event.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Triple-negative breast cancer is a heterogeneous and highly aggressive type of breast cancer with limited treatment options. This proposal seeks to elucidate the mechanism of action and define critical pharmacophores of activity in a novel compound with selective activity against a distinct TNBC subtype. Mechanistic knowledge obtained from this study will inform on oncogenic pathways that can be pharmacologically modulated to establish and generate a more effective targeted treatment for this disease.

PHR: IMPACT OF CANNABINOIDS ACROSS THE LIFESPAN (ICAL): NARRATIVE Teenagers use cannabis more than any other recreational substance. Sweeping changes in social attitudes and relaxed legal restrictions have highlighted a critical need for research that investigates in a rigorous manner the long-term consequences of adolescent cannabis use on brain function and mental health. ICAL addresses this fundamental gap in knowledge: as such, it has the potential not only to impact our understanding of adolescent health, but also to inform medical practice and public policy.
