IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Nail salon workers represent low-wage, underinsured, immigrant women in the services sector of the U.S. workforce whose occupational health and safety needs are overlooked and understudied. Prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, this small business industry faced a number of workplace hazards; these workers’ vulnerability has been worsened by the pandemic but the current state of their occupational health and safety needs, as well as their wellbeing is unknown. Results from the proposed study are directly relevant to the Services Sector and Healthy Work Design and Well-Being Cross-Sector at the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH).
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: COVID-19 and Nail Salon Workers: Taking Stock of the Pandemic's Impact on Occupational Health and Safety
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Safety and Occupational Health Study Section[SOH]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative statement Synonymous mutations, which change the rate at which a codon position is translated by the ribosome but not the amino acid it encodes, can alter protein structure and function, affect mRNA half-lives, and contribute to disease. Molecular modeling, interpretable machine learning, and synthesizing big biological datasets are suggesting molecular mechanisms that can connect this class of mutations to these outcomes. This research proposal will utilize these tools and experimental methods to gain quantitative molecular insights into these phenomena.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is highly prevalent with a significant lifetime morbidity and financial burden on society. A better understanding of the factors that drive IBD epithelial repair will help to improve mucosal healing and long-term disease remission. Understanding how intestinal stem cells adapt their energy profile to drive their repairing function to heal the damaged tissue will enhance our overall understanding of IBD and may open the door to biomarker discovery and novel treatment strategies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study is relevant to public health because it addresses the limited knowledge about the roles of support system and the contextually specific socioeconomic influence on physical and psychological health of older adults in a low resource setting of rural Cambodia. Findings can be used by health interventionists and researchers to compare public health interventions focused on providing tangible resources against ones focused on improving self-image and the sense of economic fulfillment. Because this study will add to the small body of aging and public health literature about older Cambodians, the long-term goal is for aging researchers to use the findings to advance conceptual and empirical work in this country and other low- and middle-income countries, thus advancing the mission of the NIA to support social and economic research on aging around the world and to increase diversity in research among underrepresented population. 1

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Novel, effective, targeted strategies for both earlier detection and treatment of metastatic cancers could greatly improve patient outcomes. With the identification of αvβ6, a molecule that is on many cancers and is linked to a poor survival rate for patients, and the development of our promising theranostic pair that target the αvβ6, we now have the opportunity to develop these targeted strategies. In this application we propose a clinical trial to test our theranostic pair to determine if it is effective in patients with metastatic carcinoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Using azide-containing hypervalent iodine reagents, we have developed a novel chemoproteomic platform termed Protein Surface Azidation Mass Spectrometry (ProSurA-MS) that detects conformational changes on protein surface with unbiased chemoselectivity. Combined with bioorthogonal chemistry, ProSurA-MS effectively mapped dynamics of purified proteins upon denaturation, protein-small molecule interaction, and protein-protein interaction, conformational changes of a zinc-binding protein in whole cell lysate upon zinc depletion, and measured proteome-wide azidation in live cells, thus potentiating the characterization of protein dynamics in complex biological environments. The herein proposed studies will enable characterization of dynamic changes in protein conformation induced by post-translational modifications and metal binding, basic understanding of the chemical mechanism behind the ProSurA reaction and development of second generation reagents with greater azidation yield and surface coverage, and investigation of protein interaction networks via unbiased crosslinking.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Localized provoked vulvodynia (LPV) is a common cause of painful intercourse in women of reproductive age, but therapy options short of surgery are limited and marginally effective and patients may suffer for months to years before finding relief, if ever. We have identified new targets for LPV therapy that are likely involved in other pain conditions and that could lead to a breakthrough in analgesic therapy. In the wake of the opioid epidemic, it is imperative that we develop new, effective, and safe pain therapies to replace current medications that result in dependence.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Algorithmic bias is an emerging and highly relevant topic in health policy that draws attention to the idea that seemingly well-performing predictive algorithms built using biased data can propagate systemic biases and disparities existing in clinical practice. Disparities along the cancer care continuum from diagnosis to survivorship can lead to distorted risk predictions; using these for decision-making may propagate and exacerbate biases that exist in clinical practice and result in poorer outcomes for certain subgroups. The major goal of this project is to understand and address algorithmic bias in the personalized risk-adaptive surveillance (PRAISE) framework developed and applied to colorectal cancer in the parent grant, and to assess the implications of using a biased versus a bias-corrected algorithm to guide surveillance testing among colorectal cancer survivors. This important work will motivate the use of new methods for addressing bias in risk predictions in cancer and other clinical areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Glioblastoma (GBM) is defined by a deeply immunosuppressive immune infiltrate implicated in intrinsic T cell ignorance and hindrance of systemic immunotherapy with immune checkpoint blockade. This project will unravel the mechanisms of local GBM immunotherapy with recombinant poliovirus, PVSRIPO, based on its uniquely broad and profound proinflammatory effects in the GBM myeloid infiltrate and surrounding brain. This project will define new therapy paradigms for viral GBM immunotherapy by addressing recently discovered factors in immunotherapy resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Relevance Cholesterol serves as a precursor molecule for the biosynthesis of steroid hormones, bile acids, and vitamin D, and plays a role as a Hedgehog signal transducer. In this project, we will employ cell biological and structural approaches to study the membrane proteins involved in cholesterol signaling, biosynthesis, and storage. Completion of the proposed studies will not only provide insight into the mechanisms underlying HH signal transduction and cholesterol metabolism but will also reduce the incidence of cardiovascular disease and cancers.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Treating pelvic pain remains a significant challenge as current treatment strategies are dependent on our limited understanding of the underlying mechanisms that promote pain. Findings from the proposed clinical trial will help clinicians and researchers better understand the impact of pelvic and systemic inflammation on central nervous system sensitization, and how these pathways are affected by hormonal suppression. These results will have broad implications for understanding the neurobiological mechanisms through which hormonal suppression produces pain relief in many women with pelvic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sensory-based rehabilitation following spinal cord injury (SCI) facilitates neural rewiring for functional recovery, but it is unknown if different sensory-based training programs, such as forced exercise therapy and non-forced exercise, give rise to different rewiring strategies and behavioral outcomes. The proposed research will characterize the neural rewiring strategies that occur in forced and non-forced exercise and elucidate contributions of paradoxical training paradigms to motor performance and recovery. With a unique combination of techniques and expertise of my mentors, my research will break down current barriers of translational preclinical research with the aim of instructing rehabilitation programs for SCI patients with the intent to maximize recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research on the role of cellular surfaces in controlling biomolecular condensation is relevant to public health because condensates are involved in the formation of pathological aggregates that cause neurodegenerative diseases like amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. Therefore, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that seeks to develop fundamental knowledge that will help to reduce the burdens of human disability and disease. Ultimately, it is envisioned that an enhanced, mechanistic understanding of how cells regulate biomolecular condensation will enable its clinical manipulation, providing new approaches for treating diseases that arise from disruptions to this fundamental cellular process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative Tight junctions (TJs) are protein assemblies involved in cell adhesion and intercellular transport of molecules through endothelial and epithelial tissues. While many proteins amass at TJs, two families of membrane proteins predominate TJ assembly, organization, and function. The goals of this research are to establish a fundamental understanding of how these two membrane protein families structurally assemble TJs, to identify how their disassembly contributes to TJ dysfunction, and to apply this knowledge by creating new strategies for tissue-specific treatment of TJ-linked diseases in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Protein misfolding and aggregation are the root cause of many debilitating diseases, including Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson’s disease, and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). We are only beginning to appreciate that DNA and RNA play important roles in protein folding and aggregation. This research investigates the underlying principles of how nucleic acids prevent protein misfolding and aggregation, and promote protein oligomerization; eventually, these discoveries could lead to nucleic acid-based therapies for protein misfolding diseases.

PHR: Relevance Statement The unmet need in the treatment of cancers and Opioid Use Disorders (OUD) poses a great threat to human health and welfare. The conventional drug discovery process has yielded very few successes. New approaches are needed to reduce the time and cost in drug discovery and development. We propose a novel machine learning powered systems pharmacology approach to accelerate drug discovery and development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The blood-brain barrier (BBB) formed by the cerebrovascular endothelial cells is necessary for normal brain function. Endothelial barrier opening and the consequent BBB disruption occurs in many brain diseases, leading to leakage of blood components into the brain, edema formation, and potentially death. Genetic deletion of the newly identified protein Poldip2 protects against endothelial barrier opening and brain edema formation, and this proposal investigates the underlying cellular and molecular mechanisms with a goal towards developing new therapies.

PHR: Project Narrative (3 Sentences) As Director of the Core Laboratory for Advanced Cancer Image Analysis at the University of Washington, my approach for both multi-center and cooperative group research analysis begins with consultation during regular meetings encouraging the programs to collect as much information as practical for the study, periodically provide acquisition, reconstruction and imaging protocols, laboratory analysis for tracer metabolites, manage patient imaging studies, analyze the collected imaging and patient meta-data, provide advanced image processing procedures, generate model simulations, present the analysis results at conferences and through peer-reviewed publications. To ensure fulfillment of the specific aims I would actively pursue detailed analysis of the data including development of data structures for managing the information, providing both common and innovative data analysis methodology, performing simulations if necessary and co-author publications with particular emphasis on writing the technical methods of analysis of advanced imaging studies for a variety of cancers that benefits the scientific community.

Successful completion of this project will significantly advance understanding of the genetic basis for inflammatory signaling in keratinocytes, as well as its impact on skin inflammation heterogeneity and clinical outcomes among psoriatic patients. PHR: Maglia PROJECT NARRATIVE Among the techniques that have been proposed to sequence proteins at the single-molecule level, nanopores promise the high throughput sequencing of unlabelled and full-length proteins. The main challenges lie in controlling the unfolding and transport of proteins across nanopores, stretching the polypeptides and recognizing individual amino acids. Using his unique skills, the applicant will design nanopore-machines that will tackle the fundamental challenges in single-molecule nanopore sequencing. 1

PHR: Project Narrative: Cancer is a substantial public health burden. This NCI ARTNet Research Program aims to understand the basis of acquired drug resistance to improve cancer treatments and patient survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Each cell interacts with its environment, and 1000s of human genes encode the needed hormones, receptors, transporters, and enzymes. Most are produced in the secretory pathway, but the complexity of this pathway makes it difficult to diagnose the molecular basis of associated diseases, including Alzheimer’s disease, metabolic syndrome, cancer, and many infectious diseases. Here we develop a computational platform and experimental data resource enabling researchers to study the pathway as a whole system.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Little is known about monthly patterns in BMI change and associated obesogenic behaviors, the dynamic relationship of these behaviors with one another, the social, environmental, and biological determinates of these behaviors, and their link with changes in BMI in children. The proposed study will use the principles of developmental psychopathology to understand BMI development and associated behavioral, social, environmental, and biological determinates. This approach has the potential to uncover developmentally sensitive periods when children are susceptible to becoming obese and can provide insight into mechanisms for change.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Through mentored research training and career development of the next generation of interdisciplinary team members, leaders, and innovators in health services and patient-centered outcomes, clinical epidemiology, and dissemination and implementation, the UCLA Patient-Centered Outcomes Research Training in Urologic and Gynecologic Cancers (PCORT UroGynCan) program will increase the pace and volume of scientific discovery and innovation in the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of urologic and gynecologic cancers and advance our knowledge of delivery and implementation strategies for proven interventions in real-world practice and community settings. In closing the gap between evidence-based interventions and their uptake across diverse health services settings and populations, including historically underserved populations who manifest wide disparities in health status, PCORT UroGynCan will contribute to improved health system performance as well as outcomes and health-related quality of life of patients and their families.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are no targeted treatments for the dysregulated autonomic responses (‘dysautonomia’) of autism; yet, these disruptive physiologic responses that consist of alterations in heart rate, blood pressure, and perspiration affect over 70% of autistic individuals and contribute to significant disability. Building on a novel finding that the cerebellum, a brain region affected in autism, contains specific sites that control autonomic output, the proposed research will determine which cerebellar sites selectively influence autonomic physiologic responses and identify which sites are altered in a model of autism. Results are likely to advance our knowledge of the autonomic cerebellum and identify specific regions to therapeutically target for the dysautonomia prevalent in autism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will provide a high-content molecular imaging technology to visualize the molecular neighborhood of hundreds of genes to proteins used to perform widely deployed functions in cells and tissues. Normal cell cultures and tissues will be analyzed by the proposed technology to analyze how molecular neighbors operate in a specific role to affect a single cell's decision in intricate molecular crowds. Mathematical and theoretical analysis of these datasets will provide subcellular localization and neighborhood of protein and transcript molecules and their role in forming viable multicellular biological systems, an emerging spatially resolved subcellular regulation of health and disease.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to test the prosocial compound ± 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA) as a novel treatment for a debilitating symptom of schizophrenia, impaired social motivation. This project will proceed in two phases; the aim of Phase 1 will be to establish the tolerability of MDMA in this patient population, and the aim of Phase 2 will be to test the effects of MDMA on social motivation. Results from these studies will be foundational in identifying effective psychopharmacologic and combined psychopharmacologic- psychosocial therapies for social deficits in schizophrenia.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An improved therapeutic method treating opioid overdoes is urgently needed, as the efficacy of naloxone is considered suboptimal due to the relative short half-life and inability to counteract opioid- induced pharmacological effects beyond the mu opioid receptor signaling pathway. The proposed study will investigate the evolution of B cell receptor repertoire in response to opioid use and vaccination, and combined with structure-based antibodies design, to delineate the B cell response against opioids and vaccination, and to generate opioid-specific monoclonal antibodies with improved affinity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: To combat diseases, it is essential to study the function of biomolecules to understand the underlying disease mechanisms. Multi-frequency Electron Spin Resonance (ESR) spectroscopy, which is a powerful method to study functional dynamics of proteins, lacks sufficient sensitivity and resolution to carry out studies at physiological concentrations and longer time scales. The proposed research will develop computational methods to improve signal resolution in ESR spectroscopy, enabling better understanding of disease mechanisms for more effective therapies, thus benefiting the public health.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The build-up of tau protein in the brain closely tracks with symptoms of Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) and can be measured with specialized Positron Emission Tomography (PET) brain scans and blood tests; new treatments that reduce tau are predicted to produce greater clinical benefits than currently approved AD drugs. This study will test the ability of two tau therapies to reduce brain tau levels either alone or in combination with a drug that reduces amyloid protein in patients with very early AD. Using an efficient clinical trial design adapted from cancer research, the study will identify whether either tau therapy by itself or in combination with an anti-amyloid drug is promising enough to be tested in future large studies to determine meaningful clinical benefit, as well as whether blood tests for tau could reduce the need for expensive PET scans in future clinical trials.

PHR: Project Narrative The aim of the proposed research is to test the impact of a primary care-based intervention to prevent obesity in low-income Latino infants and toddlers. Latino children are at high risk of obesity and other diseases linked to obesity including type 2 diabetes. The goal of this study is to learn how to best promote health behaviors in early life that will result in lower risk of obesity in childhood and across the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narratives (Public Health Relevance) An outstanding mystery in embryo development is how cells sense and respond to tissue-scale changes. We propose that cells are integrating both biochemical and mechanical signals to accurately sense tissue information in order to make reliable decisions to control tissue development. The proposed experiments will reveal mechanochemical crosstalk mechanisms that address fundamental questions in development, explain disease pathologies such as birth defects and cancer, and inspire novel strategies to improve the consistency of artificial tissues for therapeutic applications.

PHR: Narrative  The overall objective of this Training Program is to prepare the next generation of leaders in Medical Oncology in laboratory and clinical translational sciences. The program will provide outstanding mentored laboratory and clinical investigation research experiences from senior and experienced junior faculty and support for the recruitment and mentorship of under-represented minority fellows. It is expected that at the conclusion of their training, individuals supported by this training program will have the ability to design, initiate, and complete individual clinical or laboratory research projects, will be able to function independently or with minimal supervision, and will be positioned to soon establish themselves as independent research investigators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Viral infections continue to pose significant economic and public health challenges worldwide, yet we still only poorly-understand the host defenses that inhibit viral replication and the immune evasion proteins (IEPs) employed by viruses to counter these host responses. Here we take a unique approach to identify IEPs encoded by mammalian pathogens that target evolutionarily-conserved antiviral host machinery by screening for IEPs that suppress antiviral immune responses in both insect and human cells. We will use these pathogen-encoded IEPs to identify and characterize the conserved host machinery they target and ultimately leverage this information to develop new strategies to defeat IEP function and block viral infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Signal transduction networks are the information processing engines of the cell, and their dysregulation leads to many human diseases. Despite their fundamental importance, little is understood about how signaling networks vary across individuals and human populations, and how this variation interacts with pathogenic mutations to drive disease. We will develop a research program focused on developing computational tools to predict protein- ligand interactions in signaling networks and applying them to large-scale genomic datasets to investigate variability and dysregulation of human cell signaling.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The state of Connecticut identifies “spikes,” or sudden increases in opioid overdoses and issues “spike alerts” to first responders, harm reduction organizations and health systems in order to help mount a rapid and effective public health response to curtail overdose rates and minimize fatalities. It is unclear if these alerts affect overdose rates, how alerts are used to guide public health responses in practice and if there are modifications to the system or alternative systems that would more effectively motivate responses to overdose spikes. To this end, I will 1) evaluate the causal effect of CT's spike response framework on overdoses, 2) survey harm reduction organizations, first responders and other healthcare workers to understand their use of the system, barriers they face when responding to overdoses and preferred modifications or alternatives to the existing system 3) develop an alternative to the current system based on survey feedback and simulate its effect, along with that of other preferred modifications and alternatives, on overdose rates, all with the aim of helping reduce overdose rates and subsequent deaths in Connecticut.

PHR: Project Narrative: RNA structure is important in both human health and disease, including genetic diseases and infectious diseases. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Glioblastoma is a brain tumor that cannot be cured with standard treatments (which include surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation), so patients with these tumors need new therapies that may work better. A type of genetic material in cancer patient immune cells differs from the immune cells of healthy people. By studying this genetic material, called long non-coding RNAs, in glioblastoma patient immune cells, we can help these cells attack brain tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Next-generation alchemical free energy methods and quantum/machine-learning  models for drug discovery. PI: Darrin M. York, Rutgers University, Piscataway, NJ 08854-8087 USA.  The current proposal addresses a critical barrier to progress in drug discovery: limitations in precision and accuracy of alchemical free energy simulations for prediction of ligand-protein binding afﬁnities. Speciﬁcally, new advanced technologies are proposed to enhance precision in alchemical free energy simulations, and a new quantum mechanical/deep-learning potential force ﬁeld is developed to improve accuracy of binding afﬁnity predictions. Methods and models will be carefully validated against several targets in collaboration with both academic and industry researchers.

PHR: Project Narrative Blood-brain barrier (BBB) deterioration is an important feature of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and vascular cognitive impairment (VCI) that frequently precedes cognitive symptoms, yet the process is poorly understood and as a result there are currently no protective treatments. I have established a novel role of the prostaglandin degrading enzyme 15-PGDH in protecting the BBB in a mouse model of AD, and am expanding the study to a VCI model in the F99 phase of this project. During the subsequent K00 phase, I will incorporate the role of metabolic changes of perivascular macrophages in regulating BBB health by interacting with endothelial cells, in order to provide new insight into the discovery and development of neuroprotective opportunities for patients suffering from AD and VCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PHR Status epilepticus (SE) and refractory status epilepticus (RSE) continue to be medical emergencies and more effective treatments for rapid seizure control are needed. The goal of this preclinical SIR application is to test tolerability, safety, and efficacy of the novel intravenous formulation of topiramate in a clinically relevant rat model of RSE. The expected outcome of this work is to generate data for a pre-IND meeting to enable the future conduct of a phase I and Ila program and to enable the first-in-human proof of concept study of intravenous topiramate.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTMs) cause infections that often result in chronic disease that is near impossible to cure and extremely difficult to treat. This project aims to identify and characterize specific interactions that result in innate drug resistance and treatment failure in NTMs. This work could lead to development of specific inhibitors that would effectively treat these notoriously difficult pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastomas are the most common and deadly malignant tumors of the central nervous system, and are incurable with current therapies. In this application, we propose to test the therapeutic relevance of the YAP and TAZ transcriptional effectors and to test the efficacy and mechanisms of action of the FDA-approved drug and YAP/TAZ inhibitor verteporfin in pre-clinical human cortical organoid glioblastoma models, in animal models of glioblastoma, and in human patient specimens. If successful, this project will establish a basis for repurposing verteporfin as a treatment for GBM.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sequential therapy of solid tumors with tumor targeted radiation therapy followed by untargeted immune therapy has shown promise in the clinic. This approach can be further improved by using targeted immune therapy and studying the immune response on tumor biopsies taken before and after therapy. Using a combination of clinical and animal model data, we will refine the therapeutic doses and identify the best predictive markers of response to therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is centered around determining the role of an RNA binding protein, HuR, in cardiac fibrosis. Preliminary data suggests that HuR is involved in the propagation of pathological fibrosis through stabilizing the upregulation of extracellular matrix proteins. Therefore, we believe a fibroblast specific deletion of HuR will be cardio-protective and further HuR as a therapeutic target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Music-based interventions are receiving increasing attention for their promising effects on acute pain and chronic pain. Although the pain-relieving effects of music-based interventions are well- established, lack of understanding of how music affects pain prevents us from exploiting their full therapeutic potential. The purpose of the Music4Pain Network is to establish a multidisciplinary research network to support innovative research aimed at advancing mechanistic understanding of music for pain.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The opioid epidemic in the US continues at a cost of over $1.5T and over 75,000 deaths annually. Poor sleep is a major risk factor that both influences opioid problems and is influenced by opioid treatments and opioids themselves. Improved understanding of mechanisms that link sleep and opioid-related factors, such as changes in craving and/or ability to regulate emotions may highlight new opportunities for targeted treatment.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although some patients have durable disease control with current cancer immunotherapies, many fail to respond or progress after initially experiencing tumor regression. This proposal seeks to develop new, mechanism-based cellular immunotherapies to target melanoma and other common cancers with specific genetic alterations associated with resistance to current treatments. As part of these studies, new generalizable knowledge will be generated that improves our molecular understanding of how the adaptive immune system can distinguish between normal and transformed tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Disparities by race/ethnicity and disability status in food insecurity and healthcare outcomes are linked. The Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) has been shown to reduce but not eliminate food insecurity, suggesting that enhanced levels of SNAP benefits may further reduce food insecurity and associated unfavorable healthcare outcomes, particularly among racial/ethnic minorities and people w ith disabilities, for whom these phenomena are disproportionately prevalent and impactful. While addressing concurrent pandemic and public policy-related changes (Aim 1), this project will exploit (i) both national Medicaid data and a novel set of linked claims, public health, and administrative SNAP data from Massachusetts and (ii) a staggered set of natural experiments created by the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA) to examine the effects of SNAP benefits on healthcare outcomes (Aim 2) and disparities by race/ethnicity and disability status (Aim 3) in MA and the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PI: Savoy Project Narrative Development of a conformable thermoelectric cooling/heating device would solve issues of traditional thermal and cold therapy by eliminating the need for dedicated refrigeration systems, coolers or chilled liquid circulators, gels, or ice. The inability to produce large-area flexible thermoelectric devices is a significant shortcoming that has kept these highly effective devices from being adapted into the form factor required for a low-profile solid-state cryotherapy device. Modern water/ice cooling methods can sometimes damage tissue by over-cooling and if continuously fed, require pumps, tanks and tubes that can be prone to leaks. The benefits in patient mobility, lower risk of deep vein thrombosis, and hands-free utility of a therapeutic regimen by conforming to a specific region of the body (i.e. “wearable”) and uniformly extract heat energy with power requirements commensurate with wearable batteries are numerous.

PHR: Project Narrative In 2019, Alzheimer’s and other dementias cost the U.S. $290 billion, and these costs could rise to as high as $1.1 trillion by 2050, which increases the urgency of developing new therapies to prevent, defer, slow the progression or improve the symptoms of these disorders using innovative clinical and basic research approaches. The goal of this project is to identify novel peripheral-central neuro-immune interactome-mediated sex differences that will assist in the development of clinically relevant preventive and therapeutic strategies to reduce the morbidity and mortality of AD. The successful completion of this project will advance the understanding of sex differences in AD and serve as the foundation for further translational studies to inform the development of precision medicine in a sex-specific manner.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Programs that engage and sustain interest in science, health professions and cancer research among American Indian and Alaska Native (AI/AN) students and their teachers from middle school through college are desperately needed. With an experienced team, cutting-edge campus resources and strong partnership support, the Youth Enjoy Science program will continue to build community trust and recruit participants through outreach, train participants through research experiences, and develop and implement Indigenous science and cancer education curriculum and career development activities. Our aim is to not only increase AI/AN representation in cancer-related health professions and research but also advance the health of AI/ANs through improvements in cancer prevention, treatment, and research in AI/AN communities.

PHR: ROC narrative HIV treatment and prevention in Rakai have led to dramatic declines in orphanhood. Measuring and understanding the relationship between HIV treatment and prevention, orphanhood, and new HIV infection among AYA will be essential in guiding future HIV prevention and social policies to promote child, adolescent, and young adult health. The ROC (Rakai Orphans in Communities) project will apply innovative qualitative and quantitative methods to broaden understanding of the impact of declining orphanhood on youth risk of HIV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The L.S. Skaggs Institute for Health Innovation (SIHI) Research Evaluation and Commercialization Hub (SIHI- REACH) at the University of Montana will accelerate translation of academic discoveries into products that impact human health in states that have largely not benefitted from investment in commercialization. We have partnered with 10 academic institutions in the Washington, Wyoming, Alaska, Montana, Idaho (WWAMI) region—including a community, a technological, and a tribal college—and are building upon the success of the Washington Entrepreneurial REACH (WE-REACH) at the University of Washington. Participating institutions and innovators will gain access to funding, training, and resources to guide the research and development of new medical products, ultimately fostering a pro-entrepreneurial culture across the region, creating new small businesses, and bringing products to market that address disease burden and health disparities. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Interstitial fibrosis a strong predictor of future decline in kidney function and development of kidney failure is not readily available in most patients with kidney disease because: a) A kidney biopsy which is rarely performed is needed to estimate interstitial fibrosis and b) A non-invasive test to estimate interstitial fibrosis is not available. Kidney ultrasonography is a routine non-invasive test in assessment of kidney disease and the current study will utilize artificial intelligence techniques to develop a model to estimate interstitial fibrosis from a kidney ultrasonography image. The proposed research is relevant to NIH mission because developing a non-invasive test to estimate interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy will lead to better prediction of future decline in kidney function and monitoring of treatment in all patients with kidney disease.

PHR: CURED OVERALL: Project Narrative The BCM-TSU P20 “Collaborative Union for Cancer Research, Education and Disparities (CURED)” Proposal will establish a formal collaborative alliance between BCM and TSU for cancer research, education, and community outreach. Our multipronged approach will maximize the strengths of each institution and leverage existing collaborative relationships to create a shared infrastructure between BCM and TSU that will provide an optimal environment for cancer research, education, community outreach, and opportunities for career development and pathway enhancement focused on diversifying the biomedical workforce. BCM-TSU P20 CURED will also develop sustainable research capacity and obtain preliminary data through pilot projects that will develop into independent investigator research applications and collaborative applications to the NIH/NCI and/or other Federal/Non-federal funding agencies.

PHR: Addressing the drug diversion problem is a multi-faceted problem involving many components ranging from provider training to implementation of hardware and software systems to manage access to controlled substances. However, despite recent improvements in controlling and monitoring access to controlled substances, the process of identifying drug diversion and ensuring compliance is complicated and time consuming. Our overall goal is to further develop a technology based on blockchains to track and document transportation and administration of controlled substances in a hospital environment and detect drug diversion.

PHR: Cyclin-dependent kinase 4 and 6 inhibitors (CDK4/6i) have recently emerged as a new treatment strategy for hormone receptor (ER/PR) positive (HR+), human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2)-negative (HR+/Her2-) subtype of breast cancer (BC) patients. Recent studies suggest that their benefit may be restricted only to non-Hispanic European American (EA) BC patients, without significant improvement in African American (AA) or Hispanics patients. Using patient interviews, computational modeling and functional studies, this project will analyze the social determinants and genetic aspects contributing to CDK4/6i therapy resistance in AA BC patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite receiving significant NIH research funding, Texas academic researchers face major challenges as they seek to commercialize their discoveries, including a lack of training and support programs to help them appropriately value and validate their technology. To address this deficit, the Gulf Coast Consortia Research Evaluation and Commercialization Hub (GCC-REACH) will assist academic and medical entrepreneurs to effectively, efficiently, and successfully commercialize their biomedical discoveries. The GCC-REACH is a multi- institutional trans-Texas resource that will be based in Houston's Texas Medical Center and operated by the Gulf Coast Consortia.

PHR: Genetic Basis of the Risk and Consequences of Cannabis Exposure in Humans Cannabis use is associated with negative outcomes including cannabis use disorder (CanUD), psychosis, and cognitive impairment. PHR: CURED C-REP Project Narrative The CURED C-REP will provide an 8-weeks mentored cancer research experience that integrates Baylor College of Medicine (BCM) and Texas Southern University (TSU) infrastructures every summer followed by year- long culturally congruent outreach education activities that will increase the awareness, knowledge, and understanding of research, concepts, processes, and careers in cancer research/cancer health disparities a cohort of 20 underrepresented minority students from TSU. The proposed CURED C-REP will enhance cancer research education capacity at TSU, promote the diversity of the cancer research workforce and improve BCM’s effectiveness in developing and sustaining research programs focused on cancer health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH  Millions of Americans suffer from Fibromyalgia syndrome (FMS) and experience severe disability and diminished quality of life, making it a significant public health problem. The goal of this project is to develop and validate a multivariate regression index in rats that will mimic current clinical fibromyalgia indices which will be used to evaluate the suitability of a novel rat model of FMS. This model will be highly desirable for drug screening and pharmacologic testing because it will exhibit improved face, construct and predictive validities compared with existing preclinical FMS models.

PHR: Impacts of hurricanes and social buffering on biological aging in a free-ranging animal model Age is the strongest predictor of risk for a multitude of diseases, yet the extent to which natural disasters impact aging remains unclear. This project investigates how and in what ways major natural disasters, in the form of hurricane impacts, have modified the pace of aging in a nonhuman primate model, the rhesus macaque. Our results will reveal how and to what extent natural disasters impact the onset of age-related declines, which will inform the targeted development of behavioral and physiological interventions that could reduce the burden of aging-related disease in our aging population.

PHR: The proposed work is relevant to public health, given its focus on unraveling molecular mechanisms of Alzheimer’s disease, which can be extended to other neurodegenerative diseases. The proposed research will help to explain how the disease- prone protein aggregates appear and develop, which in future studies will be used to develop approaches controlling the aggregation process. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH’s mission pertaining to developing fundamental knowledge that will improve preventive and therapeutic treatments for diseases.

PHR: Narrative The number of drug overdoses in New York continues to rise, with 4,946 deaths involving opioids in 2021. In response, the New York State Office of Addiction Services and Supports (OASAS) is promoting new approaches that embrace person-centered care, evidence-based practices, equitable treatment, and harm reduction principles. OASAS and New York University will build a quality measurement and management (QM2) research center that provides performance feedback to activate leadership and staff of clinics to improve practice as well as publicizes quality measures to ensure public accountability.

PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will characterize a novel molecular mechanism by which cells control the expression of TAR DNA-binding protein-43 (TDP-43) through RNA modification of its transcript. Because TDP-43 pathology is present in a wide array of neurodegenerative diseases, these findings will have an important impact by advancing our mechanistic understanding of TDP-43 requirement for neuronal survival and by providing new targets for innovative therapies for age-related TDP-43 proteinopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: Atopic dermatitis (AD) is one of the most common inflammatory skin diseases in humans. Although the disease has been studied for decades, we still do not have a clear understanding of the mechanisms regulating the development of cutaneous AD. In this proposal, we will characterize a novel biological mechanism that involves fibroblast dysregulation in the formation of AD-like lesions in mice, examine similar events in human AD specimens and test potential therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of the University of Maryland BaltImore Life Science Discovery (UM-BILD) Accelerator is to create a new NIH Research Evaluation and Commercialization Hub (REACH) program that serves as a development engine to build the life science economy in West Baltimore and Greater Baltimore and to train one of the most diverse biomedical and entrepreneurial workforces in the US. Formed from a partnership by University of Maryland, Baltimore, the University of Maryland School of Medicine, University of Maryland, Baltimore County, Morgan State University, University of Maryland College Park, and the Maryland Innovation Initiative, UM-BILD will embrace existing partner programmatic efforts to increase biomedical workforce diversity such as the University of Maryland FIRST program. Enabled by a greater than $5 million non-federal match, the UM-BILD hub will: 1) provide pilot funds for commercialization-potential technologies to advance to the next stage; 2) utilize internal core services/equipment as a dedicated-life science incubator; 3) offer dedicated business training programs to diverse investigators and founders; and 4) mentor and network innovators for fundraising to further advance successful technology projects (SBIR/STTR awards, venture capital).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Single-particle cryogenic electron microscopy (cryo-EM) is electron microscopy (EM) of biological molecules embedded in vitreous ice specimens. Time-resolved cryo-EM examines specimens that reflect biomolecular reactions occurring for a series of controlled time durations. We will develop a technology for preparing cryo-EM specimens with submillisecond reaction times to enable time-resolved cryo-EM studies of short-lived intermediate states of biomolecular systems.

PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance Statement: This research is highly relevant to public health because infertility is a significant problem in a growing population of male childhood cancer survivors. Adapting a web-based sperm banking decision tool to increase usability and acceptability and identifying tailored implementation strategies to ensure feasibility and equity, will improve reproductive outcomes and enhance quality of life. This is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will extend human life and help to reduce the burdens of illness and disability, and specifically NCI’s mission to reduce the burden of cancer morbidity and mortality.

PHR: Project Narrative: More than 40,000 new rectal cancers occur annually in the US and current treatment strategies (chemotherapy, radiation and surgery) provide a 5-year disease survival of only 65%. Therefore, there is an unmet need for new treatment approaches that improve LARC clinical outcomes and reduce morbidity. We propose to examine adding a new therapy (inhibition of the enzyme IDO1) to rectal cancer therapy that may improve overall cure rates and reduce treatment related toxicity.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Residential histories provide a historical record of the social and physical environment that can have a lasting impact on health; however, few cancer research studies have incorporated life-course residential histories for underrepresented populations. To remedy this, we will develop methods to reconstruct life-course residential histories for a racially diverse and low socioeconomic population and link to area-level environmental exposures to identify cancer disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Mid-South REACH program will accelerate real-world impact of biomedical innovations through entrepreneurial education, mentorship, and financial support for aspiring entrepreneurs. The significance of this endeavor stems from the potential to turn academic discoveries into real-world products that can help patients and doctors, and to catalyze a medical innovation economy in states that have a robust, yet relatively untapped, pipeline of innovation but limited resources to translate this innovation into knowledge-based biomedical technology industry. Leveraging substantial state and institutional commitments, the Mid-South REACH Hub will exponentially expand its impact and ensure a self-sustaining innovation network.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Real-time fMRI neurofeedback allows participants to volitionally modulate their own brain activity. Here we will test whether neurofeedback can be enhanced by using the signal derived from the brains of others (i.e., brain- to-brain neural transmission) in people with heroin addiction. If a stronger neural alignment during watching of a drug-related movie between people in early as compared to later recovery is associated with decreased cue- induced craving, results could pave the way towards the development of a new intervention to scaffold recovery in heroin addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Group 1 CD1 molecules present both microbial and self-lipid antigens to T cells. However, little is known about how these lipid-specific T cells are regulated and whether they can mount an effective memory T cell response. This study proposes to investigate how hyperlipidemia impacts lipid antigen-specific T cells and to identify molecular signatures associated with memory group 1 CD1-restricted T cells in vaccination and Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection settings. We anticipate that these studies will illuminate new strategies for targeting these T cells in autoimmune disease and vaccine development.

PHR: Project Narrative Osteoporosis affects 10 million older Americans, and is associated with significant morbidity, mortality, and costs. Although there are many effective osteoporosis treatment options, no single therapy is recommended for indefinite use and thus long-term management of osteoporosis involves transitions between agents. Optimal approaches to long-term osteoporosis treatment, including how best to manage sequential and possibly combination use of different types of medications over a patient’s lifetime, are unknown and a major knowledge gap in the field. With the work described in this proposal, we aim to provide evidence to guide treatment decisions over the lifetime for patients with osteoporosis. To do so, we propose to first perform meta-analyses of clinical studies on the efficacy of sequential and combination osteoporosis treatment strategies; and then carry out comprehensive cost-effectiveness analyses to compare the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of a variety of long-term treatment strategies for patients with osteoporosis with different clinical characteristics.

PHR: CURED OVERALL: Project Narrative The BCM-TSU P20 “Collaborative Union for Cancer Research, Education and Disparities (CURED)” Proposal will establish a formal collaborative alliance between BCM and TSU for cancer research, education, and community outreach. Our multipronged approach will maximize the strengths of each institution and leverage existing collaborative relationships to create a shared infrastructure between BCM and TSU that will provide an optimal environment for cancer research, education, community outreach, and opportunities for career development and pathway enhancement focused on diversifying the biomedical workforce. BCM-TSU P20 CURED will also develop sustainable research capacity and obtain preliminary data through pilot projects that will develop into independent investigator research applications and collaborative applications to the NIH/NCI and/or other Federal/Non-federal funding agencies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To better translate biomedical discoveries from Chicago based Universities, we propose the Chicago Biomedical Consortium Hub for Innovative Technology and Entrepreneurship in the Sciences (CBC – HITES), a service center that provides academic investigators who have ideas for new biopharmaceutical inventions with the research, analysis, planning, and execution needed to turn scientific ideas into commercial products. To ensure that CBC – HITES inclusively grows the Chicago economy, the hub will capture ideas from nine diverse Chicago institutions and (1) include all of the necessary expertise – clinical, technical, regulatory – into the analysis process; (2) integrate end buyers – the Venture Capitalists and industry scouts who fund early biotech ideas – into the funding process; (3) include the operations and execution personnel needed to generate results – project managers – into the post-funding execution and (4) serve as a training ground for Entrepreneurial Fellows who experientially learn by delivering analyses, plans, and execution to the academic innovator and then work in Chicago’s life sciences ecosystem.

PHR: Cyclin-dependent kinase 4 and 6 inhibitors (CDK4/6i) have recently emerged as a new treatment strategy for hormone receptor (ER/PR) positive (HR+), human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2)-negative (HR+/Her2-) subtype of breast cancer (BC) patients. Recent studies suggest that their benefit may be restricted only to non-Hispanic European American (EA) BC patients, without significant improvement in African American (AA) or Hispanics patients. Using patient interviews, computational modeling and functional studies, this project will analyze the social determinants and genetic aspects contributing to CDK4/6i therapy resistance in AA BC patients.

PHR: Narrative Historically ribosomes were believed to translate whatever transcript they were presented with, but recent studies suggest that ribosome composition varies and plays a significant role in the regulation of translation. This proposal will provide insight into how methylation of ribosomal RNA changes with age to produce specialized ribosomes to control the translation of specific transcripts in response to environmental stressors and organismal aging. We have found that methylation of 18S ribosomal RNA plays a crucial role in regulating longevity and the stress response in C. elegans and propose to identify the molecular basis by which methylation of rRNAs specify distinct translational outcomes in response to environmental stimuli.

PHR: The Chronic Disease Self-Management program (CDSMP) is shown to improve disease self-management skills and behaviors in a range of clinical populations. I propose to adapt the CDSMP for primary care patients with opioid use disorder (OUD) and serious mental illness (SMI), assess its feasibility and acceptability in a small randomized trial, qualitatively evaluate its implementation in a primary care environment using the Rapid Assessment Procedure Informed Clinical Ethnography procedure. I will also engage in career development and training activities that will enhance my expertise in adapting, implementing, and testing of a CDSMP for persons with OUD and SMI.

PHR: NARRATIVE Primary care plays an essential role in the prevention, treatment and ongoing management of the many chronic conditions that contribute not only to premature death and disability overall, but also to the pervasive health disparities observed among older adults in the United States. This project will use a unique national data set spanning the years 2015 through 2024 to: (1) describe the magnitude of inequities in primary care access and quality for Medicare beneficiaries; (2) understand how these changed during this period; and (3) identify high-leverage interventions that can be taken by policy makers, health system leaders, and primary care practices to improve care and reduce health disparities among older adults.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this program is to increase the number of cancer researchers conducting comparative effectiveness research (CER) at the national level. The proposed intensive curriculum will provide program participants with a strong foundation in CER, and the knowledge and skills to design and conduct CER studies including ‘real-world’ observational studies, pragmatic clinical trials and knowledge synthesis. The program will benefit public health by advancing the use of comparative evidence, which can inform cancer patients, caregivers and providers of the benefits and harms of alternative healthcare options and provide value-based care that can extend the length and quality of life of cancer patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Hutchinson-Gilford progeria syndrome (HGPS) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the rapid onset of premature aging beginning in childhood. We propose to investigate whether disrupted epigenetic control contributes to some of the premature aging symptoms in HGPS. The outcome of this proposed research could potentially open avenues for new therapeutic approaches to treat progeria and shed light on the mechanisms in normal aging.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE The National Dementia Workforce Study (NDWS) will be launched by a national team of experts in clinical care of persons living with dementia, survey research, and health workforce research. The core of NDWS will be four surveys that reflect key elements of the professional dementia care workforce in the U.S.: Community Clinicians, Nursing Home Staff, Assisted Living Staff, and Home Care Staff. By pairing the surveys with additional linked data sources, the NDWS data infrastructure will allow researchers and policymakers to ask critical questions related to the care provided to the growing population of persons living with dementia in the U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol associated liver disease (AALD) is one of the major liver diseases with a high mortality rate but no effective drug treatment for AALD at present. Our project for the first time aims at developing a personalized genetic medicine for AALD, which has a great impact to both improving the human health and reducing social burden due to this deadly disease. We use novel and unprecedented approach in this project, which has a great potential to establish a new paradigm for drug develop for other common diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Child abuse and neglect (CAN) is a pressing and costly public health issue, and economic support policies may be effective strategies towards reducing CAN by strengthening families' economic well-being and reducing related stress. This proposed project will rigorously examine the impact of state-based economic support policies during and post COVID in preventing CAN, and engage families and service providers in how policies are implemented at the local level to identify effective CAN prevention strategies in community settings. Findings will inform states' selection and implementation of policies to prevent CAN and prepare the PI to engage in independent, community-based, and policy-relevant research.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative The contribution of chromosomal sex in aging and Alzheimer's disease (AD) has been largely ignored. Yet, the development of sex-specific targets in aging and AD is an attractive therapeutic strategy to treat AD patients of both sexes. This project aims to investigate whether the E3 ubiquitin ligase HUWE1 which gene is located on the X chromosome escapes inactivation in aging and AD and to determine its sex-specific interactome in aging and AD.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most Latinx childhood cancer survivors do not attain recommended amounts of physical activity and are generally sedentary, which increases their risk of chronic health conditions. This project in adolescent and young adult Latinx childhood cancer survivors whose preferred language is Spanish or English will culturally tailor and the test the efficacy of a new physical activity intervention consisting of a physical activity tracker integrated with individualized goal setting and a private social media group to improve physical activity, cardiovascular health, and quality of life. If efficacious, this portable and scalable intervention will fill a critical gap to reduce complications from cancer treatment among Latinx survivors.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Orlance’s Gene Gun uniquely enables needle-free delivery of DNA and RNA vaccines into the epidermis of the skin. We hypothesize that the ability of the gene gun to directly deliver DNA and RNA into cells in the epidermis will make it more effective than conventional intramuscular delivery of DNA and RNA vaccines in targeting tumor cells localized in the skin. Here, we will optimize gene gun delivery of DNA or RNA to identify a regimen that induces strong tumor specific immune responses and protection from melanoma in a mouse model.

PHR: The overarching goals of this research are to validate and improve personalized breast cancer risk assessment tools leveraging extensive mammographic, genetic, and epidemiologic/clinical data from large national cohorts, the Black Women’s Health Study and the Sister Study. We will apply methods in deep learning to mammographic images along with recent genetic risk assessment approaches to advance precise risk stratification while addressing critical gaps in the current evidence base. Findings from this study will inform screening and risk reduction strategies and ultimately help close the gap in racial disparities in breast cancer.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Narrative Despite widespread recognition of the benefits associated with opioid agonist therapy, few persons with opioid use disorder (OUD) who need treatment are currently taking either buprenorphine or methadone and the prevalence of OUD and number of overdoses continues to escalate. A landmark study has provided high certainty evidence supporting the initiation of buprenorphine in emergency department (ED), yet uptake remains low. The objective of this proposal is to develop and test VR-Choice, an immersive virtual reality experience designed to motivate eligible patients to agree to treatment with buprenorphine in the ED.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Virtual reality at the point of care to increase uptake of MOUD in the ED

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While much work has examined non-adherence in pediatric chronic illness, little is known about non-adherence in children with hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT), and even less is known about how race and ethnicity affects medication non-adherence rates among HSCT recipients, however there are significant disparities in adherence among underserved minority groups. There is a critical need to evaluate novel mHealth approaches to promote equitable care and reduce health disparities among children receiving HSCT, particularly the growing numbers of Spanish-speaking families. Culturally appropriate, adapted digital interventions could be easily delivered to linguistically diverse families as a frontline approach to family education and care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This proposal investigates the mechanisms of motor deficits of cerebral palsy and congenital tetrahydrobiopterin deficiency, which involve formation of destructive reactive chemical species in early brain injury resulting in cell death. New information about which forms of cell death, how they affect brain cells, and how effective potential therapies are in an animal model of cerebral palsy will be very valuable for future drug development in human studies.

PHR: (No Change) The paraventricular nucleus of thalamus (PVT) to nucleus accumbens (NA) pathway is a potent target for preventing relapse, but its molecular mechanisms are largely unknown. We propose to use single cell transcriptomic profiling and imaging to identify opioid responsive cell types in both regions and its epigenomic mechanisms in the PVT. Our proposed studies will help identify novel targets for treating opioid addiction

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it seeks to create a research network to expand our understanding of how music-based interventions (MBIs) work to alleviate pain. The research network, comprised of a cross disciplinary team comprised music therapists, engineers, psychologists, social workers, and basic scientists, will also explore new, interesting ways to measure pain during music experiences. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission to understanding and optimizing the use of MBIs to improve health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to build living models of the human endometrium to mimic the phase of the menstrual cycle where human embryo implantation normally occurs. Using samples from consented patients, and combining them with microfluidics, tissue engineering, single cell genomics, spatial transcriptomics, and proteomics, we test they ways the in vitro models faithfully capture the features of the human endometrium and its response to the changes in hormones that mature then endometrium as it prepapres to host an embryo. These models can be used to compare patients with and without certain diseases, like heavy menstrual bleeding or recurrent pregnancy loss, and to develop therapies for these and other conditions.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because of the critical need for more effective treatments for osteoarthritis (OA), which is a common disease with a large societal impact. This work focuses on the role of DNA damage and cellular senescence in chondrocytes and synovial cells and is expected to contribute new knowledge on the mechanisms responsible for the development of OA. These findings will support future novel interventions to prevent, slow, and treat this disease of the joint that is often painful and debilitating.

PHR: NARRATIVE Cancer patients are increasingly using a diverse set of cannabis and cannabinoid products to treat cancer- related symptoms, despite limited evidence of beneficial effects and largely unknown risk. This study, which is a collaboration with the NCI Community Oncology Research Program (NCORP), will measure the complex variability of the real-life context of cannabis and cannabinoid use among a large cohort of cancer patients recruited through NCORP clinics across the U.S. We will longitudinally assess the impact of these complexities on the course of cancer care, from diagnosis through the treatment experience, providing critical evidence to inform future clinical trials and practice-based recommendations.

PHR: Narrative Leukemia stem cells are responsible for poor clinical outcomes in patients with acute myeloid leukemia, and the proposed research addresses a need to better understand the mechanisms that underlie their function. We recently discovered that the cell surface marker CD99 promotes leukemia stem cell self-renewal by constraining protein synthesis, establishing a new link between regulated protein synthesis and leukemia stem cell function. By elucidating the mechanisms underlying why leukemia stem cells depend on regulation of protein synthesis across different subtypes of acute myeloid leukemia, this project has the potential to establish a new paradigm for how cancer stem cells sustain themselves, as well as to guide the design of more effective therapies targeting leukemia stem cells to improve clinical outcomes for patients with acute myeloid leukemia.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Legalization of cannabis has led to the proliferation of new cannabis products with various modes of administration (e.g., vaping, edibles, dabbing, blunts) with differing THC potency and health risks for pregnant women; yet, we know little about how women use cannabis pre- and during pregnancy, whether modes vary with socio-demographics or local cannabis policies, or how modes relate to cannabis use frequency, cannabis use disorder (CUD), polysubstance use, quitting cannabis use in pregnancy, or adverse health outcomes. In a mixed-methods study of ~310,000 racially and ethnically diverse pregnancies screened for prenatal substance use by self-report and urine toxicology testing within Kaiser Permanente Northern CA (KPNC) from 2021-2026, this research will examine socio-demographic and policy correlates of modes of use pre- and during pregnancy, test how modes relate to the risk of daily use, CUD, polysubstance use, substance use disorders (SUD), quitting pre- or during pregnancy, addiction treatment, and cannabis-related psychiatric and medical outcomes, and conduct interviews with women who used cannabis before and/or during pregnancy. Together, results will have immediate public health and clinical implications, providing important data to identify potentially actionable areas for future prevention and intervention efforts to reduce harms associated with prenatal cannabis use.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In Philadelphia, government and community partnerships have resulted in structural interventions to remediate vacant lots, abandoned buildings, and dilapidated homes to improve neighborhood disorder; these interventions have shown significant positive impacts on neighborhood crime and mental health. This study will examine the impact of these highly-innovative interventions on opioid misuse and fatal and nonfatal opioid overdose. Findings will provide support for expanding neighborhood disorder remediation projects in Philadelphia and promote similar public health-based policy and community-level health interventions for opioid overdose prevention in other cities.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Narrative Aggression is an evolutionarily conserved, adaptive component of social behavior that, in certain circumstances, can become escalated thereby threatening lives, increasing the risk of developing psychiatric disease in victims and incurring tremendous economic burdens to society. Despite this, we have a limited understanding of neural mechanisms that drive aggression vs. pro-social behavior, particularly in females. In this application, we take a novel data driven approach to predict aggression-related brain networks and then test casual hypotheses about their role in aggressive vs pro-social behavior.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Identifying and understanding genetic risk factors driving ovarian cancer disparities is critical to improve risk assessment, treatment paradigms, and patient outcomes. The Wnt ligand WNT4 is an underexplored risk factor, as we find that a common single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) at the WNT4 locus activates WNT4 signaling and drives therapy resistance, while the divergent frequency of this SNP across ethnic populations suggests that the variant underpins cancer disparities in ovarian cancer risk and outcomes. Defining the functional consequence of WNT4 in gynecologic cancers is essential to understand disease risk and etiology, develop precision treatments, and address cancer health disparities linked to the WNT4 variant allele.

PHR: Project Narrative A fundamental question in biology is why cells age and permanently cease to divide, a process called cellular senescence. The proposed project uses modern, single-cell technologies to characterize the onset of senescence, to determine how senescence relates to a transient state of cell-cycle withdrawal called quiescence, and to develop a molecular framework that can predict a cell’s likelihood of re-entering the cell cycle and its physiological age. Since chronological age is the major predictor for most human diseases, the proposed work could impact the treatment of multiple diseases by developing treatments to slow or even reverse human aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Ischemic stroke is the most frequent cause of long-term severe disability and places an enormous economic burden on society. A critical aspect in guiding treatment decisions is determining the penumbra, i.e., the region of injured brain tissue around the ischemic core that can potentially be revived. The overarching goal of this proposal is investigating the use of hyperpolarized 13C metabolic imaging in a novel endovascular pig stroke model as a new tool for improved detection of stroke penumbra that can be translated into the clinic.

PHR: Project Narrative Computerized clinical decision support (CDS) offers a promising strategy to standardize and scale evidence- based practices to keep pace with the dynamic nature of the opioid crisis and overcome barriers to addiction treatment. To change practice, CDS must be useful, usable, integrated into routine care delivery, and supported by a multicomponent implementation strategy. We will refine and evaluate the uptake, usability, and equity of a nationally disseminated multicomponent CDS intervention to increase treatment initiation in the emergency care of people with opioid use disorder.

PHR: Title: Assigning mode of action to phenotypically discovered anticancer leads . Narrative. Developing drugs from natural sources is difficult because we don't know how they work. If it works, it could make it much easier to develop new anticancer drugs.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Computer tomography (CT) scans are a common diagnostic test ordered for patients. The goal of our research is to apply artificial intelligence (AI) models to CTs to measure structural features of abdominal organs and tissues. We will then determine if organ and tissue changes are associated with organ-specific disease, hospitalization, and death.

PHR: Project Narrative Uncertainty in exposure measurements is a major source of bias in epidemiologic research aimed at elucidating causal relationships between risk factors, such as physical activity, in relation to cancer incidence and mortality, and misclassification of cancer incidence induces additional bias in studies based upon electronic health record data and other administrative ‘big data’ sources of information, such as Medicare claims data. We will develop novel epidemiological methods for valid and efficient estimation of nutritional and lifestyle effects on cancer risk, from estimation of relative risks related to within-individual change in lifestyle exposures to resolving challenges arising in the study of physical activity, diet, co-morbidities and health behaviors in relation to cancer risk due to measurement uncertainty, and apply these new methods to studies arising in the American Cancer Society’s Cancer Prevention Study II, Harvard’s Nurses' Health Study, the National Cancer Institute’s IDATA, Harvard’s Women’s and Men’s Lifestyle Validation Studies, and Yale New Haven’s Epic EHR data. With a major emphasis on methods dissemination, publicly available user-friendly software will accompany all new methods, a massive online open course (MOOC) will be developed, and short courses will be offered at national and international epidemiology and statistics conferences.

PHR: NARRATIVE These experiments study an enzyme known as RAG that performs an essential function in the development of the immune system but which occasionally makes mistakes and generates aberrations in human chromosomes that can contribute to the development blood cancers such as lymphoma and leukemia. This work studies how RAG and evolutionarily related enzymes cut DNA and interact with the human genome with the goal of discovering the causes of these mistakes and methods by which they could be prevented.
