PHR: Narrative  The model organism C. elegans has proven to be invaluable for discovery of mechanisms that influence aging and metabolism. Here we will build upon our recent work in C. elegans to determine how the master gene regulator SKN-1A/Nrf1 responds to the unsaturated fat oleic acid to benefit the organism and increase lifespan. We will also determine how stress in the protein synthesis machinery alters metabolism, and why this gene regulator is then protective, work that will provide fundamental insights into mechanisms that maintain protein synthesis and may suggest strategies for treating the human genetic disease Diamond- Blackfan anemia.

PHR: Project Narrative Disparities in breast cancer-related outcomes are pervasive and have been widely documented among racial and ethnic minorities, especially Black women. Substantial evidence demonstrates that routine patient-reported outcome (PRO) data collection using health information technology (HIT) results in improved cancer care delivery; however, PRO reporting remains low among Black patients and within the community cancer care (CCC) settings where they often receive care, and this increases disparities. The objectives of this project, in partnership with the Association of Community Cancer Centers, are to use implementation science and health equity frameworks to develop and implement routine HIT-assisted collection of PRO data at CCCs serving a high proportion of Black patients with breast cancer to produce and disseminate generalizable knowledge that can be used to unlock the benefits of PRO reporting to historically underserved patients and advance equitable cancer care and hence, is directly relevant to public health.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), commonly known as fatty liver, is a leading cause of liver cancer and disproportionately affects Latinos in the United States and worldwide. The proposed study will determine how genetic differences lead to increased risk of NAFLD and NAFLD-related complications, such as cirrhosis (scarring of the liver) and hepatocellular carcinoma, the most common form of liver cancer. Understanding how these genetic differences interact with environmental risk factors will allow us to (1) identify which individuals have the highest risk of developing liver cancer, (2) implement personalized treatment strategies aimed at reducing the risk of NAFLD-related complications, and (3) create personalized screening programs that target those individuals before cancer develops.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Temporary, pandemic-related emergency allotments for the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) ended universally in March 2023, leading to a major decline in benefits for participants. This policy could have a large impact on participating households’ food purchase quality, especially for historically underserved populations with worse food access and pre-pandemic inequities in nutrition-related chronic disease. This project will evaluate the effects of the expiration of SNAP emergency allotments on the healthfulness of participant food purchases, identify potential inequities in these effects by rurality, race/ethnicity, and economic stability, and explore how concurrent economic, social, community, and retail factors influenced food choice after this policy change.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative There is an urgent need for a shorter treatment regimen for tuberculosis (TB), an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb). To accomplish this challenge, it is necessary to understand the molecular principles underlying antibiotic tolerance in Mtb. In this proposal, we will investigate the significance of ribosome remodeling and hibernation in antibiotic tolerance of Mtb.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In chronic pancreatitis (CP), inflammation and fibrosis of the pancreas lead to significant pain and disability for many affected patients. In the most severely affected patients with CP, the complete removal of the pancreas called total pancreatectomy with islet autotransplantation (“TPIAT”) may be considered but does not always lead to significant pain relief. We will use data and specimens already collected from a rigorous, well-phenotyped, multicenter cohort of TPIAT patients to develop plasma and urine biomarkers that may predict responsiveness (e.g. pain relief) to TPIAT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: MoTrPAC Narrative While there are many important health benefits of physical activity, how exercise exerts its effects is not fully understood. A more comprehensive understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying the responses to exercise would significantly impact public health. Continuation of the Molecular Transducers of Physical Activity Consortium (MoTrPAC) will achieve its objective of generating a comprehensive map of the molecular responses to acute exercise and exercise training with the long-range goal of elucidating the mechanisms by which exercise improves health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is a significant problem in the United States with limited treatment options to reduce alcohol dependence and relapse. Based on the localization and signal transduction mechanism of metabotropic glutamate 2 (mGlu2) receptors, there is a strong rationale that positive allosteric modulators (PAMs) of mGlu2 will effectively treat multiple symptoms that contribute to alcohol dependence and relapse, including attenuation of ethanol self-administration and sleep disturbances. The overarching goal of this application is to assess the potential of mGlu2 PAMs as a novel pharmacological treatment for AUD.

PHR: Project Narrative PHLHousing+ -- a housing-focused guaranteed income experiment – provides a unique opportunity to test whether unconditional monthly cash payments reduce health disparities for minoritized groups who, historically, experience high rates of insecure and unhealthy housing. Data from randomized controlled trials of housing programs are sorely needed to evaluate effects on health outcomes and to inform efforts to translate temporary supports introduced during the pandemic into permanent ones. Study findings will have immediate implications for the City of Philadelphia's model for providing housing assistance, will inform efforts to establish similar programs in other cities, and will inform federal approaches to rental assistance.

PHR: My long-term goal is measuring how metabolism is altered in cancer so we can target cancer metabolism while sparing healthy tissues. Tumors are made up of a mix of cancer, immune, and connective tissue cells, which all play a role in supporting tumor growth, but the field has lacked approaches to measure metabolism in these different cell populations. I will use metabolic flux measurement techniques I have developed to measure the metabolism of each of the cell types living within the tumor, and to test whether targeting altered fluxes in cancer cells could slow tumor growth.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The composition of cells in tissues evolves over time as changes to DNA alter a cell’s ability to adapt, expand, or die— a process called somatic evolution. Here, the proposed research will develop new genomics approaches to study somatic evolution in human tissues at single-cell resolution. As somatic evolution plays an important role in the predisposition to many diseases, including cancer, the successful completion of this research will reveal basic biological insights that may enable earlier detection of disease and unlock new opportunities for therapeutic intervention.

PHR: Project Narrative Sexual violence is a significant public health problem associated with elevated risk for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and opioid misuse and disorder; however, few, if any, early interventions to address PTSD and opioid use exist. The emergency department (ED) may represent an important, and in some cases, the only contact with medical care systems where early interventions can be implemented. In response to NOSI DA-23-007, HEAL Initiative: Opioid Use Disorder Care Pathways for Individuals with Histories of Exposure to Violence, this R61/R33 proposal seeks to develop and test a brief video and text messaging intervention to deliver in the ED to prevent the onset or escalation of posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and opioid misuse and disorder among survivors of sexual assault.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project narrative Although research has suggested that the modest and variable effects of exercise for knee osteoarthritis (KOA) pain may be partially explained by the presence of sleep disturbances, KOA exercise programs are yet to incorporate evidence-based components to improve sleep. This clinical trial will provide critical evidence on the benefit of a hybrid intervention for KOA pain management that incorporates an evidence-based sleep improvement component alongside a personalized exercise program and will identify characteristics of patients who benefit most from this approach. Granular, longitudinal psychosocial data will also be collected to describe mechanisms underlying intervention effects to guide future research into mechanisms underlying the sleep- physical activity-pain triad.

PHR: Project Narrative: Despite considerable improvement in treatment-adapted strategies, the five-year survival rate of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) patients, especially those with TET2 deficiency or suppression, is still lower than 30%, and thus there is an unmet medical need to identify new therapeutic target(s) and develop improved therapies. This proposal aims to determine the role of TET2 in leukemia stem/initiating cell homing, self-renewal, and bone marrow microenvironment, and delineate the molecular mechanism(s) by which TET2 loss in AML confers a more aggressive clinical prognosis. We will also develop novel effective approaches by combining CXCR4 inhibitors with hypomethylating agents and assess its therapeutic potential to cure high-risk AML patients with TET2 deficiency or suppression.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic mutations accumulate in every cell of our bodies throughout our lives, and these mutations have long been thought to be an important reason why our bodies age. However, it is not known whether some people accumulate mutations at a faster or slower rate with age, and whether differences in the rate at which mutations occur might predict how long we live and the risk for aging-related diseases. This study will answer these questions by measuring the mutation rate of a large number of people, which may allow us to predict, and understand why, people age differently.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A high percentage of people living with HIV/AIDS that do Methamphetamine abuse develop HIV associated neurocognitive disorders despite effective systemic antiretroviral therapy. The circumstances leading to persistent neuroinflammation, which play a part in neurocognitive disorders, are currently not defined. We will characterize mechanisms of HIV, and Methamphetamine-mediated DNA-damage detection in the brain that can trigger neuroinflammation, this knowledge can inform future therapies on NeuroHIV in the context of Methamphetamine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative U.S. epidemiological data indicates that Black women are a high-risk HIV disparity group, yet initiation of novel prevention strategies like pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) among this group is stagnant. Socio-structural challenges like intimate partner violence and gendered racism can constrain PrEP access among Black women, but few implementation studies have mitigated these challenges to improve PrEP initiation. The proposed research aims to implement and assess the effectiveness, implementation, and sustainability of a multilevel intervention to increase PrEP initiation among Black women with and without intimate partner violence in Baltimore.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE/PROJECT NARRATIVE Population-level data on the sexual and reproductive health (SRH) needs and experiences of transgender, nonbinary, and intersex (TNBI) people in the U.S. are virtually non-existent. To further the cross-cutting goal identified by NICHD’s Strategic Plan 2020--of addressing health disparities for sexual and gender minorities-- this study will collect rigorous, foundational, epidemiological data on SRH risk factors and outcomes among a large, diverse sample of TNBI people from across the United States; data that are essential to designing effective public health interventions informing evidence-based healthcare, and improving health outcomes. Further, this study will test and evaluate innovations in study design and survey methodology that will improve recruitment, retention, and data quality in studies of marginalized populations across disciplines.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Narrative The project is expected to yield actionable mechanistic insights into environmental exposures, tumor immunophenotype, and genetic factors driving the atypical presentation of HCC in Blacks and may identify new targets for intervention and prevention. The study will also yield a polygenic risk score for cirrhosis for use among ancestrally diverse populations. The results will alert patients and providers to the fact that HCC risk is disproportionate to cirrhosis stage in Blacks, raising awareness and encouraging early enrollment in surveillance.

PHR: Project Narrative The US foreign-born Latino population is rapidly aging and includes increasing numbers who, due to a lack of legal authorization, are excluded from the nation’s key social safety net programs for older adults. This project explores how immigrant legal status impacts the health and wellbeing of older (50+) Latinos, and the degree to which they can rely on kinship networks – chiefly their middle-aged children – for daily financial and health care needs.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will test the hypothesis that intensive lowering of circulating cholesterol decreases prostate cancer progression by stimulating a long-term antitumor immune response. Key observations made in mouse models will be examined in a clinical trial in patients diagnosed with prostate cancer on active surveillance. Demonstration that cholesterol-lowering therapy shows activity to activate long-term anti-tumor immunity will have impact on future trial design for primary and secondary cancer prevention and for examining for cholesterol lowering strategies for other cancers where immune stimulation can improve outcomes.

PHR: Policy solutions that center the needs, priorities, and assets of birthing people and communities are required to address the stark and longstanding social disparities in pregnancy-related deaths and disability in New York City (NYC) and elsewhere. Integrated supportive care models (ISC) that increase access to quality obstetric services and improve the social determinants of health hold significant promise but are lacking empirical evidence. Guided by our academic-governmental-community partnership, our mixed-methods project will provide critical, timely new information on the multi-level impacts and implementation of NYC’s Medicaid- supported doula programs to inform dissemination and sustainability of policy-relevant ISC interventions and improve maternal health and health equity for birthing people in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although activated immune cells are key players in multiple sclerosis (MS), and glutamate dysregulation contributes to tissue degeneration, the crosstalk between immune response and glutamate dynamics is not well understood. This proposal will develop and validate new non-invasive positron emission tomography and magnetic resonance imaging approaches to improve detection of immune cells and glutamate dynamics in real time, thus providing unprecedented information about their interplay in MS. Findings from this work will validate clinically translatable neuroimaging tools to provide new ways of assessing therapy responses, understanding underlying mechanisms in MS, and potentially aid in the design of novel treatments.

PHR: Project Narrative Gastric adenocarcinoma patients with peritoneal carcinomatosis (PC) die miserably due to the lack effective treatments and poor understanding of molecular biology. By utilizing patient-derived PC cells and preclinical models, we will uncover the functional importance of YAP1 in mediating cancer stemness and PC and elucidate the mechanisms by which YAP1 mediated immunosuppression to develop novel therapeutic strategies of inhibiting YAP1 and TIM3/Gal-9. Upon completion of this study, we will have a strong rationale for a novel combination that could overcome the shortcomings we experience in the clinics today.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this study, Sarya LLC (Sarya) will develop and commercialize a new specific positron emission tomography (PET) imaging agent 64Cu-LLP2A for diagnosis, staging, and treatment of the hematological cancer, multiple myeloma (MM). The development of this technology will fulfill an unmet need for molecularly targeted, sensitive and specific MM imaging agents that can accurately stage and restage MM, identify high-risk MM patients, guide personalized MM treatment, and evaluate clinical response to treatment.

PHR: Project Narrative American Indian/Alaska Native (AI/AN) populations were disproportionately affected by the COVID-19 pandemic compared to other racial/ethnic populations. We plan to analyze RADx-UP consortium data to evaluate the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on AI/AN RADx-UP participants with chronic health conditions, changes in access to healthcare, and sociodemographic factors on COVID-19 testing and vaccination uptake. This study will allow for development of intervention strategies to improve COVID-19 testing and vaccination uptake in this underserved population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Rapid Acceleration in Diagnostics for Underserved Population (RADx-UP) consortium recruited over 370,000 participants to generate data on COVID-19 testing, pandemic stress, and vaccination among underserved and vulnerable persons across the US. Our team of epidemiologists, and chronic disease, infectious disease, and health policy experts plans to use these data test the performance of public health resource allocation and infection surveillance tools. Our goal is to mitigate health disparities during the inevitable future pandemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: MoTrPAC Narrative While there are many important health benefits of physical activity, how exercise exerts its effects is not fully understood. A more comprehensive understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying the responses to exercise would significantly impact public health. Continuation of the Molecular Transducers of Physical Activity Consortium (MoTrPAC) will achieve its objective of generating a comprehensive map of the molecular responses to acute exercise and exercise training. with a long-range goal of elucidating the mechanisms by which exercise improves health.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative  This project will design and field a new wave of the Child Development Supplement in 2023, as part of the on-going Panel Study of Income Dynamics (PSID), collecting data on all children aged 0–17 years in PSID families through interviews with primary caregivers (typically one of the child’s parents) and with older children themselves (aged 8–17 years). These new data will support studies of health, development, and well-being in childhood; the effects of the Covid-19 pandemic; the relationship between children’s characteristics and con- temporaneous family decisionmaking and behavior; and the effects of childhood factors on subsequent social, demographic, economic, and health outcomes over the entire life course for these individuals as they are fol- lowed into the future as part of PSID.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Oral mucositis, a painful oral ulceration, is one of the most debilitating toxicities of cancer therapy. Our proprietary drug targets multiple processes of oral mucositis thus delivering a more effective oral mucositis treatment in cancer patients. Our proposed studies will allow us to obtain IND approval by the FDA to initiate the first-in- human clinical trial after completion of this grant, thus bring a new therapy to clinic. Meeting this unmet need will improve cancer patient outcomes and quality of life by enabling optimal RT regimens, reducing pain and preventing other sequelae.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Animals have evolved sophisticated sensory systems that allow them to sense and respond to environmental cues, optimizing their health and survival. The goal of this project is to identify the neuronal mechanisms that underlie sensory perception of harmful stimuli, such as the presence of dead conspecifics, and how these mechanisms elicit physiological changes that regulate lifespan in an invertebrate model, Caenorhabditis elegans. By identifying the specific mechanisms involved in this process will provide insight to exploit neural signaling in the treatment of aging-related physiologies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To achieve the Ending the HIV Epidemic: A Plan for America, better strategies are needed to promote antiretroviral (ART) adherence and viral suppression in persons living with HIV (PWH) from health disparity populations to engage them in HIV care and to reduce HIV risk behaviors during periods of non- suppression. In response, our study team has developed and demonstrated evidence for components of the CHAMPS+ intervention which will promote ART adherence and suppressed viral load for PWH who live in the Deep South, a geographic area of the US with high rates of new HIV infections and PWH who are virally unsuppressed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to address the inequities in COVID-19 outcomes among persons involved with the criminal legal system (PCLS), characterized by lower testing and vaccination rates and more adverse outcomes relative to the general population. These disparities are influenced by the interaction of individual (e.g., underlying health conditions), structural (e.g., crowded detention facilities, limited healthcare accessibility during and after incarceration) and social network (e.g., medical mistrust, vaccine hesitancy) factors. Leveraging individual, structural and social network data from existing multisite RADx-UP studies and using innovative modeling approaches, this study aims to better understand these multifaceted interactions and identify interventions to improve COVID-19 testing and vaccination rates among PCLS and their communities.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PUBLIC HEALTH STATEMENT Advanced age diminishes bone repair capacity and is associated with increased surgical intervention at the time of the injury and subsequently due to the need for revisional surgery. Apolipoprotein E (ApoE) is a circulatory protein which we show to increase in abundance with age and to have deleterious effects in bone fracture healing. Here we propose to investigate the efficacy of using neutralizing antibodies temporally neutralize circulating ApoE to improve aged fracture healing and to identify the mechanism by which ApoE is able to inhibit bone repair and investigate the function of a newly identified osteoblastic cell-surface receptor, muscle-specific kinase (MuSK).

PHR: Project Narrative Maintaining mitochondrial genomic integrity is necessary to protect against numerous pathologies, including age-related diseases. This proposal aims to highlight the underlying basis for the mitochondrial common deletion, a widespread aberrancy that cripples oxidative phosphorylation and is widespread in aging tissue. By studying the effects and underlying mechanisms of the mitochondrial common deletion, we hope to better understand how mitochondrial dysfunction contributes to age-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Overall) This RCMI U54 application is from the existing, successful Tuskegee University (TU) Center for Biomedical Research Program that is committed to the elimination of health disparities in racial/ethnic minority and underserved populations in the ‘Deep South’, particularly among African Americans. By leveraging the distinct location of the center in the Alabama Black Belt and the historical mission of Tuskegee University dedicated to the education of minorities, we have build a health disparity focused program, whose mission is to understand the causes for these health disparities by supporting and enhancing diverse basic biological science, clinical health, and community-based research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Latinx adults are typically underrepresented in study samples, limiting what is known about differences in systemic conditions within Latinx communities that have led to disproportionate disease burden before and throughout the COVID-19 pandemic. The current proposal describes an innovative approach to address the limitations of prior research and inform prevention and control strategies designed for sub-groups within the Latinx community who experience the greatest systemic barriers to SARS-CoV-2 testing and vaccination. Study findings on the most important systemic conditions related to engagement in COVID-19 preventive behaviors and access to preventive services for Latinx sub-groups have potential to inform disease mitigation efforts among Latinxs beyond COVID-19 and, ultimately, promote health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Young men’s alcohol-related sexual risk behavior and resistance of condom use continues to pose an important public health concern contributing to both unplanned pregnancies and the spread of sexually transmitted diseases such as HIV. This project will advance our ability to understand the roles of alcohol, sexual aggression history, and emotional processes in these risk behaviors by investigating emotions and emotion regulation as mechanisms underlying alcohol-related sexual risk. An understanding of the specific mechanisms which drive condom use resistance and sexual risk behaviors will contribute evidence for the development of science driven behavior-change prevention programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dating app-facilitated sexual violence (DAFSV) has substantial negative impacts on victims’ health and is especially common among men who have sex with men (MSM), yet there is an absence of research on DAFSV perpetration and its risk and protective factors among MSM – which is needed to inform the development of effective prevention efforts and policy. Dating apps are the first point of contact between many MSM and their romantic and sexual partners, and DAFSV may function as a pre-cursor to in-person sexual violence, suggesting a need to investigate their intersection and co-occurrence with other public health concerns including problematic drinking and sexual minority stress (e.g., discrimination). To understand these associations between DAFSV perpetration and its risk and protective factors, in-person sexual violence perpetration, alcohol use, and sexual minority stress, and to ultimately identify ways to prevent DAFSV and promote safter dating and sexual interactions among MSM, we will sample 1150 MSM for an online survey (Phase 1) and conduct in-depth qualitative interviews with 60 of these MSM who report DAFSV perpetration.

PHR: NARRATIVE Here we investigate the epigenetic mechanisms that control the transcriptional activation- repression cycle induced by environmental and stress challenges in keratinocytes, a process that is critical for skin and organismal homeostasis. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study extends a line of research that seeks to reduce alcohol-involved sexual assault on college campuses by developing the first smartphone application to integrate evidence-based alcohol and sexual assault prevention tools, making them accessible 24/7 for students to use in the moments when they are most needed. This study will use multiple rounds of feedback from students, student service providers, campus administrators, and subject matter experts to develop the app and then test its feasibility in a pilot randomized clinical trial. Findings will provide support for a full-scale test of the app’s impact and lay the groundwork to universally deliver real-time prevention tools to reduce alcohol-involved sexual assault on college campuses.

PHR: Project Narrative Examining the relationship between numeracy (the ability to comprehend numerical information), risk perception of tobacco-related diseases, and tobacco use behaviors has not yet been fully explored, especially how these relationships differ by demographic factors. This project will use nationally representative public data sets that contain tobacco use, risk perception, and numeracy measures to examine these relationships and determine which populations have low numeracy, do not understand the risks involved with tobacco use, and thus cannot make fully informed decisions on using atobacco product. Identification of these subpopulations will allow tailored educational campaign recommendations to be formed (involving numeracy-level appropriate risk communication), which will encourage healthy behaviors and decrease tobacco-related disease outcomes (such as cancer). .

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Soluble adenylyl cyclase (sAC) is essential for sperm function, and both men and male mice with the sAC gene deleted are sterile. Mice given acute acting sAC inhibitors are temporarily infertile with no other observable side effects. Our goal is to develop sAC inhibitors into a safe, `on-demand' male birth control pill whose effects would be temporary and taken only when needed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV incidence, although having declined modestly overall in the United States, remains a significant public health problem for young men who have sex with men (YMSM), among whom HIV rates have risen with notable racial, ethnic, and geographic disparities. In response to the continuing HIV epidemic in YMSM and disparities in initiation of and adherence to pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP), our study team proposes to expand MyPEEPS Mobile to develop MyPEEPS Mobile Plus, a combination intervention comprised of MyPEEPS Mobile + PrEP E-Peer Navigation to overcome the current challenges of PrEP care among YMSM. If efficacious, MyPEEPS Mobile Plus will support PrEP initiation, adherence, and persistence and decrease HIV risk in diverse YMSM in the United States.

PHR: Despite the successful control of the virus in people with HIV (PWH) with antiviral treatments, elimination or cure is impossible due to the presence of latently infected cells in various anatomical compartments including the brain and CNS. Given the deep breadth of knowledge on viral latency the peripheral reservoir cells (e.g. resting CD4+ T cells), several approaches for treatment exist, including “kick and kill” strategies, whereas, there is limited understanding of the myeloid cell viral reservoirs in the CNS. Using our recently developed novel multicellular human 3D-brain organoids with microglia from brain of HIV infected individuals, we will assess how HIV-1 establishes latency in these cells in CNS, that will help us to further develop therapeutic approaches to either activate and treat or silence the virus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Research in hematology has been at the cutting edge of medical advances for decades, providing novel paradigms for the study of human disease. Nevertheless, hematologic diseases remain major public health problems, and the number of physician-scientists dedicated to the study of hematology is declining. This grant is focused on clinician scientists and aims to support a laboratory-based training program to nurture the next generation of hematologists focused on research in molecular hematology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emerging research strongly suggests that adverse changes in the lung microbiome increase neutrophilic inflam- mation, which is associated with chronic lung diseases such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The development of microbiome-targeting biotherapeutic drugs holds significant promise to address this problem by reducing pulmonary inflammation. The goal of this proposal is to develop and demonstrate efficacy of a lead therapeutic candidate that is based on extracts of specific Lactobacillus strains for treatment of neutrophilic in- flammation and dysbiosis associated with COPD.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pregnancy loss impacts millions of women in the United States and around the world. Understanding how serum response factor works with progesterone, the hormone of pregnancy, to facilitate the successful initiation and continuation of pregnancy will reveal key insights on the biological mechanisms of uterine immune homeostasis when pregnancy goes right and the development of a hostile uterine environment when it goes wrong.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Obesity hypoventilation syndrome, accumulation of carbon dioxide in the body, is the most severe form of sleep disordered breathing, which does not have effective drug therapy. We have collected preliminary data showing that a melanocortin 4 receptor (MC4R) agonist setmelanotide, which is FDA approved to treat genetic obesity, is a powerful stimulator of breathing, and will perform a randomized controlled trial of this drug in mice with obesity hypoventilation and sleep apnea. We will employ state-of-the-art neuroscience tools to identify specific neurons in the brain in which MC4R agonists work to stimulate breathing, enhance responses to carbon dioxide and treat obesity hypoventilation and sleep apnea.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Post-surgical TNBC recurrence is the major cause of the poor prognosis of TNBC patients. This proposal aims to identify intracellular ferritin as a new TNBC therapeutic target and develop a ferritin-degrading proteolysis targeting chimeras (PROTACs) molecule to leverage the intracellular ubiquitin-proteasome system to degrade ferritin to induce the TNBC cell pyroptosis. The endogenous platelets will be applied to encapsulate developed ferritin degraders for enhanced in vivo pharmacokinetics and anti-TNBC recurrence efficacy, which can serve as monotherapy or synergize with current immunotherapeutics to prevent post-surgical TNBC recurrence.

PHR: Project Narrative: Native American groups are among the most under-represented groups across STEM disciplines, including Brain Sciences. This disparity has arisen from a number of historical and institutional challenges. To meet this challenge, we propose the creation of a research education program to support post-baccaulareate students as they transition into graduate school in developing scientific literacy, research, and laboratory skills focused on neuroscience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Optimal outcomes after surgery may be impaired due to immune mechanisms which cause tissue injury or interfere with healing. The goal of this program is to inspire and train the next generation of surgeon-scientists who will lead immunology research focused on solutions for clinical problems relevant to tissue injury, repair, regeneration and replacement. Discoveries by these surgeon-scientists are anticipated to lead to new tools for diagnosis or prognosis of immune-mediated diseases and also to new immunotherapies which improve surgical outcomes.
PROJECT_TERMS: Immunology;Operative Surgical Procedures;Research Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Advanced research training in immunology for surgery trainees (ARTIST)
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Allergy, Immunology, and Transplantation Research Committee[AITC]

PHR: Lack of effective HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) programs is a significant contributor to ongoing spread of HIV in sub-Saharan Africa (SSA). Our proposed study, to be conducted in Botswana, will leverage a successful national ART program and infrastructure to first test a set of strategies for the general population (18-49 years old) to increase PrEP uptake using information and communications technology to expand reach, reduce barriers due to mobility and competing needs for work. Based on lessons learnt from the preliminary study, we will then assess if PrEP uptake and persistence will be better with the new strategies as compared to the way PrEP is currently being offered in Botswana.

ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This T32 renewal application seeks continued funding to provide postdoctoral training in Behavioral Oncology research. Since 2003, the program has successfully attracted and recruited from a talented and diverse pool of applicants and has provided postdoctoral trainees with the skills, experiences, and high-quality mentoring needed to become successful investigators. Building on our prior success, this renewal will foster skills to address established and emerging areas of need in Behavioral Oncology, approach research from a lens of health equity, and leverage transdisciplinary science to generate sustainable impact on patients and communities.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: This program trains the next generation of immunologists who will lead the innovative research, teaching, and biomedical entrepreneurship that is needed to advance basic science and develop new translational approaches for the prevention and treatment of autoimmune diseases and cancer, the improvement of organ transplantation, and the design of new and more effective vaccines. The funding will contribute to public health by supporting the training of highly skilled individuals who will join the national biomedical research workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: This is an institutional training program to train physician and non-physician (PhD) scientists in a collaborative manner to become research leaders in two closely related areas: abnormal formation of blood clots (thrombosis) and the body’s response to injury or infection (inflammation). Thrombosis and inflammation are present in a broad range of severe human diseases in need of greater research, ultimately leading to advances in health.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myopia, or nearsightedness, is a significant public health concern because, in addition to the high costs and socio-economic burden, myopia can lead to permanent vision loss and ocular abnormalities causing blindness. Moreover, recent evidence suggests that the prevalence of myopia and, consequently, its impact are increasing rapidly. Hence, we aim to identify novel targets for urgently needed treatment strategies to prevent and reduce the degree of myopia.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescents with Autism Spectrum Disorder experience depression at rates nearly twice that of their neurotypical peers, yet risk factors for depression in autism are not well understood and interventions are limited. Longitudinal, multimethod assessment of social and nonsocial reward responsivity and associations with depression symptoms in autism will advance mechanistic models, informing intervention development. This project will be the first to examine how relationships between reward responsivity and depression symptoms change over time in adolescents with autism, clarifying risk factors and potential intervention targets for this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The goal of this proposal is to continue and improve a program to train the next generation of immunologists and provide them with the tools needed to forge successful careers in research. We recruit the most talented and motivated predoctoral students and our outstanding faculty trainers provide exceptional mentorship and training in how to conduct research in immunology, in addition to preparing them for careers in research and research-related fields. The immune response cuts across all types of disease in the human population, and we are at the beginning of our ability to develop therapies to harness the immune responses for novel therapies, so progress in this field is essential.

PROJECT_TITLE: Immunobiology of Myeloid and Lymphoid Cells

ORG_NAME: CENTER FOR INNOVATIVE PUBLIC HEALTH RESEARCH
PHR: If efficacious, ITG has the potential to help curb the alarming increase in HIV incidence among Ugandan young people as they age through young adulthood. Given its scalability and low cost, this powerful intervention could be quickly added to the currently small arsenal of HIV prevention programs for young adults in Uganda, if warranted. We are partnering with the Ministry of Health to guide us on sustainability should the findings of this R01 warrant.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE: OVERALL This Program of research focuses on delayed treatment sequelae of oropharyngeal cancer (OPC) which has been rising at epidemic pace for several decades. Although contemporary treatment strategies are highly effective at curing OPC, many survivors ultimately spend cancer-free years with disabling toxicities that threaten critical functions such as speaking and eating. The investigators will integrate three Projects focused on highly impactful delayed side effects including jawbone death (osteoradionecrosis), nerve loss (lower cranial neuropathy), and swallowing difficulty (dysphagia) using common infrastructure and synergistic methods of research to understand the time course, mechanisms, non-invasive testing, and treatment options to improve lifelong health and quality of life of OPC survivors.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE: PROJECT 1 (OPC-ORN) Osteoradionecrosis (ORN) is a highly morbid, delayed bone-related complication from radiation therapy with substantial impacts on healthcare costs, function, and quality of life. Our work explores the potential to characterize subclinical mandibular injury that is prevalent before symptomatic manifestation of observable ORN. Validation of risk stratification by dosimetric, imaging, and clinical criteria would enhance our efforts to monitor, mitigate, and treat this devastating delayed sequela of curative treatment.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE: PROJECT 2 (OPC-NERVE) The incidence of highly curable oropharyngeal cancers is rapidly rising and there are more long-term survivors than ever. Radiation treatment is very commonly given at doses sufficient to cause crippling late cranial neuropathy (loss of nerve function controlling tongue and throat) that can progress to the point that it results in a loss of speech, lifelong feeding tube dependence or death from aspiration pneumonia years after cancer is cured. This application seeks to understand how abnormal nerve function in the tongue may be present and measured long before it is evident in clinic, and whether it is feasibility to offer earlier therapy to help preserve function before irreversible damage is done.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE: PROJECT 3 (OPC-RAD) Currently the most effective treatment for locally advanced oropharyngeal head and neck cancer is photon (X- ray)–based radiotherapy (IMRT), given with or without chemotherapy; however, this therapy can cause delayed, progressive, irreversible late-radiation-associated dysphagia (L-RAD) that can worsen quality of life and contribute to mortality. Proton-based radiotherapy (IMPT) is being evaluated as a promising, less toxic alternative to IMRT in a randomized trial; however, whether IMPT (vs. IMRT) can prevent L-RAD, and whether pentoxifylline+tocopherol (PENTOCO) can prevent and mitigate L-RAD, are unknown at this time. We propose here to (1) model the risk of developing L-RAD after IMPT vs. IMRT and (2) test whether PENTOCO will prevent and mitigate L-RAD in patients with head and neck cancer.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE: CORE C (PROF) The Patient-Reported Outcomes/Function (PROF) Core (Core C) will provide comprehensive infrastructure for prospective collection of longitudinal functional outcomes and surveillance of treatment-related adverse events in a unique cohort of oropharynx cancer patients. This shared resource will play a critical role in patient-facing operations and data maintenance that are integral to all P01 Projects and Cores. The overarching aims of the PROF Core include improvement of patient recruitment and retention while optimizing longitudinal data collection and monitoring of patient symptoms via novel feedback loops and machine learning.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: OVERALL The University of Miami’s Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center (Sylvester), the only NCI-designated cancer center in South Florida, is a source of discovery and innovation in cancer research, effective and inclusive approaches to education and training, novel community outreach and engagement activities for the prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of cancer, and hope for residents of its uniquely diverse catchment area. Focused on catchment area-relevant research, Sylvester’s four Research Programs span the spectrum of basic, clinical, translational, and population science research to reduce the human burden from cancer in the community the center serves. Sylvester leaders, clinicians and researchers work collaboratively to create a culture and environment that advances diversity, equity, and inclusion, and uses technologically advanced and culturally sensitive approaches to develop, evaluate, and implement novel treatments and effective interventional strategies that will sustainably and favorably impact cancer outcomes in South Florida and beyond.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Despite the best cybersecurity measures, ransomware attacks have occurred in Radiation Oncology with devastating effects. Our project proposes novel methods to improve ransomware attack resiliency and uses engineering principles to quantitatively and qualitatively evaluate the proposed techniques. The developed methods can help improve outcomes for cancer patients by enabling safer and timelier radiotherapy treatments in ransomware attack situations and by reducing the impact of ransomware attacks on patients impacted with social determinants of health.
PI_NAMEs: LAMB, JAMES MICHAEL;SULLIVAN, SARAH ELIZABETH;VINOGRADSKIY, YEVGENIY  (contact)
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Systems Engineering for Ransomware Attack Response Resiliency in Radiation Oncology
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disparities in pediatric asthma are highly influenced by multifactorial determinants, particularly in rural and underresourced areas, such as Arkansas. Given the complex relationship between of these determinants, asthma outcomes, and the need to investigate the extent of how patient, provider, and community-level variation impacts our population, this proposal aims to improve the identification and understanding of multifactorial, multilevel determinants of asthma through 1) engagement of patients with asthma and their caregivers, 2) uncovering unknown region and population-specific factors underlying differences in outcomes, and 3) examining variation in asthma outcomes through multilevel analyses (patient, provider, community). There are few population-level analyses of pediatric asthma in rural and underresourced settings, and this proposal represents a foundational step in impacting disparity and inequity in asthma, while also providing findings that will inform innovative patient-centered, population-based interventional trials targeting high-risk pediatric asthma in Arkansas with broader implications as a model for investigations among other rural at-risk populations.

STUDY_SECTION_NAME: NHLBI Mentored Patient-Oriented Research Study Section[MPOR (MA)]

ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Despite large-scale, nationwide efforts to better address suicidal behavior in Veterans at high risk, the development of interventions that target some of the key risk factors associated with suicide remains limited. This study aims to collect pilot data to test feasibility/acceptability of a novel adjunctive evidence-based cognitive remediation (CR) therapy with manualized “Bridging” sessions for transfer and practice of problem- solving strategies for real-world stressors, including those that trigger suicidal thoughts. This 10-week (20 session) Neuropsychological Educational Approach to Cognitive Remediation CR+Bridging telehealth intervention will be administered virtually via HIPPA-compliant services to 36 Veterans with major depressive disorder and a history of suicide attempt(s). Pre-, post-treatment, and follow-up assessments of neurocognitive, clinical, social, and real-world functioning also will be conducted. This study has potential for high public health impact and promise to help improve quality of life for Veterans at high risk for suicide.

ORG_NAME: CLEMENT J. ZABLOCKI VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: This project is relevant to public health because it will provide critical information on the neurological and behavioral consequences of mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI). The proposed research is relevant to the VA Office of Rehabilitation Research and Development’s mission because it is directed toward studying the effectiveness of pharmaceutical interventions in the treatment of comorbid mTBI-addiction. The Department of Defense and the Defense and Veteran's Brain Injury Center have estimated that 22% of all combat casualties from the conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan are brain injuries. As these military personnel transition into the VA healthcare system, many of the long-term effects of these traumatic brain injuries have not been clearly defined or are not known. Some evidence exists to indicate that exposure to traumatic brain injury may influence drug addiction and relapse. Our preliminary studies have supported this assertion. This study will explore the chronicity of this relationship and explore interventions to alleviate its effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Bats are reservoirs of several human pathogenic viruses with pandemic potential, including coronaviruses and henipaviruses. Currently, there are no closed breeding colonies of bats that host these viruses, thus, it is difficult to study the viruses in their natural reservoir hosts. We will establish breeding colonies of horseshoe bats and Indian flying foxes to provide bats, cells and reagents for researchers who study SARS-related coronaviruses and Nipah virus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The Integrated Stress Response (ISR) signaling pathway helps cells adapt to various conditions of stress, and abnormal ISR signaling is associated with various metabolic and neurodegenerative diseases. This pathway simultaneously activates gene transcription and suppresses general mRNA translation. Here, we propose to determine how stress-responsive transcripts bypass mRNA translation blocks associated with ISR, and determine their significance in stress adaptation and disease manifestation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Hepatitis B (HB) continues to be the world’s leading cause of hepatocellular carcinoma. Although a vaccine is preventive, none of the current therapies are curative for patients who have already been infected, even after ten years of use. New effective medicines are urgently needed. We propose to develop small molecule antivirals that can be selectively delivered to the liver where HB virus resides and significantly reduce the levels of multiple HBV gene products including hepatitis B surface antigen. This project will advance an innovative class of anti- HBV compounds towards preclinical animal efficacy studies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The protease caspase-6 contributes to inflammation, neurodegeneration, and protein aggregation in neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer’s (AD). We have developed highly potent inhibitors of caspase-6 that gain exquisite selectivity by binding covalently to a unique cysteine residue in the substrate-binding groove. This Phase I STTR project will further develop this novel series of inhibitors and will utilize PK and tissue distribution studies to select the most promising compounds for AD disease-specific animal models. With potent inhibitors in hand, we will be able to elucidate target half-life and engagement with an established click-based probe of aCasp6 binding. This work will enable design of a future studies that will determine whether caspase-6 inhibitors are effective at blocking disease progression in animal models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Data-driven modeling methods are revolutionizing the modeling of complex systems and have proven to be incredibly successful at learning scientifically explainable and interpretable governing equations from data, yet are unreliable when applied to data with levels of noise and sparsity common to biomedical and biological data. My group has developed the Weak form Sparse Identification of Nonlinear Dynamics (WSINDy) method that has shown incredible promise in creating models and revealing mechanisms directly from data with substantial noise (in some cases at or above the 100% noise ratio level). The overarching goals of this research are to use the WSINDy method to investigate the 1) individual cell-based drivers for collective cell migration and 2) data-driven inference for unobserved processes in infectious disease dynamics as well as 3) extend WSINDy to infer stochastic dynamical systems and discover critical (but hidden) compartments.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease frequently experience psychological distress (i.e., depression and anxiety), which is associated with poor health outcomes and which patients, their caregivers, and clinicians have identified as the most critical palliative care need. This study will identify how an evidence- based coping skills training program, which partners patients and their caregivers to manage and overcome disease-related distress, reduces depression and anxiety among outpatients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. The findings will provide a better understanding of how social relationships affect patients’ psychological distress and will help health systems design and implement efficient strategies for patient- and family-centered palliative care within chronic illness care, particularly those affecting health disparities populations who experience inequities in access to such services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cells must inherit the right number of chromosomes every time they divide. Defects in this process are the most common chromosomal abnormality in cancer cells and contribute to birth defects and other diseases. We are therefore studying the process of chromosome distribution to daughter cells when they divide to understand the basis for a number of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The packaging and organization of eukaryotic genomic DNA into nucleosome units provides a rich layer of physical characteristics and interactions that constitute an important feature governing the activity of many chromatin regulators in the nucleus. Leveraging single-molecule visualization and manipulation methods, this project aims to dissect how the physical topology of nucleosomes regulates the function of pioneer transcription factors, chromatin-modifying enzymes, and energy-consuming molecular machines in real time and at high resolution. Our studies will uncover how nucleosomes biophysically modulate the interaction between chromatin and its regulators and may reveal mutation-selective protein-chromatin interfaces linked to pathogenesis that are vulnerable to chemical intervention for treating disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative A number of molecular and cellular mechanisms have been linked to autism spectrum disorder (ASD), but how these mechanisms lead to the behavioral phenotypes that define autism remains largely unknown. Sensory processing deficits are one the most prevalent and debilitating features of autism that also provide a window into how brain function is altered in ASD more generally. This study will use the auditory system to examine sensory circuit disruptions in two rat models of ASD— the Fmr1KO rat model of Fragile X Syndrome and the Tsc2+/- Eker rat model of Tuberous Sclerosis Complex— in order to determine how the distinct cellular and molecular consequences of Fmr1 and Tsc2 mutation manifest at the neural circuit level to ultimately drive clinically-important behavioral phenotypes in ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Although not ideal, emergency department use for non-traumatic dental conditions is common and results in unnecessary antibiotic and opioid prescribing. This project seeks to understand barriers and facilitators to appropriate non-traumatic dental condition management in the emergency department through quantitative and qualitative methods and pilot tests an intervention strategy to improve emergency department provider’s prescribing of antibiotics and opioids for non-traumatic dental conditions. Findings from this project will provide preliminary data to support a clinical trial to demonstrate the effectiveness of our intervention as a model to implement nationally to improve management of non-traumatic dental conditions in the emergency department and other health care settings.

PHR: Project Narrative Transgender adults experience disproportionately high rates of tobacco use compared to the U.S. general adult population. Despite the role health care providers can play in cessation, transgender adults report barriers to accessing evidence-based, clinician-delivered interventions. This research will be foundational in the development of a transgender-specific health services resource for health care providers who might not have the time or expertise to provide gender affirming smoking cessation support to their transgender patients.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Nuclear Hormone Receptors (NRs) are a structurally related family of transcription factors that are valuable targets in inflammation and cancer therapies. This proposal seeks to better understand a common ubiquitin- proteasome dependent degradation mechanism governing NRs and its role in transcriptional regulation. The long-term goal is to interrogate the relationship between and decouple hormone induced NR activation and degradation; we will first conduct basic research in biochemistry to understand the interactions between E3 ligases and NRs, and test the feasibility of this overall approach in cellular models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to develop a nanomedicine sensor that is capable of determining the genetic content of manufactured viruses with a high degree of accuracy. Current virus content analysis methods are unable to consistently and accurately determine if viruses intended for gene therapy contain their full genetic cargo or not, and as a result, under- or over-dosing remains a critical problem in viral gene therapy. Additionally, current analytical methods require using large amounts of the virus preparation for quality control, which is costly and wasteful; our proposed sensor requires only minute (pico- to nano-molar concentrations) virus amounts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The gap junctions are a class of membrane channel proteins that form direct pathways for cell-to-cell communication. Dynamic mechanisms of channel gating are required to control these communication pathways, while their misregulation is associated with a range of pathophysiological conditions, including blindness, deafness, cardiac arrhythmia, stroke and cancers. Our research group is using methods in high- resolution imaging by electron cryo-microscopy (CryoEM) to understand the detailed mechanisms of gap junction regulation and how aberrant regulation of inter-cellular communication manifests in disease.

PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Dix, Richard D Project Narrative The proposed project is relevant to public health because its performance will demonstrate for the first time that intraocular stimulation of multiple cell death pathways through different mechanisms contribute to the severe retinal disease pathology and loss of function that develops during pathogenesis of AIDS-related HCMV retinitis. The project is relevant to the NEI mission because its performance could lead to new therapeutic approaches to lessen vision loss and blindness associated with HCMV retinitis during AIDS and other forms of immunosuppression through use of cell death pathways inhibitors. This novel therapeutic approach could extend to other retinal diseases of herpesvirus origin in immunologically normal persons. PHS 398/2590 (Rev. 06/09) Page Continuation Format Page

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) among Gram-negative rod organisms is one of the most urgent public health threats in the United States and globally. By using series of survey of clinicians, retrospective cohort analyses, and machine learning prediction analytics, this study elucidates the current perceptions for AMR among providers and creates a machine learning model to accurately predict AMR risk at patient-level. The findings from this study will help create a decision-support system to guide clinicians for appropriate empiric therapy to treat infections due to Gram-negative rod organisms and prepare the applicant for a career as an independent infectious diseases health service investigator.

PROJECT_TITLE: Improving Empiric Antimicrobial Therapy for Gram-Negative Infections through a Personalized Smart Antibiogram

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities (IDD) have poor health outcomes, and their life expectancy is 20 years shorter than the rest of the U.S. population. The limited arsenal of efficacious treatments for these disorders exacerbates this public health emergency. This proposal will develop a framework for identifying convergent mechanisms for a group of IDD risk genes, which would accelerate the development of mechanism-based therapies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this project, we will investigate a new therapeutic and drug delivery system to treat the two key disease pathways associated with age-related macular degeneration (AMD), inflammation and oxidative stress. Anti- VEGF therapeutics are currently used to mitigate neovascularization, but this does not treat the inflammatory pathway of the disease, and the need for frequent intravitreal injections results in high costs and burdens the patients and health care system. The objective of this work is to perform in vivo validation of an injectable, biodegradable, stimuli-responsive nanoparticle delivery system that can sustain release of an investigational therapeutic to treat retinal inflammation for several months.

PHR: Project Narrative Identifying and using an object depends on knowing its shape, which we perceive through both our senses of touch and vision. IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mapping the network of genes disrupted in human disease allows us to design treatments that correct the network back to the normal state to treat the core disease process rather than only managing symptoms. However, mapping the network requires large amounts of data to learn the connections between genes, and in many human diseases we do not have enough data to confidently map the network, especially in rare diseases and diseases that affect tissues in the body that are difficult to reach to obtain samples to study, like the heart. In this research, we develop a new method for computers to learn connections between genes from tissues where we do have a large amount of data, serving as a knowledge base so that the machine can then confidently map the networks disrupted even in diseases where we have only a small amount of data, enabling us to design network-correcting treatments for those diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: It has been increasingly recognized that asthma is a consequence of joint activities among genes rather than of individual genes’ independent contributions. We propose an approach to detect distinct epigenetic networks (DENs) with each unique to a group of subjects via network clustering using DNA methylation (DNAm) data before disease manifestation, e.g., at-birth DNAm and childhood asthma. Next, we will study the longitudinal association of DENs at birth with asthma incidence in children, post-adolescence, and young adulthood, assess the role of age, sex, and race in this association, and examine the benefit of evaluating joint rather than individual activities of CpGs on asthma incidence.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anti-PD-1 chemoimmunotherapeutic treatment strategies rely on chemotherapy-induced immunomodulation (chemo-immunomodulation) for efficacy against metastatic triple-negative breast cancer and have hitherto performed unsatisfactorily. The goal of this project is to identify, characterize, and establish the clinical relevance of genomic and transcriptomic features that influence chemo-immunomodulation in metastatic triple-negative breast cancer and utilize the data generated from the studies herein to develop a machine-learning-based model predictive of chemo-immunomodulation by select agents. The results of this study may provide critical insights that inform novel paradigms for designing, optimizing, and maximizing the efficacy of anti-PD-1 chemoimmunotherapeutic strategies in metastatic triple-negative breast cancer based on patient-specific genomic and transcriptomic features and their effect on chemo-immunomodulation.

PHR: Biomolecules can self-organize into membraneless condensates by phase separation. We will investigate how chromatin features determine where transcription condensates form in the cell nucleus, and how condensates structure transcription activity. This knowledge is important to understand how biological functions arises from chromatin-condensate structures in health and disease.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE B cell signaling is central to the adaptive immune response, serving as the basis for generation of humoral immunity to foreign agents. A multi-component co-receptor complex carefully regulates the strength of B cell signaling, and dysregulation of signaling through this complex can lead to autoimmunity, immunodeficiency, and B cell cancers. This research program will elucidate the molecular details of how the B cell co-receptor complex functions, is regulated by novel accessory components, and will engineer new tools to modulate B cell function, laying the foundation for new immunomodulatory therapeutics.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer screening modalities are often associated with false positives, high rates of indeterminate findings, overdiagnosis, and overtreatment, which are all serious limitations that can be addressed with imaging. Our group pioneered image biomarker approaches leveraged in the prior funding cycle to create the first and only EDRN Clinical Validation Center (CVC) to dedicated to the validation of image biomarkers to improve early detection of cancer. In this renewal application, we build on our initial progress to bring practical automated solutions to these pressing screening problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Each of our cells inactivates many of its available genes to perform a unique function. Failure to properly inactivate genes underlies developmental disorders and devastating pediatric brain and blood cancers. This project investigates how cells inactivate the correct genes at the correct time during development to understand how defective gene inactivation can cause disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Baby’s First Years study will provide rigorous evidence about the causal impacts of early childhood unconditional cash transfers on family processes and brain development, learning, and behavior among children in low-income families as they transition into school at age 6. It will also assess, at age 8, the extent to which any impacts persist 20 months after the cessation of the cash transfers. Evidence from the study will inform policy debates about the benefits for children of cash income and related supports and the consequences of proposed expansions and cuts to federal and state social assistance and tax programs.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The proposed research is very relevant to public health as it aims to establish a novel non-invasive approach to assess and monitor systemic microvascular development in premature babies responding to an unmet clinical need in neonatology. This research will apply nailfold capillaroscopy to non-invasively identify infants with vascular growth impairment, e.g. retinopathy of prematurity (ROP), necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) and pulmonary hypertension (PHTN) complicating bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) which could benefit from novel therapeutic interventions aimed at preventing microvascular complications of prematurity, thus improving patient’s outcome.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Endolysosomal vesicles use molecular motors to move long distances on microtubules, and they influence a range of cellular functions including growth, division, and survival. Perturbations in microtubule-based transport and vesicular trafficking underlie many neurological diseases and cancer. This research aims to elucidate how vesicles attach to molecular motors and how their movement directs the distribution of other organelles via membrane contact sites.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The precise control of gene expression is crucial for the faithful orchestration of the developmental program, but mis-expression of genes can be pathogenic in many contexts. The proposed work will combine advances in large-scale DNA synthesis and single-cell sequencing to study the regulation of genes that pattern the developing nervous system, but are also implicated in diseases such as Alzheimer’s and cancer. Therefore, the results of this project will reveal fundamental principles of development but will also inform disease mechanisms and potential therapies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Double-stranded RNA is a potential contributor to brain inflammation in age-related diseases, but its involvement and regulation in aging and Alzheimer’s disease remain unknown. This project will examine the role of a regulator of double-stranded RNA (ADAR1) and its influence on brain function, inflammation and dementia, while also identifying the cellular origins of double-stranded RNA in this context. The proposed research may also identify potential therapeutic targets to combat brain inflammation with aging and Alzheimer’s disease.

ORG_NAME: VA NORTHERN CALIFORNIA HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Project Narrative Stroke is the leading cause of chronic disability in the United States. Each year, approximately 795,000 strokes occur accounting for over half of all acute inpatient neurological admissions across both Veterans Affairs and civilian medical settings. Persons 45-64 years of age now account for approximately half of total stroke care costs, a shift heralding an urgent need for rehabilitation to not only reduce disability and attendant costs of care, but optimize stroke recovery for persons in the productive and vital years of their lives. As a result, there is a critical need to identify rehabilitation methods that promote genuine recovery. The current proposal investigates methods to optimize induction of neuroplasticity in an effort to enhance walking function in Veterans following stroke. We will test three approaches to delivering paired associative stimulation, a non-invasive form of neuromodulation with known influences on neuroplasticity.

PHR: UV Plasmon-Enhanced Chiroptical Spectroscopy of Membrane-Binding Proteins Relevance to Public Health Membrane binding proteins have diverse important biological functions ranging from controlling signaling to regulating membrane fusion but are difficult to characterize with existing biophysical tools. This project develops electromagnetically enhanced chiroptical spectroscopies that can provide detailed structural information about membrane-binding proteins under physiological conditions and will, thus, lead to a greatly improved understanding of these important proteins with important disease diagnostic implications.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Millions of children visit emergency departments each year with variable access to pediatric expertise, and it is currently unclear how the sickest children fare. Ensuring the best outcomes in pediatric acute care is a national public health priority and depends on understanding variability in hospital quality. To understand where in the nation outcomes could be improved, we will use sophisticated whole-nation network analysis to develop a comprehensive atlas of national pediatric acute care outcomes, which we will then use to compare outcomes in three of the most common serious pediatric diseases: appendicitis, neurotrauma, and sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For the 32 million people in the U.S. currently living with atopic dermatitis (eczema), the waxing and waning course of their chronic disease is impossible to predict, does not respond uniformly to treatment, and results in substantial economic impact and decreased quality of life. Understanding drivers of the disease activity is essential to developing treatments, and sodium/salt consumption is a likely contributor. Using a new MRI technique to image sodium in the skin on a cohort of 90 older adult men and women followed for two years, we will test novel hypotheses about the role of dietary salt intake and skin barrier function on sodium storage in the skin and atopic dermatitis severity and persistence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Anastasis is a newly discovered cell recovery phenomenon that enables dying cells to survive by reversing the apoptotic cell death process. The mechanisms and consequences of anastasis remain unclear. By developing a biosensor to detect anastasis in live animals, and identifying key regulators of anastasis, our project will develop critical tools and knowledge to study the physiological, pathological, and therapeutic implications of anastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Eggs and oocytes are unusually large cells that have unique mechanisms for regulating their cell cycles. Several molecular pathways involved in human diseases, such as cancer, are used to control progression through these early developmental stages. The goal of this MIRA R35 project is to understand how cell size regulates cell cycle and developmental progression in these extreme cell types to uncover broader control principles that may be relevant to human health.

PHR: LISTOS Narrative Our proposed project, LISTOS O cancer Mexico for Cancer Control - L everaging I mplementation S cience T o ptimize S trategies for Cancer Control will increase capacity for implementation science for control in Mexico and Latin America. The project proposes to establish a new center in and carry out two cancer control implementation science research projects: 1) Implementing colorectal cancer screening in publicly funded health systems in Mexico, and 2) Implementation of integrated care for rapid diagnosis of breast cancer in Mexico. The research projects and capacity building activities have the potential not only to advance the science of cancer control implementation, but most importantly, to reduce the burden of cancer in Mexico and Latin America.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project will build novel computational tools to measure, interpret, and predict basic biological dynamics of cell signaling, transcription and translation. When integrated with single-cell experiments, these tools will support national goals to seek predictive knowledge about the nature and behavior of living systems; to enable more rapid and cost-effective health-related discoveries; and to develop the human, physical and computational resources necessary to enhance the nation's ability to prevent and treat disease.
