IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE  This study will examine clinically-relevant rhythmogenic properties of spinal locomotor-related interneurons, including their intrinsic and local network rhythm-generating properties and how they are activated by neurons in the brainstem. Findings will provide essential insights and reveal potential therapeutic targets for the restoration of locomotor function to be used in the treatment of paralysis and disability that result from injury or disease.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Findings from this study will lead to a more nuanced understanding of mechanisms underlying sex-specific trajectories of internalizing symptoms and help inform targeted early interventions. Specifically, results may identify sex-specific treatment targets and inform trials of personalized neuromodulatory therapies such as transcranial magnetic stimulation. Furthermore, predictors of longitudinal symptomatology could be used for treatment stratification in clinical trials using personalized biomarkers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Ubiquitin ligases are enzymes that attach a protein signal called ubiquitin to specific proteins, which often results in the recycling of these proteins by the cell. Ubiquitin ligases are critical to the survival of all animals, plants, and fungi, and disruption of their function results in numerous diseases in humans including most cancers and neurodegenerative diseases. We study the molecular function of ubiquitin ligases to gain new insights into how they function and use them as a scaffold to engineer biosensors to study disease, engineer biological systems, and improve sustainable manufacturing of foods, fuels, pharmaceuticals, and other chemicals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Within a cell, organelles can communicate with each other via specialized protein structures called membrane contact sites (MCSs). MCSs play a crucial role in cellular homeostasis, but our knowledge about them is limited to a very narrow group of organisms. This research seeks to characterize MCSs in a branch of pathogenic protists that cause significant human diseases—such as malaria and toxoplasmosis—to understand how their unique organelles communicate with each other, and identify new targets for the development of anti-parasitic therapies.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parkinson’s disease affects millions of individuals worldwide and causes progressive abnormalities in movement as well as changes in motivation such as apathy and impulsivity. The goal of this research is to understand the brain mechanisms underlying these impairments in motivation by probing brain networks at high resolution. This work may lead to new and precise strategies to treat these non-motor symptoms of Parkinson’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will tackle a challenge central to public health: understanding the essential cellular and molecular mechanisms controlling tissue degeneration, regeneration and return to homeostasis in vertebrates. Using a model system that provides natural and cyclical tissue degeneration and regeneration, these efforts will investigate mechanisms underlying fundamental problems in tissue patterning and homeostasis, as well provide insight into pathological states of hypertrophy and degenerative disease and repairing lost or damaged tissue through regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE Psychosocial stress and voice problems are inevitably linked, however, the underlying biological mechanisms governing this relationship remain understudied. The microbiome is a key regulator of the psychosocial stress response, with deleterious, stress-induced changes to epithelial barrier integrity. This proposal will investigate the microbial and epithelial consequences of psychosocial stress in the larynx.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Escherichia coli is the most thoroughly studied bacterium on earth; therefore, a computer knowledgebase that in- tegrates experimental ﬁndings for this organism from thousands of scientiﬁc publications is a valuable and cost- effective resource for science and education. The comprehensive knowledge and computational tools available through EcoCyc accelerate the research of scientists who use this organism to develop biofuels, of scientists who study related pathogenic bacteria, and of scientists who work with the bacteria comprising the human microbiome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Our purpose is to understand the molecular processes that control the gout flare with our research plan based on an inflammatory pathway we identified from a very large genome-wide association study in gout. In our research we will study the genetic regulation of the pathways in experimental systems (including a zebrafish model of gout and human cell lines), we will determine how gout risk genotype changes gene expression and the epigenome in immune cells from volunteers and cell lines, and we will study how a particular class of gene that doesn’t code for protein (‘lncRNA’) controls expression of immunomodulatory genes in gout.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Because each patient’s tumor is unique, treatments should be tailored to individual patients. We will develop a patient-centric approach that integrates novel experimental and computational methods using patient derived tumor cells to identify novel drug targets and potentially effective drugs and drug combinations. Identifying targets and effective drugs directly in patient derived samples with known clinical history will significantly enhance translation of our findings leading to improved clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is characterized by excessive consumption of alcohol, frequently in a compulsive manner to avoid the negative affective state that arises during withdrawal. The goal of this proposal is to determine if astrocytes within the lateral orbitofrontal cortex contribute to escalated drinking following the development of dependence. These studies will further elucidate the role of astrocytes and neurons in the lateral orbitofrontal cortex in dependence and withdrawal to provide insight on future therapeutic interventions.

PHR: This study will provide a prototype of a culturally tailored technology-based program for pain management of Asian American breast cancer survivors with depressive symptoms. This study will accelerate the translation of technology-based programs into health care and will be an important contribution in pain management of cancer survivors with depressive symptoms. Ultimately, this study will contribute to reducing ethnic disparities in health/disease experience by providing directions for culturally competent health care services, specifically for adequate pain and symptom management of racial/ethnic minority cancer survivors.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE DNA methylation age, a good reflection of the human aging process, has been used to predict chronological age and aging-related diseases. Developing a transfer learning framework to refine existing age prediction models and construct prediction intervals will increase the adaptability and interpretability of these epigenetic clocks.

PHR: Narrative Currently prescribed treatments for children with cerebral palsy are often invasive or make irreversible changes to the neuromuscular system that may have long-term detrimental impacts on function. Noninvasive transcutaneous spinal neuromodulation using SCIPTM device paired with activity-based neurorehabilitation therapy (ABNT) has the potential to improve function and quality of life for children with cerebral palsy .

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drexel's ComPASS Coordination Center (C3) will provide the leadership, resources, and support to accomplish the goals of the Community Partnerships to Advance Science for Society (ComPASS) Program, a first-of-its- kind national effort to advance health equity in communities that have been shaped by structural and systemic forces and traditionally excluded from, and, at times, harmed, by the research enterprise. Shifting the power back to communities, the C3 will provide the administrative assistance, data, and training needed to help ComPASS grantees achieve their unique stated goals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative. Engineering the genetic code of living organisms can achieve functions that are not available in extant living systems, 1.) including escape-free biocontainment, 2.) the prevention of horizontal gene transfer, and 3.) resistance to all natural viruses. This proposal will yield a novel technology and a bacterial host for controlled drug production that simultaneously achieve these three functions. The combination of genetic-code-based biocontainment and horizontal gene transfer prevention is expected to enable long-term, safe therapeutic applications including noninvasive drug production inside the human body, without the unwanted proliferation of such therapeutics or their genetic information outside patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall purpose of this proposal is to continue to identify new strategies for cancer immunotherapy based on understanding the molecular features of the T cell-inflamed and non-T cell-inflamed tumor microenvironment. Our overall approach centers on a bi-directional work flow between patient outcomes and clinical samples, and mouse models for mechanistic understanding. Our 5-pronged research stream investigates novel T cell immune checkpoints, innate immune strategies to promote de novo T cell responses in the tumor microenvironment, tumor cell-intrinsic oncogenic events mediating immune resistance, regulation of anti-tumor immunity by the commensal microbiota, and germline variants influencing host anti-tumor T cell responses.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genomic information has the potential to transform health care by informing risk prediction and giving biological insights into potential treatments. However, existing genomic models have been based primarily on non-African individuals and have been based primarily on single nucleotide polymorphisms, ignoring more complex variant types. Here, we leverage innovative data analysis methods to characterize genetic variation at repetitive regions of the genome and their contribution to medically relevant phenotypes within Africa.

PHR: The goal of VA's RR&D office is to maximize functional recovery. This proposal will allow us to test an intervention that combines the fundamentals of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation with state-of-the-art nutritional support and innovations in care such as telehealth and the use of activity trackers to optimize patients before high-risk surgery. This intervention has the potential to not only reduce complications and hospital readmissions, but also to maximize functional recovery and quality of life for thousands of Veterans undergoing high-risk surgery every year. Furthermore, the proposal is the first step in the design and implementation of prehabilitative services for Veterans living in rural areas and those with inadequate support or transportation.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women with chronic conditions are more likely to not use contraception and experience unplanned pregnancy, yet lack resources that address their unique contraceptive decision needs. To address this pressing public health and clinical issue, this project will evaluate a web-based contraceptive decision support tool that helps patients choose contraception in context of their chronic conditions and personal priorities. The project’s focus on contraception for a medically at-risk population is aligned with NICHD’s Strategic Plan to support people’s reproductive priorities, reduce contraceptive non-use, and improve reproductive health outcomes.

PHR: NARRATIVE Sub-Saharan Africa carries the highest burden globally of both HIV and cervical cancer. Cervical Cancer is 6-fold more common in women with HIV, and is preventable via vaccination prior to HPV exposure, or through screening and treating women for HPV infection or cervical lesions. Rwanda is a low-income country with high burden of both HIV and cervical cancer. Finding effective implementation strategies for cervical cancer in WWH can impact favorably on African women’s health.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) affects millions of people worldwide and is a risk factor for later development of neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's Disease (AD). TBI causes rapid release of the proteins amyloid and tau, which are the toxic proteins that build up in the brain in AD. Using Positron Emission Tomography (PET) and Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) performed as soon as possible after TBI, this project will monitor the deposition and rate of clearance of these proteins, with the goal of better understanding how brain clearance may relate to TBI recovery and later risk of neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Centers for Disease Control and Infection consider Clostridioides difficile infection an urgent public health threat; this career development award addresses our limited ability to predict its severe complications, response to treatment, or recurrence of disease, and to distinguish it from indolent carriage. We hypothesize that by integrating fecal immune, metabolic and microbial data, with modern bioinformatics tools, we can improve our ability to predict these situations and understand the biological mechanisms behind them. Biological markers in stool will be valuable tools to choose or design more timely and effective treatments for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The number of pregnant women with obesity and/or gestational diabetes has increased more than 30% in the last decades producing nearly half a million infants each year in the United States alone who are born Large for Gestational Age (LGA, birthweight >90% for sex and gestational age). These infants have feeding difficulties, prolonged hospital stays and are at increased risk for future obesity. This study will evaluate the role of body composition, appetite- regulating hormones, and the implementation of a novel infant feeding strategy and its impact on length of hospital stay and short-term clinical outcomes in these at-risk infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE AfaSci is developing an FDA-accepted investigational new drug (IND) AFA-281 for alcohol use disorder. This drug can normalize neural activity and enhance the body’s anti-inflammatory ability. In our preliminary studies, AFA-281 decreased alcohol intake and preference, and suppressed alcohol-seeking behavior in rodents. We now propose to rigorously test its efficacy in animal models of alcohol use disorder to provide evidence for future clinical development of this IND into a safe and effective medication for alcohol use disorder.

PHR: Project Narrative Cancer immunotherapies have led to major treatment breakthroughs for a number of different cancers, but the majority of head and neck cancer patients do not respond to immunotherapies, and clinical responses are often not durable. We have demonstrated that targeting tumors with stereotactic radiation in combination with immunotherapy while sparing draining lymphatics enhances anticancer immunity, resulting in significantly improved response profiles. The research outlined in this proposal will leverage targeted tumor radiation in combination with optimized immunotherapy in a particularly lethal form of head and neck cancer to improve clinical outcomes for both tumor control and treatment toxicity, using both animal models of head and neck cancer as well as data from clinical trials of combination targeted radiation and immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a disease that affects the joints and is characterized by chronic inflammation, cartilage and bone damage that and can lead to permanent disability. We are studying how a type of white blood cell (CD8 T cell) and a protein called a granzyme can activate an inflammatory pathway (called the complement pathway) which drives inflammation and joint damage. Defining this new pathway would reveal new targets for drug development to treat RA.

PHR: Although there are few racial/ethnic and income-based differences in men’s fertility intentions, Black, Latino and low-income men are more likely to be involved in unwanted pregnancies and less likely to rely on vasectomy than White and higher income men. These differences have persisted in the US for decades, and there have been few efforts to comprehensively assess the individual demand and healthcare supply-side factors underlying these uneven patterns of vasectomy use. By developing and testing a vasectomy decision support tool and prospectively assessing men’s vasectomy-related health care navigation, the proposed study seeks to identify potential strategies to facilitate timely access to desired vasectomy services to ensure that all men, regardless of race/ethnicity and income, can make informed reproductive healthcare decisions.

PHR: Project Narrative Why do children, who have not suffered the illnesses of time, need support in the pediatric intensive care unit? In this study, we will use next-generation sequencing to assess monogenic (i.e., single gene) and polygenic (i.e., many gene) risk for disease and abnormal medication response for critically ill children. The results of this study have the potential to change the clinical management of children with critical illness, shed light onto the biologic basis of disease, and drive novel therapeutic development.

PHR: Project Narrative MorPhiC consortium will deliver rich resources of molecular and cellular phenotypes before and after gene knockout using in vitro cellular systems. We will develop statistical methods to combine MorPhiC resources and omic data in human phenotype studies to infer gene functions in diverse settings and identify potential causal genes of human phenotypes. Our methods pave the way to use MorPhiC resources to study the impact of gene loss on complex phenotypes.

PHR: Project Narrative Virtually all U.S. adults will develop multimorbidity – coexistence of multiple chronic conditions – by late adulthood, resulting in poor health outcomes and exponential increases in healthcare utilization, cost, and treatment burden as multimorbidity progresses. To improve the care of patients with multimorbidity, clinicians and investigators need effective, systematic, patient-centered tools that measure prevalent and impactful diseases weighted to patient-prioritized outcomes broadly applicable for diverse community-dwelling adults. This research will yield a new, validated, patient-centered multimorbidity index for electronic health record (EHR) data that is readily available and scalable to help guide clinical decisions, population-health management, policy, and research to improve the health outcomes and quality of care for diverse, vulnerable aging adults across the lifespan with multimorbidity – all NIA priorities.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed RM1 grant will enhance the measurement, quality, and equity of care delivered in 20 community opioid treatment programs (OTPs) by co-designing and implementing measurement-based care (MBC) tools and systems. Using a Hybrid Implementation Effectiveness Type II trial with a stepped-wedge design, we will simultaneously evaluate MBC implementation (e.g., fidelity) and clinical (e.g., patient retention, improved quality of life) effectiveness. This significant and innovative study will provide: (1) critical preliminary evidence regarding the role and significance of capitalizing on MBC in opioid use disorder (OUD) interventions (including evidence on potential mechanisms underlying MBC’s effects); (2) enhanced implementation of a sustainable, equitable, and effective MBC intervention via implementation strategies that are co-designed with stakeholders (policymaker, payer, and OTP), including paperwork reduction strategies as a means to enhance capacity; and (3) alternative avenues to potentially enhance symptom-related outcomes and treatment retention of OUD interventions with downstream societal, psychological, and public health benefits.

PHR: NARRATIVE We will develop efficient computational tools to detect base modifications in DNA and RNA molecules, through analysis of ionic signals generated from the Nanopore sequencer. We will also validate these tools on cancer samples and cell lines. These novel methods and the computational toolbox for DNA/RNA modification detection will facilitate our understanding of the human epigenome and epitranscriptome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is characterized by a lack of behavioral inhibition, leading to uncontrolled and excessive alcohol consumption. This project tests the hypothesis that chronic alcohol exposure leads to critical adaptations in a thalamostriatal behavioral inhibition circuit, releasing the brake on alcohol seeking and use even in the face of behavioral suppressors. Understanding how chronic alcohol exposure alters the complex integration of information in this crucial reward circuitry will help to identify key targets for therapeutic exploration.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Narrative The overarching goal of this project is to test the impact of health equity-focused navigation support for colorectal cancer screening on reducing disparity gaps across primary care clinics serving a racial and ethnically diverse population using a stepped wedged, randomized trial. We anticipate that tailoring navigation implementation and documenting contextual adaptations will lead to lower disparity gaps in colorectal cancer screening and will provide patient, clinic, and health care system feedback on how such programs can promote health equity.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Bridging the gap: Delivering Equitable Colorectal Cancer Screening

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obstetric Life SupportTM (OBLSTM) is a validated simulation curriculum to train health care workers (HCWs) across the chain of survival on preventing, recognizing, and managing maternal medical emergencies. This project will evaluate implementation of OBLSTM in a regionalized perinatal health system in Arizona, leveraging public-private partnerships to target HCWs in hospital, freestanding birthing center, and prehospital contexts, and especially those serving maternity care deserts and other marginalized communities. Findings will be used to promote national scale-up of this important health care innovation with the goal of improving patient safety and reducing inequities in maternal morbidity and mortality.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Implementation of a Maternal Resuscitation Curriculum in a Regionalized Perinatal Health System: Maximizing the Chain of Survival to Reduce Maternal Health Inequities

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Breast cancer brain metastasis (BCBM) is associated with deadly outcomes due to limited therapeutic options and poor response, urgently calling for the development of novel therapeutic intervention strategies. We have found that oncolytic herpes simplex virus-1 (oHSV) therapy induces neutrophil infiltration and neutrophil extracellular trap (NET) formation through induction of Insulin-like growth factor-2 (IGF2) expression and secretion into tumor microenvironment (TME), hampering therapeutic efficacy of oHSV. In this proposed research, we will uncover the mechanistic relationship between oHSV-induced IGF2 and oHSV-triggered neutrophil infiltration and NET in BCBM, and characterize the preclinical therapeutic impact of novel IGF2- scavenging oHSV in combination with radiation therapy as well as NET-mitigating oHSV for significant advance of BCBM treatment in the future clinical application.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because a noninvasive MRI-based quantitative tool for measuring cerebral metabolism can be used to monitor patients longitudinally, both clinically and in Alzheimer's disease clinical trials. The advantages of MRI over PET include improved spatial resolution, decreased cost, increased availability, and noninvasive imaging technique, specifically not requiring injection of a radioactive tracer. This research is relevant to the NIA's mission to support research to improve the health and well- being of older people.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Consumer-grade wearable devices, such as the Fitbit, are popular gadgets that also objectively measure physical activity, sleep and heart rate, and can transmit their data in near-real time. We investigate the Fitbit as a clinical tool to objectively assess recovery after pediatric appendectomy, the most prevalent inpatient pediatric surgical procedure in the US, and apply machine learning approaches to the Fitbit data for early detection of infection. We also investigate the effect of the availability of Fitbit-based alerts for infection in near- real time on clinical decision making, time to first contact with the healthcare system, and healthcare utilization patterns.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the United States, deaths related to pregnancy have more than doubled over the last twenty years, with an additional rise after the COVID-19 pandemic. To address these alarming trends, we designed a program that delivers care to mothers and infants together and provides multiple types of support during the year after pregnancy – the Multi-modal Maternal Infant Perinatal Outpatient Delivery System (MOMI PODS). In this trial, we’ll determine if MOMI PODS improves heart, metabolic, and mental health among new mothers and study how this may occur and how we can improve the program to better meet patient and family needs.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: The impact of cannabis use on HIV infection and the latent reservoir is poorly understood, particularly for solid tissues such as the brain. We propose to establish a robust humanized mouse model of cannabis use and HIV infection with human microglia. We will use this model to understand how cannabis exposure impacts the size, transcriptional activity and phenotype of the brain HIV reservoir during therapy.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Human Teratogens Course Pregnant or breastfeeding individuals are often worried about exposures such as medications, maternal diseases, chemicals in the environment, infectious agents, and other substances and seek counseling from their healthcare providers. The Human Teratogens Course educates healthcare providers with up-to-date information on exposures during pregnancy and breastfeeding. The course also teaches healthcare providers how to assess and evaluate the benefits and risks of these exposures to better counsel their patients and improve the quality of their services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Aging is a key risk factor for many chronic diseases, including Alzheimer’s disease. This proposal aims at examining the role of R-loops in mechanisms of transcriptional stress, genome instability, and chronic immune response; all hallmarks of aging. Successful completion of proposed aims should provide new avenues for therapeutic approaches targeting these hallmarks, and thus slowing down onset or progression of neurodegenerative disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: UBTF tandem duplications (UBTF-TD) in exon 13 were recently described by our group as a new recurrent and likely class-defining somatic alteration in pediatric AML that is associated with poor outcome. In this proposal, we will use newly developed human and mouse models and a large series of primary patient samples to dissect the molecular impact of UBTF-TD expression through a combination of functional and multi-omic approaches. The successful completion of these studies will provide the first mechanistic insights into how this recently identified mutation in a gene that encodes for a nucleolar protein disrupts hematopoietic development to drive leukemia formation and will ultimately aid in the identification of therapeutic options for this new high-risk subtype of pediatric AML.

PHR: Narrative Altered expression or function of KDM5 family genes can result in two clinical pathologies: cancer and intellectual disability. To understanding how dysregulation of KDM5 causes these disorders, we first require detailed knowledge of how these transcriptional regulators carry out their normal physiological functions in vivo, which is the goal of this research proposal.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The rationale for remote neurocognitive assessment include addressing the needs of underserved populations, reducing the risk of exposure to infective disorders, rapid care access, and minimizing travel burden to distal clinical centers. A Computerized Assessment by Remote Examiner System (CARES) is proposed that will integrate a range of system functions, including end-to-end study/trial monitoring and management services ranging from user registration to reporting. CARES will host computerized versions of neurocognitive and behavioral tests widely applied in clinical assessment, controlled trials and wide-ranging research. The CARES constitutes a key enabling technology for assessing those with AD/RD and early stage MCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative While there are many important health benefits of physical activity, how exercise exerts its effects is not fully understood. A more comprehensive understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying the responses to exercise would significantly impact public health. Continuation of the Molecular Transducers of Physical Activity Consortium (MoTrPAC) will achieve its objective of generating a comprehensive map of the molecular responses to acute exercise and exercise training. with a long-range goal of elucidating the mechanisms by which exercise improves health.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mapping the function of every gene in human cells will enable us to begin to define how gene expression programs impart specialized and adaptive human cellular functions required for life. The innovative approach proposed here combines CRISPRoff, a cutting-edge genetic manipulation technology, with comprehensive single cell molecular phenotyping approaches in a classic model of human development, which will allow us to study the effects of specific genes in a biologically meaningful way to yield new insights that are broadly applicable across cell types and disease areas. Specifically, we will characterize at single cell resolution in space and time the function of human transcription factors and epigenetic regulators in early developmental cell fate transitions.

PHR: Project Narrative The fusion peptide of HIV-1 is a vulnerable target site with tremendous promise for new preventions and treatments. This project applies recently established technologies to understand how antibodies against the fusion peptide effectively suppress HIV-1. This study will reveal new best-in-class antibody drugs against the fusion peptide site and provide actionable vaccine strategies to help end the HIV-1 pandemic.

PHR: Health Relevance All drugs of abuse cause levels of the neurotransmitter dopamine to be elevated in the nucleus accumbens. This effect is considered critical to the addictive and psychomotor activating properties of abused drugs, as well as to the arousing effects of psychostimulants, but the specific neural mechanisms at play remain enigmatic in part because the natural functions of accumbens dopamine are poorly understood. By determining how dopamine alters the activity of accumbens neurons to promote both arousal and reward-seeking behavior, we will open a new path towards understanding how the elevated dopamine caused by drugs leads to the behavioral consequences of taking these drugs, which may ultimately lead to novel therapeutics to treat addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE Despite the importance of medical imaging in modern clinical diagnosis and treatment, current techniques struggle in essential areas such as monitoring newly developed cell-based therapies, detecting diseases of inflammation, and quantitatively detecting bleeding. Magnetic Particle Imaging (MPI) is an emerging medical imaging technology that provides scientists and clinicians with a new tool for understanding, diagnosing, and monitoring these pathologies. In this Direct-to-Phase II SBIR grant, we will develop critical technologies to bring the sensitivity and resolution of the world’s first human-scale MPI scanner near the physics limits, marking a significant step forward on the path to a commercial clinical MPI scanner.

PHR: Project Narrative  Approximately 1 million total knee arthroplasty procedures are performed in older adults each year, but 15% or more of patients report unsatisfactory long-term pain outcomes despite a technically-successful procedure. Although mechanisms contributing to chronic post-TKA pain are poorly understood, our recent prospective work suggests that elevated oxidative stress may contribute. This project will use a randomized, placebo-controlled design to test for the first time whether a potent antioxidant intervention (glycine + N- acetylcysteine) improves long-term post-TKA pain, functional, and opioid use outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transmembrane protein 106B (TMEM106B) is a protein that normally localizes to the lysosome and has been genetically linked to frontotemporal dementia (FTD). Recently, filaments formed from TMEM106B have been discovered in several disorders, including FTD and Alzheimer’s disease. The current project is focused on characterizing and defining patterns of TMEM106B aggregation in the brain, in addition to understanding the functional consequences of this filament deposition on the disease course.

PHR: Harm Reduction Workers (HRWs) play a critical role in the substance misuse continuum of care but they are exposed to high rates of lifetime and occupational stress and trauma which is linked to adverse impacts on patient care, unmet mental health needs, turnover, burnout, and relapse. This research will adapt, field test, and conduct a hybrid-type I efficacy trial comparing the effects of Stress First Aid for HRWs versus a no- treatment control condition on social-support, burnout, secondary traumatic stress, use of mental health care, engagement, and turnover. The long-term goal of our work is to implement a sustainable and effective occupational stress intervention for HRWs nationally in order to strengthen their important role in the substance misuse work force.

PHR: Project Narrative In this project, we will bring together experts from various fields of MRI and neuropathology, including post-mortem MRI, vascular pathology, image processing, and registration to develop the necessary tools and resources for analyzing post-mortem brains related to Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and AD-related dementia (ADRD) through MRI-histopathology analysis. This study will enhance our comprehension of the vascular contributions to cognitive impairment and dementia (VCID) and provide insights into the underlying mechanisms for their in vivo interpretations.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis is the second leading cause of maternal death in the U.S. For racial and ethnic minoritized birthing people, especially those who are Black, living in poverty, and from underserved communities, labor and postpartum are particularly vulnerable risk periods. We propose a multicenter, multidisciplinary study, with community co-leadership and co-design, to evaluate a maternal sepsis safety bundle, optimize risk prediction accounting for the social determinants of health, and establish a novel maternal care continuity model to reduce sepsis-related death and disability and increase maternal health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: HENRY FORD HEALTH + MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disparities in PrEP uptake persist in the United States, particularly among priority populations (e.g., men who have sex with men, Black and Latino individuals), as estimates show only 9% of Blacks and 16% of Latinos who met the indications were prescribed PrEP. Barriers to PrEP prescription exist in the primary care setting for providers and patients; this study will be the first known application of the multiphase optimization strategy (MOST) framework to test the effect of intervention components aimed to increase PrEP initiation in primary care, alone and in combination, in an optimization trial. The proposed research will yield important insights into what combination of intervention components delivers the most efficient intervention to providers and patients and what factors affect PrEP uptake among priority populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative There are distinct sex-based differences that affect the natural history and immune pathogenesis of HIV infection. These factors likely impact the establishment, distribution, and transcriptional activity of the HIV reservoir. Our study will determine the effect of declining sex hormones on HIV persistence and inflammation in midlife women during all stages of reproductive aging while on suppressive antiretroviral therapy and define underlying mechanism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Through recent innovations in imaging techniques and the ability to process these images at scale, we have unprecedented access to public datasets of molecular and cellular spatial patterns of organization. To make full use of these new spatially-complex data streams, to understand the dynamical processes that are shaping cellular and molecular spatial collectives, to go beyond simple description of pattern towards understanding of function and adaptive design, we must rst develop a predictive theory of complex spatial structure. My group builds mathematical representations of the spatial architecture of molecular and cellular biological systems and studies the evolutionary-relevant properties of these complex spatial topologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Sundowning syndrome, characterized by agitation, aggressiveness, and wandering during the late afternoon and early evening, occurs in about 20% of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and Alzheimer’s disease-related dementias (ADRD) patients and often leads to institutionalization. Using mouse models of AD/ADRD and other transgenic mouse lines, we will examine the role of a novel neural pathway from the brainstem to the circadian system in temporal disturbances of body temperature, locomotor activity, and behavioral aggression that are relevant to those seen in sundowning. This project may lead to a better understanding of sundowning-related circadian dysfunction and may suggest an eventual therapy that could greatly improve the quality of life for AD/ADRD patients and their caregivers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a major cause of death and disability across all ages. Primary mechanical damage induced brain tissue disruption after TBI progressively expands due to secondary injury mechanisms. Lipid peroxidation and subsequent cell demise via a recently discovered program of regulated death, ferroptosis, are important mechanisms involved TBI pathogenesis. However, the information on the types of cells in which these two aberrant processes are occurring and the major TBI-induced deficiencies in their regulation remain unknown, largely due to the lack of adequate methods. The goal of this application is to optimize and apply developed by us entirely new and revolutionizing technology – multi-omics imaging based on the employment of specifically designed secondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS) and permitting simultaneous high-resolution imaging of three major types of biomolecules – lipids, proteins, and metabolites. Thus, not only the types of cells in TBI brain will be reliably identified but also accurate and quantitative information on changes of the amounts of oxidatively modified lipids and other metabolites will be determined in different subcellular compartments. By correlating this information with the data on neuropathology of the injured brain we will be able, for the first time, to decipher the mechanisms of lipid peroxidation driving ferroptotic death in specific cell types during TBI progression. Consequently, new effective and selective small molecule regulators of ferroptosis-inducing lipid peroxidation will be developed for targeted therapies and for evaluation of their efficacy in TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Our discovery of the nitrate signaling network controlled by three types of evolutionarily conserved master regulators, the dual NLP nitrate-sensor/transcription factors, the Ca2+- sensor/transducer protein kinases (CPKs), and the master nutrient signaling hub TOR will help uncover the poorly understood molecular links in nutrient regulation of transcription, metabolism, and organ growth in plants, which are the core to agricultural and bioenergy productivity for sustaining human life and the ecosystems on the planet. The new concepts and mechanisms revealed from this nutrient-triggered Ca2+ signaling represent a paradigm shift in current research on nutrient regulation in multicellular organisms from plants to humans and may aid the elucidation of transcriptional networks coupling metabolic regulation and organ growth pivotal to the health, longevity, and diseases of animals and humans. As plants play a central role in bridging the conversion of inorganic nitrogen to organic nitrogen in the global nitrogen cycle, the proposed studies will lead to fundamental knowledge with sustained impact on nutrient signaling central to plant biology, environmental protection, as well as human nutrition and health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative This project proposes to develop a battery-free, flexible, and implantable piezoelectric nanogenerator device that performs closed-loop biofeedback electrostimulation (ES) on the vagus nerves to control food intake. This device is attached on the stomach surface and generates tunable ES signals in response to stomach peristalsis upon food intake. This project will establish an essential biological and engineering foundation that will allow us to move rapidly to the next step of in vivo studies using this closed-loop neuromodulation technique in large animal models, eventually leading to human trials.

PHR: NARRATIVE Sarcomas represent a heterogenous group of tumors that affect individuals across the lifespan. Determining disease, survivor, treatment, lifestyle and genomic factors that contribute to oncologic (treatment response, recurrence) and non-oncologic outcomes (treatment toxicity, quality of life) and survival in sarcoma patients is critical for strategic surveillance for current survivors and to inform future therapies. Furthermore, strategies to monitor disease through liquid biopsy approaches has tremendous potential as both a prognostic and predictive biomarker, to guide therapeutic interventions.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) is highly prevalent and can potentially have long-lasting consequences for the brain, cognitive function, and behavior, including elevated risk for substance abuse and psychopathology. In this study, we will use a powerful and rigorous cotwin control approach to identify causal effects of TBI by comparing twins with mTBI history with their identical cotwins who never had a TBI. A better understanding of long-lasting consequences of childhood and adolescent mTBI will promote the development of more efficient treatment and rehabilitation efforts, as well as prevention of substance abuse and psychopathology frequently associated with mTBI history.

PHR: Successful HIV cure requires eradication of virus from all reservoirs to prevent recrudescence in anatomically distinct locations including the CNS, where microglia and macrophages are a potential HIV reservoir; however, our knowledge of the mechanisms underlying HIV latency, persistence, and reactivation in these cell populations in the presence of non-HIV-related comorbidities such as cocaine are limited due to major barriers. Our novel approach using state-of-art technologies and models will define discreet cell subtypes infected with HIV in complex multicellular contexts in the presence of cocaine and will address a critical gap in our knowledge that is needed to eliminate HIV reservoir in the CNS of PWH with substance use disorders, while also developing physiologically relevant platforms to identify novel targets for effective latency reversal strategies, antiretroviral drugs, and adjunctive neuroprotective therapies in the CNS.

ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study is highly significant because it addresses the growing health-harming legal needs impacting vulnerable Latinx and recent migrant communities affected by intersecting epidemics. Testing a critical-time intervention medical-legal partnership (CTI-MLP) approach, as the one proposed in this study, could improve patient-reported overall global health by mitigating health harming legal needs and addressing social and structural barriers to care for medically underserved communities. Completion of this project will result in the development of an innovative, evidence-based intervention package to prevent and reduce health inequities, improve patient and community health outcomes, and advance health equity among historically marginalized populations.

PHR: The Partnership between Ponce Health Sciences University (PHSU) in Puerto Rico and the Moffitt Cancer Center (MCC) in Tampa is focused on reducing cancer disparities in the Hispanic/Latino (H/L) communities and contributing to the elimination of health disparities in the H/L population at large. The Partnership aims to provide the means to expand research capabilities of the ISUPS (PHSU) and enhance research on cancer health disparities at the NCI-designated Cancer Center (MCC). The joint programs have resulted in successful outcomes in cancer research, education, training, community outreach and in biobanking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative There is a critical gap in understanding hospital- and structural-level causes leading to maternal mortality and severe maternal morbidity (SMM), particularly with regard to preventable deaths. Our central hypothesis is that social determinants of health and hospital factors significantly impact maternal and pregnancy outcomes, and are more prognostic for BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, People of Color) populations. The proposed research is innovative, as it will (a) use data to develop and validate a prognostic scoring tool for maternal mortality/SMM that goes beyond individual-level factors; (b) assess hospital-level factors that may contribute to maternal mortality, by using data from 128 separate health systems in Cerner's Real-World DataTM (RWD) national database; (c) integrate geocoding and linked death data to enable better estimates of structural and social determinants of health (SSDoH) factors that contribute to maternal mortality/SMM; and (d) facilitate a rapid “scale-up” to a national level, given the multi-site nature of the Greater Plains Collaborative (GPC)/PCORnet data system.

PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to identify the extent to which two forms of prosocial engagements—formal volunteering carried out under the auspices of formal organizations and informal helping provided to friends and neighbors—lead to slower cognitive decline, and also uncover evidence on whether these helping behaviors serve as a buffer against adverse effects of genetic risks for Alzheimer's disease (AD) and disadvantaged neighborhood conditions. Findings from this project are expected to provide robust evidence for the linkage between helping behaviors and delayed cognitive decline and reduced AD risk, thereby informing empirically driven intervention approaches that promise a win-win-win proposition for those who engage in the helping behaviors, the persons helped, and the society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative The high spatial-resolution and energy-resolution of cadmium telluride (CdTe) and cadmium zinc telluride (CZT), compared to that of scintillators, offers superior image quality in nuclear medicine and X-ray imaging applications. Unfortunately, the current state-of-the-art (i.e. Traveler Heater Method) for growing CdTe/CZT crystals is slow, expensive, and does not meet the demands of the current market needs. The Accelerated Crucible Rotation Technique (ACRT) has recently been applied to CdTe/CZT and has proved to be rapid-production process for growing high-performance CdTe and CZT crystals, a process that will change the current CdTe/CZT market by providing affordable, high-quality devices to stakeholders in the high-demand and growing medical imaging markets.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Regulations of stem cells and their microenvironments are altered in older age which lead to impaired damage repair and tissue regeneration in most animals examined. Here, we propose to use the cutting-edge spatial transcriptomic tools to identify changes in stem cells and their microenvironments in young and old planarians, and in the regeneration of new tissues in old planarians to facilitate our understanding of how an old planarian can regenerate a young eye. Such knowledge will help improve regenerative medicine in elderly patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Cases of and deaths from most chronic diseases are disproportionally higher in communities of color. These health disparities are linked to chronic stress and the proposed research will gather knowledge about anti- racist healing in nature as a tool for stress reduction in BIPOC young adults. The culturally-appropriate, and affirming low-cost interventions that are developed will promote telomere growth to prevent health disparities.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substance use has been declared as a public health emergency, fueled by alarmingly high relapse rate (as high as 90%). This mechanistic human study will examine whether down-regulation of enhanced preferential attention to drug-related cues to reduce craving and prolong abstinence in individuals with cocaine use disorder. Successful completion of this project will advance mechanistic research into developing attention regulation as a potential behavioral intervention for relapse prevention in substance use disorders.

PHR: NARRATIVE For many human diseases, we do not know which cell types and which genes within those cell types are at the root of the problem. Rapid advances in DNA sequencing technology now allow us to look inside individual cells from healthy tissue, but we lack algorithms and software for comparing such measurements to those from diseased tissue. This proposal aims to develop generally applicable software tools that will allow scientists to compare the regulation of genes in healthy and diseased tissue, as well as uncover fundamental mechanisms in embryonic development and other biological processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: MoTrPAC Narrative While there are many important health benefits of physical activity, how exercise exerts its effects is not fully understood. A more comprehensive understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying the responses to exercise would significantly impact public health. Continuation of the Molecular Transducers of Physical Activity Consortium (MoTrPAC) will achieve its objective of generating a comprehensive map of the molecular responses to acute exercise and exercise training with a long-range goal of elucidating the mechanisms by which exercise improves health.

PHR: Project Narrative The major goal of this grant application is to determine the molecular mechanisms by which the transcriptional co-activators YAP/TAZ control age-related skin dermal extracellular matrix (ECM) homeostasis. In this application, we will test the novel hypothesis that dermal ECM homeostasis is governed by the adaptation of fibroblasts to the state of the surrounding ECM microenvironment and that this “outside-in adaptation” is critically regulated by YAP/TAZ.

PHR: HERE! Project Narrative School-based health centers have a growing evidence-base in addressing disparities children in rural communities face across health, behavioral health, and educational outcomes. With many rural children and families being hard hit by economic downturns and the national pediatric mental health crisis, support around social determinants of health needs is a priority. The current cluster randomized crossover trial across 12 rural school-based health centers will assess the impact of rural school-based community health workers on student attendance, socieo-emotional learning and school climate, and school-based health center onsite and telehealth services utilization versus an enhanced usual care condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Discovering biological features underlying disease mechanisms is crucial to develop effective treatments and therapies, but follow-up studies verifying relationships between features and disease traits are costly. We propose a recommendation system based on the PCS framework that aims at efficient discoveries for high yields in experimentation. We will leverage this system to recommend genes and interactions for follow-up gene-silencing experiments to advance the mechanistic understanding of cardiac hypertrophy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: (3 sentences) Bayesian models that monitor serum vancomycin levels to optimize the delivery of intravenous vancomycin have limitations in achieving a patient-specific pharmacokinetic model. To overcome these limitations, we will develop deep-learning based models suited for time-sequencing data to disentangle complex relationships in big patient data from electronic health records. The success of our models will lead to optimized vancomycin usage, increased patient safety, and reduced healthcare costs through high prediction accuracy and reliability.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite its life-saving potential, lung cancer screening uptake remains extremely low in the United States,  especially among Black and low-income Americans. The goal of this proposal is to identify and pilot test the  feasibility of multilevel strategies to facilitate the equitable uptake of lung cancer screening. This research will  help address an urgent public health need to increase screening equity and help all eligible patients benefit  from a proven strategy for the early detection of lung cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People living in rural areas are more likely to have a serious injury and more like to die from that injury than their urban counterparts. This disparity can be reduced by appropriate use of air medical helicopters to quickly transport injured patients to a trauma center from rural regions, but use of this resource when others may need it, risk of crashing, and high cost make it important to use air medical transport (AMT) by helicopter appropriately. Decisions by first responders about which patients benefit from AMT are frequently inaccurate, and this research will help us identify who needs to be transported by helicopter and ultimately reduce disparities for rural patients that rely on air medical helicopters for life-saving care after injury.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  FimH and FmlH are critical adhesion proteins that enable uropathogenic E. coli (UPEC) to cause serious and often drug-resistant urinary tract infections (UTIs). Current attempts to treat UTIs must overcome unique challenges due to the complexity of UPEC pathogenesis and drug delivery limitations. The proposed research will identify long-lived D-peptides that block these adhesion proteins and serve as a potential alternative treatment for challenging UTIs.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a maternal health crisis in the United States. Although severe maternal morbidity (SMM) is largely preventable, Black birthing people are disproportionately affected by SMM and associated risk factors. The purpose of this study is to test the effectiveness of an integrated care model approach at two different levels of intensity designed to facilitate timely, appropriate care for high-risk Black birthing people and reduce risk for SMM.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The majority of patients with pancreatic cancer suffer from involuntary weight loss, fatigue, and frailty, known as cachexia. These effects of cancer limit patients' quality of life, their ability to tolerate treatment, and can contribute to mortality. Our studies investigate how pancreatic cancer changes metabolism of fat stores to cause cachexia in the hopes of developing new effective treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative MRI is an exquisitely flexible and sensitive technique, with observable signal changes due to an array of underlying neurobiological and neurodegenerative factors that occur due to cerebrovascular disease, Alzheimer's disease, and traumatic brain injury. However, multiple underlying phenomena (e.g. myelin loss, neuron death, and vascular tissue damage) can cause similar signal changes, thus reducing the specificity with which MR is able to characterize the neurobiology (e.g. of vascular lesions seen in the broad spectrum of neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s Disease and post-traumatic neurodegeneration). In this project, we will build and share acquisition and analysis tools that bridge the divide between in vivo MRI images, ex vivo tissue images, and neuropathological diagnosis allowing the development of new innovative technologies for highly specific in vivo pathology mapping with significant clinical impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT According to the CDC database, 6.5 million (10.7%) of Americans aged 65 and older are living with Alzheimer’s disease in 2022, while there are no potent medicines to prevent its onset or progression. In this project, we will test a novel pathogenesis hypothesis and two treatments that target the aggregation of hyperphosphorylated tau. Positive outcomes of this project will shed insights to the mechanisms of Alzheimer’s dementia and may suggest new treatments of this devastating disorder.

PHR: Project Narrative When screening for prostate cancer it is often unclear who should be biopsied and if there is a targetable lesion to biopsy, which are critical to the accurate diagnosis of clinically significant prostate cancer. In this proposal, we will develop a set of quantitative and non-invasive tools to help clinicians determine who should be biopsied and where to target the biopsy. These tools will utilize restricted spectrum imaging (RSI), a novel tissue microstructure imaging method, and deep learning to predict the Gleason score of prostate lesions, and incorporate clinical data including age, family history, and genetics to accurately predict current and future risk for clinically significant prostate cancer. 2

AIQ Solutions will build a dedicated AI-powered theranostics software -TRAQinform Theranostics- to provide objective and actionable information predicting and summarizing theranostic patient response to meet the currently unmet need for theranostic patient management, not addressed by any existing commercial products.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks to continue the pre-clinical development of novel MYC degraders to treat c-myc-dependent non-small cell line cancers (NSCLCs) and colorectal cancers (CRCs). We show that our MYC degraders harbor excellent drug-like properties and are effective in inhibiting the growth of c-myc-dependent NSCLC and CRC in pre-clinical models. Our MYC degraders have potential to impact the lives of millions of cancer patients in U.S. and represent a significant market opportunity.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are an estimated 11.2 million Mexicans living in the United States, making them by far the largest national origin immigrant group and 25% of all immigrants. The newest sources of large migration from Latin America are the Central American countries of El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras: from 1990 to 2015 the number of people from these three countries resident in the United States grew from 975,000 to 3.0 million. The Mesoamerican Migration Project will collect survey data in Mexico, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and the U.S. and build on the long-standing NICHD-funded Mexican Migration Project and Latin American Migration Project to provide the most comprehensive dataset for describing, tracking, and explaining current and past migration from Mexico and Central America to the U.S.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The success of programs to prevent vertical transmission of HIV has led to a growing population of HIV- exposed, uninfected (HEU) children who, despite not being infected, exhibit neurodevelopmental delays and reduced growth. In this project we will continue to follow a prospectively recruited well-characterized cohort of children without and with HIV exposure, stratified by ART exposure duration, through early childhood with multimodal MR neuroimaging and cognitive assessments around ages 6 and 8 years, examining how factors around birth impact later brain health and how the postnatal environment, including maternal health, influences neurodevelopment and school-readiness. Additionally, we will build capacity for using low-cost mobile MRI scanners to differentiate healthy and atypical neurodevelopment in low-resource settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Blood flow to the brain is very important for healthy neurological function, but it is dysregulated in patients who suffer strokes, Alzheimer’s disease and other related dementias. Here, we will examine whether strokes can initiate disease processes in astrocytes, a key brain cell that controls brain blood vessels, to cause long-lasting decrease in blood flow and contribute to dementia. Findings from this study may guide the development of novel treatment strategies to prevent or reduce dementia by restoring brain blood flow.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES

PHR: Narrative Recent years have shown that the structural dynamics of biomolecular systems is essential to biological actions and interactions in the cell, and it is critically important to identify the sites controlling the structural dynamics so as to design effective modulators of function and assess the impact of mutations. With this perspective, we aim to develop novel computational methods and tools to predict allosteric sites and essential mechanisms, assess the pathogenicity of point mutations, and assist in the design of effective intervention methods for modulating biological function and allo-targeting. These tools will be made accessible to the broader community through our widely used ProDy interface to enable effective usage and dissemination.

PHR: Social modifiers of primate lifespan Social adversity is one of the strongest predictors of individual mortality, yet the extent to which the social environment determines how long humans and other primates live, and the molecular signatures of social aging and longevity remain unclear. This project investigates whether and why some primates live longer than others, and how social factors modify lifespans and the pace of molecular aging in a well-studied genera, the macaque. This work will help place human lifespans in the evolutionary, ecological, and social contexts from which they emerge, and will identify hypotheses about how modifiable social factors could effectively be deployed to improve health and wellbeing in aging primates, including, potentially, humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an urgent, unmet public health need to improve outcomes for chronic lung diseases, which disproportionately impacts the Southeast. This program will provide research training for investigators who will ultimately improve the healthcare and outcomes for individuals with lung diseases with particular emphasis on lung cancer prevention, screening and implementation, critical care, telehealth, and rare lung diseases, including pulmonary fibrosis, sarcoidosis and cystic fibrosis. Training in innovation and entrepreneurship will enable investigators to create innovative solutions to challenges in health, to catalyze interdisciplinary entrepreneurial efforts, and ultimately become change agents to address national and global health problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Brain temperature regulation is a crucial hemodynamic parameter particularly after ischemia or brain injury. Currently, we have limited methods to measure and predict brain temperature in the clinical setting. Our goal is to develop a new method for non-invasive brain temperature monitoring, combined with a simulated model to enable brain temperature predictions, validated in healthy volunteers and patients with chronic cerebrovascular disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Future advancements in our ability to develop, license and deploy effective vaccines against infectious and non- infectious diseases depend on advanced training of scientists in the multidisciplinary, rapidly evolving field of Vaccinology. This T32 Training Program in Vaccinology provides post-doctoral fellows with training in the performance of “bench” research and/or clinical studies and the analytical skills required to critically posit, evaluate, and advance focused and relevant scientific questions within the broad field of Vaccinology. Towards this goal, talented trainees receive exceptional academic support, research guidance, and mentoring from our dedicated faculty, as evidenced by the scientific and career successes of our prior trainees in the last two decades of this grant.

PHR: Narrative Despite major advances in melanoma therapy, a major fraction of patients with advanced disease fail to respond adequately to therapy. This Program Project brings together highly collaborative studies focusing upon specific mechanisms underlying disease formation/progression and success or failure of these therapies, utilizing a collection of genetically defined preclinical animal models, and highly annotated melanoma patient biopsies. The Projects highlight key druggable pathways whose modulation profoundly alters the tumor microenvironment, rigorously assessing their mechanistic detail in stringent animal models, in advance of translating these opportunities into clinical trials.

PHR: Narrative Project 1 examines the role of DDI2 as regulator of a pathway that suppresses levels of MHC- antigen presentation complexes at the tumor surface, thereby promoting immune evasion. Because DDI2 is transcriptionally targeted by the melanoma oncoprotein MITF, we will test the hypothesis that the MITF-DDI2 axis represents a novel oncogenic immune modulation mechanism. We will also scrutinize the antigenic repertoire regulated by DDI2 via immunopeptidomics to test the hypothesis that pharmacologic DDI2 suppression would stimulate both quantity and diversity of presented antigens by melanoma cells.

We also have developed cellular barcoding methods to examine the clones of cancers cells that are most hurting the patient at a particular time. The ability to examine the spatial signals and clones will potentially lead to new therapies.

PHR: Narrative This project focuses on a novel epigenetic target for immunotherapy of melanoma, the CARM1 enzyme. We will investigate how inhibition of this enzyme enhances the function of dendritic cells and T cells in the immune response against melanoma.

PHR: Narrative Zinc dyshomeostasis is implicated in the elderly population and Alzheimer’s disease (AD). ApoE4 is the strongest genetic risk factor in AD, and Zinc-APOE4 interaction and resulted toxicity in the central nervous system (CNS) is unclear. New information obtained from this study may lead to novel strategies for targeting zinc dyshomeostasis and its interaction with APOE4 as potential treatment of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite scientific advances in combating deadly infectious diseases and successes in treatment in developed countries, the world-wide death toll continues to rise because new diseases continue to emerge, drug resistance is increasing, and there are no effective vaccines for some of the deadliest diseases. To address these challenges, the Graduate Program in Tropical Infectious Diseases (GPiTID) is embedded in a school of public health but focuses on fundamental scientific discovery using cutting edge approaches of genomics, cell biology, immunology, population biology and gene editing, coupled with epidemiology of the diseases in their natural setting, to address major infections that pose a threat to public health both in the US and abroad. There is a focus on fundamental scientific training but in the context of the diseases as holistic problems and with an emphasis on fundamental discoveries that could lead to new interventions including drug, vaccine, and insecticide development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our understanding of the neural basis of human cognitive abilities has been limited by opportunities and methods to record from populations of single neurons in the human prefrontal cortex. This work leverages recent advances in neurotechnology and opportunities to record from awake humans to study how populations of neurons in prefrontal cortex mediate human cognitive function. Using a unique neural probe that can record hundreds of neurons from a single shank, we will study executive function during awake deep brain stimulation surgeries.

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative In response of RFA-AG-24-018, we propose to develop a biologically relevant multi-scale model of brain aging using advanced yet clinically feasible diffusion MRI, which holds enormous untapped potential to bridge the meso-macro gap and disentangle the extent of neuro-inflammation and neurodegeneration in aging and the onset of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and AD related dementias (ADRD). We will create in vivo brain charts of quantitative diffusion MRI and white matter microstructure markers across the life-span, in order to create a novel brain aging framework and validate it using histopathology and proteomics on postmortem brain samples, as well as by longitudinal follow-up MRI and comparison against conventional structural MRI. This brain microstructure age framework will provide meaningful insight into the microstructural processes underlying brain aging and AD/ADRD and enable quantitative assessment of treatment response to future symptomatic and disease-modifying therapies.

PHR: Project Narrative Disorders causing cognitive impairments have devastating effects on our daily lives, including severe problems in forming new and retrieving exiting memories. Multiple distinct learning systems store our different kinds of memories, like skills or directions, but remarkably, these systems are not independent and can interact in both beneficial and disruptive ways. Our research aims to use such learning interactions as an opportunity to understand the cognitive processes that coordinate the different learning systems and to thereby reveal how cognitive impairments can broadly disrupt learning and memory even without affecting the learning system themselves.

PHR: Narrative  The roles of circular RNAs in sepsis-associated systemic inflammation, inflammatory lung responses, and end- organ damage, such as lung injury, remain largely unclear, particularly in the elderly. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERALL The UK CTSA program hub is uniquely positioned in the National CTSA Consortium to foster novel technologies, team science, clinical trial start-up and cutting-edge translational research across the lifespan. Our UK CTSA hub has a significant presence on the national stage, and our focus on the Central Appalachian community, a rural region with many of the highest priorities (i.e., cardiovascular, neuroscience, cancer, obesity/diabetes) of health disparities in the nation and an epicenter for the opioid and substance abuse epidemic, distinguishes our mission and activities. The programs in this proposal will ultimately elevate the health and quality of life for people of this region and provide a national model for rural, underserved populations. ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Senescent cells are typically harmful in many tissues due to their secretion of inflammatory factors in the local microenvironment, however, the specific impact of senescent neurons on brain aging and dementia remains unknown. This study utilizes laboratory experiments to generate multi-omic datasets from the human brain and employs customized deep learning techniques for analyzing spatial omics data. The aim is to identify the precise effects of senescent neurons on their microenvironments and use mouse models to evaluate potential molecular regulators and treatments that could alleviate these detrimental effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Oral mucosal immune-related adverse events secondary to anti-PD-1 can cause serious morbidity and pain; here, we seek to understand the pathogenesis of these oral mucosal adverse events. Here we propose an innovative plan incorporating interrogation of human specimens, generation and analysis of novel mouse models, and validation using patient-derived organoid cultures. This work is highly relevant to cancer patients' oral health given the increasing use of immune stimulating systemic agents and the significant morbidity of these oral mucosal side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Fungi are a vast and biologically diverse group of organisms that affect all of our lives in myriad ways. Fungi are important causes of human and crop diseases, affecting literally billions of lives each year. Most of these devastating effects occur through the loss of life of infected and immunocompromised patients, as well as loss of crop yield throughout the world. Additionally, fungi are also important scientific models to better understand basic physiology of more complex organisms, such as humans. In this program, we are training the next generation of scientists to explore fungi in many areas of biological investigation, both as infectious agents as well as model systems to understand genetic disorders and evolution and plant-fungal symbiotic interactions.

PROJECT_TITLE: Tri-Institutional Molecular Mycology and Pathogenesis Training Program
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Microbiology and Infectious Diseases B Research Study Section[MID-B]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sleep health is essential for well-being, yet significant disparities exist for young children (2-5 years old) who are racially minoritized or living in poverty. The objective of this research is to define disparities in early sleep health by examining how socio-cultural, neighborhood, and family risk factors predict conditions in children's sleeping environment and sleep health. This study will provide a critical next step in reducing disparities in early childhood sleep health and its downstream effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Traumatic brain injury (TBI) across the lifespan has been shown to progress towards Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and related dementias (ADRD); however, what is missing is a well characterized TBI rodent model that recapitulates ADRD features (cognitive decline, atrophy, inflammation, amyloid-β, etc.). This project will utilize a rodent closed head injury model to assess age of injury and AD risk alleles across the lifespan using clinically relevant outcome measures to deeply characterize how TBI leads to ADRD symptomology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: OVERALL PROJECT NARRATIVE Research in the Davis Center is uniquely focused on using diverse animal models to define the cellular and molecular mechanisms of tissue regeneration and aging, and on translating that information into new regenerative medicine therapies and improvements to healthspan. This Phase III COBRE proposal will transition state of the art core facilities at MDIBL in comparative animal models, bioinformatics and data science, and light microscopy to self-sustainability and support a pilot project program in aging and regenerative biology which will enable MDIBL investigators, visiting scientists, pilot project awardees, and MDIBL course participants to build highly competitive research programs. Core support will consolidate the progress made after hiring, promoting, and retaining successful COBRE investigators in the MDIBL Davis Center and building this Center into a leading research institute in Comparative Biology.
