PHR: Drug delivery to brain tumors is hindered by the so-called “blood-tumor barrier”. It has been shown previously that this barrier to effective drug delivery may be overcome by injecting microbubbles into the bloodstream and then activating them with focused acoustic energy (i.e. focused ultrasound) as they pass through the tumor. In this project, we aim to further improve and refine this drug delivery approach by pre-treating brain tumors with pharmacological strategies that “normalize” tumor blood vessel structure and function so that they better synergize with focused ultrasound.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is increasing recognition that traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a risk factor for progressive neurodegeneration. In order to study how TBI can induce long-term and evolving pathological processes, we propose to develop novel preclinical models of TBI that replicate both the brain pathologies and progressive cognitive deficits seen in some TBI patients. Generating relevant and validated models will be critical for advancing our understanding of TBI-related neurodegeneration and developing novel therapeutic interventions.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The oligomeric forms of Aβ40 and Aβ42 are considered as the primary toxic agents in the etiology of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). Thus, determining the conditions that promote Ab aggregation in the brain is crucial to understanding the pathogenesis of AD and identifying new therapeutic targets. We will use novel approaches in multiscale modeling, high resolution microscopy, antibody staining, and measurement of paralysis phenotype to determine the role of the drastic physiochemical changes and metabolic stress associated with pathological states such as stroke, traumatic brain injury, and migraine in the onset and progression of Aβ40 and Aβ42 aggregation in the brain.

PHR: This T32 application describes a comprehensive recruitment, training and retention program that combines a strong basic science curriculum with a strong translational cancer focus that distinguishes it from other training programs. Our goals are to train top-quality scientists capable of conducting independent cancer research; foster the intellectual, technical and communication skills required to succeed in the academic or industrial arenas of today and in the future; and to provide an understanding of the basic, public health, and clinical problems of human cancer. The Cancer Center Director of our NCI Designated Comprehensive Cancer Center provides substantial financial support for education and training.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Research using the amphibian Xenopus, because of unique advantages as an experimental system, has revealed key insights in many domains of biomedical research, including cell biology, development, neurobiology, physiology and signal transduction. This proposal seeks to generate and characterize different Xenopus mutants in key genes related to human diseases using new technology, which will help provide significant insights about the causes of these diseases.

PHR: Project Narrative Furthering the ongoing fight against cancer requires scientists who can communicate across traditionally distinct research disciplines such as epidemiology, biostatistics, genetics, -omics, and environmental health— while ensuring that advances are undertaken in an appropriate manner toward reducing disparities. The proposed T32 program will fulfill this need by providing exceptional training to prepare predoctoral students in the integration of innovative methods and cancer research questions in a cross-cutting transdisciplinary and translational manner. Graduates of the program will have the expertise to work in multidisciplinary teams and be tomorrow’s cancer research leaders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Unfortunately, survival following lung transplantation is the worst amongst solid organs with only 80% and 50% of patients alive at 1 and 5 years, respectively. Acute and chronic rejection, known as primary graft dysfunction (PGD) and chronic lung allograft rejection (CLAD) are the major drivers of these poor outcomes. The PPG investigators seek to identify common mechanisms that cause PGD and CLAD in mouse models and in patients with a goal of identifying new treatments that will improve survival for lung transplant recipients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narra$ve We propose to use a “Team-Science”-based two-phase approach towards the development of a robust murine model of TBI-induced ADRD phenotype. In Phase 1, we will examine and screen for mouse strain determinants and TBI injury types that might favor post TBI-ADRD formation and progression. In Phase 2, using the selected mouse strain/injury model candidate, we will introduce and evaluate two TBI-ADRD model enrichment factors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE By supporting diverse neuroscientists at multiple career stages, the Neuroscience Scholars Program (NSP) fosters and grows a diverse neuroscience workforce that will efficiently address a breadth of difficult research questions and adopt approaches that may not be envisioned by groups with more homogeneous backgrounds and training. Such a diverse, well-trained neuroscience workforce is instrumental to making new discoveries about how the brain works and to finding innovative ways to prevent and treat neurological illnesses and disorders that account for a greater burden than any other group of diseases (Kaji, 2019). Diversity in the neuroscience workforce also ensures that research discoveries apply to a broader spectrum of the U.S. population; involving researchers from underrepresented groups increases attention to and research on health disparities and otherwise-neglected issues specific to women’s health and those of diverse populations (Ovbiagele, 2023).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Coronary artery disease is the most common type of heart disease (1 in 20 people age 20 or older have CAD) and is the leading cause of mortality in the US. LadeRx is developing a chelated manganese-based contrast agent which will enable quantitative myocardial perfusion imaging with concomitant high-resolution anatomical data in a single MRI exam. This will substantially improve the management of patients with coronary artery disease, particularly patients with multivessel disease and patients with renal-impairment.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant for public health because the expected outcome of the proposed experiments is a full-scale spiking neural network model that will help explore the mechanisms of brain aging on the storage and retrieval of memories. Innovative experiments will investigate the contribution of fast temporal dynamics of the neurotransmitter acetylcholine on modulating encoding and retrieval states and their changes during aging in live behaving subjects. The project is relevant to NIA’s mission because the expected results will contribute to our mechanistic understanding of how age-related changes in cholinergic modulation can result in maladaptive network activity and ultimately age-related decline in memory.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Currently, research curricula and mentorship specific to Sexual and Reproductive Health, Rights and Justice (SRHRJ) topics, and Community-Engaged Research (CER) methods are lacking in consistency and accessibility across academic institutions, disciplines, and training levels. The University of Utah-based ASCENT Center for Reproductive Health is poised to address this through the creation of the ASCENT Research Training Program SRHRJ open to scholars nationwide from upper undergraduates to professional level. Ultimately, this program and resulting toolkit will increase accessibility to advanced CER techniques, enhance the training experience, and support professional and career development for a new generation of diverse SRHRJ scholars.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A hallmark of human intellect is our ability to flexibly manipulate information in working memory and for language to apply meaning to it, however the neuronal mechanisms supporting this uniquely human neural entanglement remain poorly understood from cellular to systems levels. The proposed interdisciplinary team will pursue a transformative understanding of working memory and language interactions by leveraging high-density laminar array recordings in neurosurgery patients during their operating room treatment procedures—allowing access to single units and local-field potentials distributed across cortical layers—complemented by unprecedented single-cell genomic and spatial transcriptomic insights from tissue samples after task performance and the array recordings. High-resolution laminar fMRI will be pre-operatively obtained in the same patients and with the same task to allow investigating system-wide interactions, and the combined datasets will be integrated across scales with a next-generation biophysical model to advance mechanistic understanding of human laminar circuit motifs and how working memory and language interact to organize and give meaning to our inner thoughts.

PHR: OVERALL PROJECT NARRATIVE Yale Cancer Center (YCC) is committed to eliminating the burden of cancer through transformative research, with attention to the needs of all people facing this disease. Our goal is to understand and prevent cancer, detect cancer early, and manage cancer more effectively, while maximizing access to care, addressing the needs of the community, ensuring equity and diversity in our workplace, and training future cancer researchers, clinicians, and leaders.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative (Overall) Rats are instrumental for the understanding of human disease and they play an important role in the development of drugs and therapeutics. The Rat Resource and Research Center provides a unique centralized repository for importing, storing and distributing a large number of rat strains, embryonic stem cells and related reagents. The RRRC also provides critical services to assist biomedical researchers and performs innovative research to ensure the quality, reproducibility and availability of rat models.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH

ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chimeric antigen receptor T-cell therapy (CAR T) is revolutionizing the treatment of relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma (RRMM) and offering new hope to a growing population living with incurable cancer; however, survivorship outcomes for patients treated in standard of care settings remain unknown. This study will establish a first-in-kind resource of highly characterized and diverse RRMM patients treated with standard of care CAR T, with systematic assessments of patient-reported outcomes and biospecimen samples, to identify psychosocial and immune-related factors associated with key survivorship outcomes. Findings from this study will have direct implications for developing and implementing patient education materials, clinical decision-making tools, and supportive care interventions to improve RRMM survivorship outcomes after CAR T.

PHR: Narrative The Emory VTP-T32 addresses the urgent need for training the next generation of vaccinologists. However, to achieve the full potential of vaccines and address difficulties that have hindered progress, a new generation of well-prepared scientists continues to be needed.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed studies aim to develop squirrel monkeys, rhesus monkeys, baboons, and chimpanzees as a well-defined immunological model to target immunosenescence. We plan to investigate the relationship between immunosenescence and both neurodegeneration and cognition across these species with differing lifespans. The differences within and between species may elucidate differences within human populations and can lead to the development of interventions aimed toward improving longevity.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Research investigation in population science is essential to ensure that discoveries from molecular medicine and clinical trials translate to routine practice and ultimately decrease the population-level burden of cancer. The Dana-Farber Harvard Cancer Center’s (DF/HCC) T32 Training in Oncology Population Sciences (TOPS) program equips postdoctoral fellows with the skills necessary to evaluate cancer care quality and effectiveness, and to develop, test and implement interventions to improve care delivery thereby ensuring that T1/T2 discoveries translate across the T3/T4 bridge to achieve maximal impact on population health. Postdoctoral fellows pursue a two-year program of mentored research, coursework and professional skills training that supports innovation and leverages the expertise of DF/HCC faculty to prepare them for independent investigation in cancer-focused population science.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training in Oncology Population Sciences (TOPS)

PHR: Narrative Alzheimer's Disease (AD) and AD related disorders (ADRD) are progressive neurologic disorders primarily affecting the elderly. Damaging more than just the skin, burn injuries can lead to excessive inflammation that often involves multiple organs systems including leakiness of the protective barriers of the gut and the brain, leading to aberrant cognitive function including delirium and dementia, which may parallel the changes seen in AD/ADRD. By investigating age-related mechanisms responsible for early damage to the gut and blood brain barriers after burn injury, we hope to identify novel strategies to reduce the impact of this post-injury neuroinflammation and mental decline seen in elderly subjects suffering from a wide range of diseases, including AD/ADRD.

PHR: Narrative Given the large number of “big data” initiatives (i.e., “-omics studies) in the Alzheimer’s disease research space and their potential transformative power, we propose a new pre- and post-doctoral training program designed to bridge gaps between “big data” science and more focused hypothesis-driven biological studies that establish causal relationships. This training grant will prepare a next generation of scientists to move the field forward by leveraging both big data initiatives and more fundamental scientific approaches.
PROJECT_TERMS: Alzheimer's Disease;Big Data;Biology;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Alzheimer's Disease Big Data to Biology Training Program (ADBDB-TP)
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Career Development for Established Investigators and Conference Grants Study Section[AGCD-4]

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early detection of Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementia (AD/ADRD) makes it possible for initiation of early intervention, its assessment (preventive clinical trials) to slow down the progression, even prevent the onset and reduce care costs. Leveraging unique AD/ADRD resources in Arizona including the Arizona Alzheimer’s Consortium (AAC) and Mirabella - a senior living community on the Arizona State University campus, we propose to train pre-doctoral researchers with an Artificial Intelligence (AI) mindset when attacking long-standing challenges in AD/ADRD research including clinical science, diagnostics and engineering, disease biology, data science, and drug discovery/development. This novel integration provides the opportunity not only for intergenerational education but also for community defined field research projects in the training program.
PROJECT_TERMS: Alzheimer's Disease;Communities;intergenerational;Research;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Intergenerational Community Driven Training in Alzheimer's Disease Research: An AI+X Approach
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Career Development for Established Investigators and Conference Grants Study Section[AGCD-4]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL COMPONENT – PROJECT NARRATIVE  This is a revised application for a Program Project Grant seeking to provide support for a coordinated, multi- disciplinary investigation of the molecular mechanisms that underly clinically relevant immune-mediated thrombocytopenic disorders that are of importance to clinicians, scientists, and patients alike. The central unifying theme of our application is to develop a deep understanding of a wide range of immunological insults that lead to thrombocytopenia and downstream sequelae in the fetus, newborn, and adults. The Program takes place at the Versiti Blood Research Institute of Versiti's Blood Center of Wisconsin - a nationally renowned facility strictly focused on and devoted to all aspects of blood-related research, including transfusion medicine, hematology, and immunobiology, and within the Pediatric Hematology Division of Children's Hospital of Philadelphia - an elite scientific research institution located on a premier academic medical campus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Platelets circulate in the bloodstream and, when they encounter a damaged blood vessel, become activated and stick together to help to plug up the damaged area and stop bleeding; excessive bleeding occurs when platelet counts are too low, which is a condition referred to as thrombocytopenia. This application represents a unique application of hematology and immunology expertise required to tackle unresolved problems in the immunologic bleeding disorder Fetal/Neonatal Alloimmune Thrombocytopenia (FNAIT), which is a non- malignant hematologic disease that arises when the immune system of a pregnant woman makes antibodies that clear a baby's platelets before or immediately after birth. We are especially interested in determining why FNAIT develops in some at-risk pregnancies, but not others, and why some babies with FNAIT experience excessive bleeding in the brain, referred to as intracranial hemorrhage, which can result in irreversible brain damage and death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) is an adverse immune reaction resulting from antibodies targeting platelet factor 4 (PF4) bound to heparin, causing morbidity and mortality in patients undergoing heparin treatment. This research characterizes the interactions between HIT antibodies and PF4/heparin complexes, as well as identifies gut microbiota species associated with the generation of HIT antibodies. These findings will offer new insights into the pathogenesis of HIT, impacting its diagnosis, prevention, and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Vaccine-induced immune thrombotic thrombocytopenia (VITT) is a rare, life-threatening clotting complication of the Johnson & Johnson and AstraZeneca vaccines for COVID-19. How VITT causes clotting that can lead to death even with modern day treatments is not known. We have discovered new proteins called chemokines that may be important in causing the clotting and believe that our studies may help find new medicines to treat VITT and other situations where people clot too much.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it proposes a new methodological approach to studying and controlling zoonotic diseases, which represent a substantial threat to public health. A validated method for measuring and modeling human-livestock contact networks is expected to have positive impact as no empirically-derived human-animal network models exist, compelling zoonotic disease modelers to make oversimplifications which limit the validity of their findings. This project is relevant to NIAID’s mission to better understand and ultimately prevent infectious diseases because it is expected to open new horizons for targeting interventions and surveillance at the human-animal interface, optimizing cost effectiveness and facilitating more timely response before substantial human-to-human transmission has occurred.

PHR: Project Narrative Respiratory disease represents a major health care problem. Indeed, influenza and pneumonia, as well as chronic respiratory (lung) diseases, are among the top ten leading causes of death in the U.S. population. The purpose of our pulmonary research training program is to develop new leaders and innovators to drive research and development in the field of lung biology and disease and thereby solve this problem.

PHR: Project 1 Narrative T cell malignancies represent a class of hematologic cancers with high rates of relapse and mortality in both children and adults for which there are currently no effective or targeted therapies. We have developed a fratricide-resistant “off-the-shelf” chimeric antigen receptor T cell that targets CD7+ T cell malignancies (UCART7) and, through CRISPR/Cas9 gene editing, lacks both CD7 and T cell receptor alpha chain expression thereby preventing graft-versus-host disease when infused into allogeneic recipients. We propose to test UCART7 in patients with relapse or refractory T-cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (T-ALL) and use preclinical mouse models to determine if UCART therapy can be improved using cytokines (IL-7 and IL-15), dual phosphoinositide 3-kinase delta/gamma inhibitors (duvelisib) and/or dual-targeted UCART.

PHR: Our research will test a new cellular immunotherapy, called memory-like natural killer cells, in a clinical trial for patients with acute myeloid leukemia who have relapsed after allogeneic hematopoietic cell (bone marrow) transplantation. Additional goals of this research are to identify correlates of leukemia response or resistance to this new treatment, impact on other components of the immune system, and to test new approaches to optimize the response and recognition of AML by memory-like NK cells. We also expect that this research will lead to new combination immunotherapy treatments for patients with leukemia in the future.

PHR: We and others discovered that RNA splicing factors are mutated in the blood cells of many patients with myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML), leading to the formation of DNA:RNA hybrids in cells (i.e., R loops) and activation of ATR and PARP1 DNA damage response pathways. Inhibition of ATR or PARP cause splicing factor mutant cells to die and the combination is synergistic. This project will optimize the combination of ATR and PARP1 inhibition in preclinical models, providing the rationale for an investigator-initiated clinical trial.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The prognosis for patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) or myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) carrying TP53 mutations is dismal and there is an urgent need for better therapies. We have generated preclinical data suggesting that TP53-mutated AML/MDS is selectively vulnerable to the combination of decitabine and an ATR inhibitor. Here, we will conduct and phase I clinical trial of this novel combination therapy in patients withTP53- mutated AML/MDS.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Ferroptosis is a form of regulated cell death that is characterized by the accumulation of lipid peroxides, leading to oxidative damage, plasma membrane disruption, and cell death. Ferroptosis is partly mediated by the amino acid transporter, system xc-, owing to the critical role of system xc- in regulating cellular antioxidant defenses and redox balance. This proposal will test the hypothesis that [18F]hGTS13, a system xc- specific radiotracer, can inform on the sensitivity of different cancers to ferroptosis and monitor pharmacological induction of ferroptosis, additionally, we will translate [18F]hGTS13 for first-in-human investigation.

PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer's disease and Alzheimer's disease related dementias (AD/ADRD) are heterogeneous diseases whose causes and progression depend on the interactions of many factors, including trans-neuronal transmission of “prion-like” proteins, such as tau and α-synuclein, and regional gene expression. Here we use powerful mathematical modeling and a combination of in vitro and in vivo approaches to jointly evaluate how these two mechanisms interact as well as identify key genes that serve as important mediators of the transmission process.

PHR: OVERALL: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall goal of this renewal P01 proposal is to identify imaging and genomic signatures of brain tumor heterogeneity and evolution to optimize patient management of the two most common primary brain tumors in adults: glioblastoma and meningioma. This will be achieved by integrating multi-parametric imaging strategies assessing spatial and temporal changes in individual patients during the course of their disease along with genomic properties of the tumor. We will ascertain non-invasive imaging markers that reflect the underlying biological mechanisms driving glioblastoma evolution and mengingioma molecular differentiation to improve patient care through informing new therapeutic targets and ways to monitor early response.

PHR: PROJECT 1: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intratumor heterogeneity underlies treatment failure in glioblastoma and is poorly understood because only a tiny fraction of the tumor is available usually. Our multi-disciplinary team will use imaging-based whole tumor sampling with genomics to delineate the roots of glioblastoma for each patient, fostering the development of better models and new therapies. The project will enable new therapeutic strategies aimed at an untapped source of therapeutic targets that could avoid the major source of failures, broadly increasing the probability of clinical impact.

PHR: PROJECT 2: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The goal of this project is to understand mechanisms driving meningioma evolution and heterogeneity to (1) identify drivers underlying meningioma biomarker performance to optimize risk stratification, (2) define magnetic resonance imaging features of meningioma biomarkers to establish a foundation for non-invasive risk stratification, and (3) inform future therapies to improve the care of patients with meningiomas. Meningiomas are the most common primary intracranial tumors, but limited understanding of meningioma biology and the misconception that meningiomas are benign has encumbered medical and scientific advances for patients with meningiomas. To address these limitations, we will use prospective regionally distinct meningioma samples (Aim 1), retrospective patient-matched meningioma samples over time (Aim 2), and an organoid model of meningioma tumorigenesis integrated with a novel functional genomic technique that links genetic and therapeutic perturbations to genomic phenotypes in single cells (Aim 3) to define mechanisms driving meningioma evolution and heterogeneity.

PHR: IMAGING TUMOR HETEROGENEITY & METABOLISM CORE: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Imaging Tumor Heterogeneity & Metabolism Core provides Projects of the P01 with the high degree of research and clinical imaging support by applying advanced imaging methods and novel data analysis procedures to facilitate the collection of image-guided tissue samples during surgical resection and providing metabolic and physiologic imaging correlates of gene expression that describe intra- and inter- tumor heterogeneity. Core functions will include the development of new methods and the translation and maintenance of technologies developed in the Projects from the prior and upcoming cycles into the clinic, creating the required framework to acquire, analyze, visualize, and interpret relationships between advanced metabolic and physiologic imaging features and underlying genomic drivers of intra- and inter-patient heterogeneity from spatially mapped tissue samples.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Treatment of the frequent indications for anticoagulation among adults with epilepsy is complicated by theoretical pharmacokinetics, as well as in vitro and animal data, that support interactions between widely-used enzyme- inducing antiepileptic drugs (EI-AEDs) and direct-acting oral anticoagulants (DOACs), which would be expected to lead to a reduction in the therapeutic effectiveness of DOACs and an elevated risk of thromboembolic events. However, this may not translate to real-world changes in thromboembolic event risk upon co-prescription of these drugs, and there is scant research on EI-AED/DOAC interactions in humans, with the small number of available studies having highly inconsistent findings, major methodological limitations that impede interpretability, and an overall lack of consideration of the potential role of higher-order drug interactions. Leveraging large-scale administrative claims data to evaluate a nationally representative population of adults with epilepsy in the real- world setting, the proposed research will assess the associations between thromboembolic events and EI-AED/DOAC interactions, as well as the contributions of concomitant medications via three-way drug interactions, in order: to provide vital foundations for prescribing decisions in the substantial proportion of epilepsy patients that require anticoagulation; to report observed three-way drug interactions signals associated with EI-AEDs and DOACs to drive further investigations; and, to advance potential approaches for higher-order drug interaction screenings using real-world data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE SLC25A4 deficiency is an inherited disorder that manifests as a progressive skeletal myopathy and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy; there are no effective systemic therapies for affected patients. Preliminary data from our laboratory demonstrate that recombinant AAV vectors with specific tropism for skeletal muscle cells and cardiomyocytes can be synthesized. Here, we investigate the efficacy of myotropic AAV-mediated gene replacement as a therapeutic option for SLC25A4 deficiency.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Proteoforms, the diverse molecular entities that comprise a protein, can have myriad biological functions and roles in disease. The most powerful method for proteoform measurement is mass spectrometry, but proteoform measurement using this instrument tends to be slow and difficult. We aim to develop technologies to enable rapid and simpler proteoform measurement by mass spectrometry for the purpose of enabling more biomedical research into proteoform function in biology and human disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will investigate a novel method of reducing the impact of implicit bias on therapeutic relationships, healthcare delivery, and consequent patient health outcomes. This could have a revolutionary impact on reducing bias in healthcare delivery and resulting health disparities nationwide. This project directly responds to recommendations from several institutes and research groups who have identified reduction of implicit bias in healthcare and resulting health disparities as a matter of extreme importance and urgency, including the National Institute of Health (NIH), the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ), and the Center for Disease Control (CDC).

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parkinson’s Disease and melanoma are two diseases of aging that show a positive epidemiological association. Both characterized by genomic instability, the role of alpha-synuclein in nucleolar DNA double-strand break repair could hold a molecular connection between these two diseases. This proposal aims to determine the role of alpha-synuclein in nucleolar DNA double-strand break repair and melanoma growth and metastasis through cellular senescence modulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Biomedical scientists use descriptions of biomedical concepts (and of the relationships among concepts) known as ontologies to standardize how researchers and clinicians talk about biomedical phenomena. There are hundreds of such ontologies covering different areas of biomedicine, and finding, accessing, and putting ontologies to use can be extremely challenging. BioPortal provides a knowledgebase that integrates more than 800 biomedical ontologies, making it easy for scientists and clinicians to use the resulting knowledge to describe their data, to access information more reliably, to build other knowledge resources in standardized ways, and to bring biomedical knowledge both to the laboratory and to the point of care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease (CVD) remains the leading cause of death in the United States, with atherosclerosis being a major cause of CVD. Our research is designed to study FFAR4, a novel protein that protects against lipid accumulation in macrophages (or foam cell formation), the hallmark of atherosclerosis. The outcomes of these proposed studies will uncover the underlying mechanisms that drive FFAR4’s cardio-protective properties, and may ultimately identify FFAR4 as a novel therapeutic target for atherosclerosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Invading extravillous trophoblasts (EVTs) are specialized cells of the placenta that directly contact maternal decidual immune cells and play a critical role in vascular remodeling at the onset of pregnancy. These cells expressed an enigmatic molecule called HLA-F; our study is designed to provide a better understanding of HLA-F molecules and their interactions with receptors on decidual natural killer cells. Given that inadequate tolerance of EVTs by decidual immune cells can lead to miscarriages and other pregnancy disorders, the results of our study on HLA-F have implications for our understanding of these pathologies and treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Respiratory viruses cause strong activation of sensory C-fibers, which in turn causes sneezing, coughing, and secretions. It is also likely that the activation of C-fibers contributes to reflex bronchoconstriction in children with asthma and the exacerbation of their disease. Since little is known about the mechanisms by which respiratory viruses lead to C-fiber activation, we will address the hypothesis that, with regard to coronaviruses, activation is partially mediated by direct interaction between the viral spike proteins and C-fiber terminals in the airway mucosa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposed study addresses aligns with NIMHD’s Research’s Strategic Plan, which highlights the crucial need to take life course and multi-level approaches to advance the science of minority health disparities through dissemination and implementation of novel scientific and community-driven approaches. Social determinants of health contribute to the disparate impact of migration-related trauma and suicide on Latina immigrants, and this innovative study will further inform our understanding of cultural resilience by exploring salient communal and cultural factors that have been less explored in this population. With an enhanced understanding of how migration-related trauma influences mental health symptom severity and risk of suicide in the context of salient cultural and communal resources, we will be better positioned to develop targeted trauma-informed, suicide- prevention interventions to promote health equity and the psychological wellbeing of Latina immigrants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human induced pluripotent stem cells (hiPSCs) have tremendous potential in the development of preclinical heart models but are limited in their clinical relevance due to low, inconsistent, and heterogeneous cardiomyocyte (CM) yield after differentiation. The proposed work will investigate how different hiPSC clonal lineages respond to differentiation cues, characterize lineages based on affinity for becoming CMs, and target low-affinity lineages with additional differentiation cues to increase quantity, consistency, and homogeneity of CM yield. This will elucidate mechanisms affecting hiPSC cardiac differentiation and generate methods for producing hiPSC- derived CMs on a clinically relevant scale.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Chromatin regulators are disproportionately mutated in individuals with neurodevelopmental disorders. Dot1L, a methyltransferase, is one such protein in which patients with monoallelic de novo mutations solely in Dot1L have deficits such as global developmental delay. This proposal aims to examine Dot1L’s contribution to transcriptional regulation in the brain and Dot1L’s impact on neuronal function and behavior with hopes to provide insights into a broader understanding of chromatin regulators role in brain function and neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Black people with disabilities disproportionately experience poor physical and behavioral health outcomes due to compounding socioeconomic challenges and stigma-related stressors. Intersectionality theory suggests that such magnified health inequities may be in part driven by experiences shaped by both racism and ableism, though few quantitative measures exist to capture this dynamic, multifaceted construct as it fluctuates over time and across contexts. To address this empirical gap, the proposed project will develop and validate a brief self-report measure of daily intersectional stigma experiences for Black people with disabilities via a three- phase, multimethod approach, with the goal of facilitating future observational and intervention research geared towards addressing the deleterious impact of intersectional stigma on this multiply marginalized population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because cell division is a fundamental process of broad importance, yet the mechanisms underlying how cells grow and elongate in highly confining microenvironments for cell division are unclear. Therefore, the proposed research on understanding of the force-based mechanisms of cell division in highly confining microenvironments, via combined experimental and computational approaches, is relevant to part of NIH’s mission that seeks to develop fundamental knowledge that will help reduce the burdens of human disability and disease. Ultimately, it is anticipated that this study will uncover new insights and provide a new perspective on cell division, which will contribute to our understanding of processes in development, homeostasis, regeneration, and disease, and will also potentially lead to new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitral regurgitation is the backward leakage of blood towards the lungs when the heart contracts, often as a consequence of heart attacks or degeneration of the mitral valve tissue. Current surgical repair techniques for mitral regurgitation have alarmingly high rates of long-term regurgitation recurrence, and clinical trials studying transcatheter edge-to-edge repair have reported highly contradictory outcomes, largely due to the widespread variation in patients' preoperative clinical characteristics. Our objective is to understand how the mitral regurgitation disease process and transcatheter repair alter the mitral valve's geometry and function, and to preoperatively simulate transcatheter repair directly on a 3D model of the patient's mitral valve to predict long-term recurrence and select the best method of repair to improve the patient's long-term outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pneumonia is a major cause of death worldwide and involves widely varying responses in the lung that are postulated to cluster into distinct sub-phenotypes. Different sub-phenotypes would be responsive to different host-directed treatments, making elucidating and characterizing lung pathobiology variations a major research priority. This F32 will provide training in lung pathobiology and help define pulmonary underpinnings of pneumonia sub-phenotypes, which will aid in the development and proper utilization of host-directed pneumonia treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Menkes disease is a rare genetic condition that disrupts copper in the body and prominently affects the brain, with neurodegeneration and other neurological symptoms appearing soon after birth. Copper plays a role not only in Menkes but in a number of neurological conditions including Parkinson’s and ALS, consistent with the high energy demands of the nervous system and the crucial role of copper in mitochondrial function. The proposed research will clarify the metabolic pathways responsive to copper and their effects on neuronal function. The application of this knowledge will inform our understanding, research, and treatment of neuropathology of diseases known to be associated with dysregulated metals and/or metabolism for which there are currently limited therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This multi-method project aims to better understand behavioral health disparities among racial/ethnic minority and women post-9/11 veterans, who make up a growing proportion of the veteran population but for which few theoretically informed, longitudinal studies exist. Using qualitative interviews, repeated longitudinal assessments, and innovative machine learning methods, we will test a comprehensive model of individual and environmental factors contributing to disparities in alcohol use, attitudes towards care, and actual care receipt among a large and diverse sample of post-9/11 veterans recruited outside of VA settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The human polyomavirus JC (JCPyV) infects most people for life but only causes diseases in persons with a compromised immune system. JCPyV reactivation in the brain causes the often fatal progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML). There is currently no effective treatment for PML. Natural killer cells help the body defend itself against viral infections, and the proposed studies will determine how these immune cells contribute to the control of JCPyV replication and curtail PML. The outcome of these studies will provide basis for potentially discover immune targets for novel therapeutics against JCPyV.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Assertive sexual communication is linked to higher condom use rates, and, in turn, lower rates of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and sexually transmitted infections (STIs). However, adolescent sexual minority males (ASMM), a population disproportionately at-risk for acquiring HIV/STIs, do not receive adequate information or skills surrounding assertive sexual communication with a partner. The proposed project will help us adapt an existing digital intervention to increase sexual assertiveness among ASMM, with a specific focus on condom negotiation, to increase condom use rates.

PHR: NARRATIVE The United States is experiencing a healthcare clinician maldistribution that negatively affects access to care and health outcomes for millions of Americans. The rural-urban access to care disparity is a well-known but growing public health threat for rural Americans. The findings of this study will identify an optimal set of policy options and incentives that would attract clinicians to a rural area.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with limited English proficiency (LEP) receive inferior preparation to leave the hospital after a medical admission. The goal of this application is to address disparities in patient safety, clinical outcomes, and patient experience related to the hospital discharge process for patients with LEP. The proposed Aims will adapt an evidence-based intervention (ReEngineered Discharge), which has been shown to improve outcomes around hospital discharge, to the needs of patients with LEP, thereby directly aligning with NIMHD’s Strategy to “adapt evidence-based interventions for implementation and evaluation within health disparity populations.”

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Fragile X Syndrome, the most common form of inherited intellectual disability and monogenic cause of autism, is caused by the loss of the RNA-binding protein FMRP. FMRP regulates translation by cooperating with microRNAs; however, the magnitude of microRNA dysregulation in human-specific models of FXS remains unclear. This study will determine the extent of microRNA dysregulation in human models of FXS and reveal whether RNA-binding proteins and microRNAs operate bimodally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: The physician-scientist pipeline persistently struggles to attract and retain individuals historically underrepresented in medicine (URiM), including individuals who are Black, Hispanic, American Indian or Alaskan Native, Native Hawaiian, and other Pacific Islander. This is a 5-year, longitudinal, mixed-methods study that will identify trajectories of research career intentions, and determinants thereof, in 400 URiM students matriculating into MD programs and compare these with trajectories and determinants among 200 non-URiM students. This study is significant and innovative because it will provide granular data about the formative experiences of URiM MD students that can be used to support growth of the racial and ethnic diversity of the physician-scientist workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative. Neurons and astrocytes have unique demands in regulating the quality of their proteome that require the autophagy degradation pathway, but how autophagy is regulated to facilitate cell type-specific functions and responses to stress is largely unknown. This proposal will elucidate cell type-specific functions for the autophagy receptor p62 in neurons and astrocytes, and how ALS-linked mutations in p62 impair p62 function in each cell type. Insights from this study will generate new ideas for how neurons and astrocytes use p62 differently in basal, stress, and disease conditions, and may uncover new and more precise cell-specific targets to modify autophagy for the treatment of neurodegenerative disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE Immature testicular tissues have been cryopreserved for thousands of patients worldwide with anticipation that they can be thawed in the future and matured to produce sperm. Autologous transplantation of frozen/thawed testicular tissues/cells will not be appropriate or safe for all patients. In this proposal, we test three different physiomimetic systems for maturing immature testicular tissues or cells and producing sperm outside the body. In addition to clinical applications, these systems can be used to gain fundamental insights into human testis development or used as platforms to screen of toxicologic or pharmaceutical compounds or develop drugs that promote or prevent sperm production.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE ____________________________________________________________________ Community firearm violence (CFV), defined as fatal and non-fatal shootings that result from interpersonal violence, is an increasing threat to public health in the United States that disproportionately impacts people and communities from structurally marginalized racial groups. While emerging research indicates that news media reporting on CFV is causing harm to firearm-injured people and impeding effective public health responses, investigations in this area are extremely limited. To reduce gaps in existing knowledge, we will partner with a community-based organization that supports ethical reporting on CFV to define and measure racial and spatial disparities in harmful reporting on CFV in Philadelphia with the goal of producing evidence to inform journalistic guidelines that minimize harmful reporting on CFV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: NARRATIVE There is an urgent public health need to collect valid and reliable data on structural racism before effective interventions to reduce structural racism can be designed. We propose to create an intersectional, multilevel, and multidimensional Structural Racism Measure that includes economic indicators, has measurement invariance (or equivalence), and is valid for both Blacks and Hispanics/Latinos. The new measure will better capture social disadvantage and the lived experience of people with health disparities and will become an important tool for researchers and others working to eliminate health disparities and discrimination.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Developing evidence has revealed that cocaine reward behavior is attenuated following oxytocin administration in rodents, though the specific mechanisms underlying this effect remains unclear. This research project focuses on oxytocin’s potential mechanism within the male and female rat ventral tegmental area (VTA), a central region of the mammalian reward circuitry. Using a novel combination of transgenic rat and viral-mediated silencing of oxytocin or cannabinoid 1 receptors, this project highlights oxytocin’s impact on dopamine neuronal firing in the VTA through its interactions with the cannabinoid receptors to identify a neural mechanism underlying oxytocin’s effect on cocaine preference behavior.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clinical research training in Obstetrics and Gynecology (OBGYN) has fallen behind other disciplines; however, the challenging problems in OBGYN and women’s health are vitally important to public health. Led by a diverse group of faculty, this four-day clinical research training course will provide a strong foundation in research methodology and valuable learning and networking opportunities for junior faculty and fellows in OBGYN. Ultimately, the course will create a cadre of junior investigators who will help improve the health of women and pregnant people for years to come.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The primary purpose of this EAP is to administer novel RAPA-501 autologous T cell therapy to high-risk people with ALS (pwALS), with the goal of established the feasibility and safety of this intervention and obtaining a signal of efficacy in this population of pwALS. This EAP project will also yield a wealth of understanding pertaining to the biologic underpinnings of the neuroinflammatory component to ALS progression and its potential amelioration through RAPA-501 TREG/Th2 cell therapy. This EAP will also incorporate AI-based comparator cohort methods that will permit more accurate estimation of RAPA-501 treatment effect in this EAP and will contribute to global efforts to incorporate exploratory comparator arms into ALS clinical trials that lack placebo arms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Young adult men who have sex with men (MSM) have high rates of heavy alcohol use and account for majority of new HIV cases. Text messaging, a ubiquitous technology, is starting to be used to enhance effects of brief interventions and shows promise as a tool to support and maintain behavior change, but there is room for improvement, and further theory-based rigorous development and empirical testing is needed. The proposed study leverages the empirically supported construal level theory (CL T) to, in the MOSAIC K99 phase, develop and pilot test text messages via a user-centered approach with members of the intended end-user population, and in the R00 phase, test the efficacy of CL T-based text messages in reducing heavy drinking and HIV risk among young adult MSM, at the day level, via a fully powered micro-randomized trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Women of color have increased prevalence of short sleep duration and poor sleep quality, which increases risk for cardiometabolic disorders such as diabetes and high blood pressure. The results of this community- engaged project conducted among women from the Black/African American, Hispanic/Latinx, Native Hawaiian/Pacific Islander and African Immigrant/Refugee communities will increase our understanding of women’s time use and how the relationships between time spent for sleep, physical activity and other demands affect risk for cardiometabolic disease. Study findings will result in novel interventions to improve the sleep and health of women of color.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project leverages advances in network-based computational neuroscience to dynamically track brain-based trajectories of remission from opioid-use disorder (OUD) during early methadone treatment. By scanning at bi- weekly intervals over three months, this will provide essential proof-of-concept data to help characterize the temporal dynamics of early OUD treatment and associated unique patterns of functional brain organization at unprecedented temporal resolution. By providing mechanistic insight into early OUD treatment, findings should contribute to the scientific response to the growing opioid epidemic and may be used to inform treatment development.

PHR: Project Narrative The orphan G protein-coupled receptor GPR3 appears to be important in substance abuse and is a unique biological target for tobacco use disorder. We will conduct a virtual high-throughput screen followed by a medicinal chemistry campaign and structure activity analysis to develop potent, selective, drug-like GPR3 agonist probes. Potential probes will be validated in cell-based functional assays followed by testing in animal models of nicotine abuse.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding factors that underpin resilience to the development of substance use disorders (SUD) is critical. Thus, our prior work used a model of brief early resource scarcity to identify molecular changes that promote resilience to addiction-related behaviors in adult rats. Here we extend this work using new approaches to determine if resilience is also observed in the adolescent period–a key period for SUD vulnerability and brain development–and to delineate cell type-specific molecular signatures linked to resilience in key developmental windows.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid addiction is a highly prevalent and devastating disorder with no effective treatments, resulting in an enormous burden on family and society. This work will investigate a unique subpopulation of striatal neurons that co-express both dopamine D1 and D2 receptors that may play critical roles in the cellular and behavioral actions of opioids. If successful, my studies will establish important new avenues for novel, more effective therapeutic strategies for opioid abuse and addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The mechanisms by which certain mutations can lead to the same apparent native fold but can cause  differences in function is of fundamental biological relevance, whose understanding could lead to new drug  discoveries. It also speaks to broader issues in molecular self-assembly, protein folding in general, biological  and biology-inspired materials, bioengineering, human health and disease. Our proposed work, at the  interface of biology and mathematical topology, will provide the rigorous framework upon which the relation  between structure and function of biomolecules can be understood and controlled to address these  questions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study seeks to understand how alcohol misuse can worsen inflammation during HIV infection, hypothesizing that this effect is related to alcohol's ability to cause gut leakiness. We are also testing the hypothesis that anti- inflammatory prebiotics can decrease the severity of gut leakiness and inflammation caused by alcohol misuse during HIV infection. The completion of this proposal may lead to the design of novel strategies to prevent/treat inflammation-associated diseases in people living with HIV and alcohol use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed expanded access would provide 200 people living with ALS with 24 months of access to pridopidine, an investigational product that is being tested in a randomized clinical trial for ALS, the HEALEY ALS Platform Trial. This expanded access would provide broad and long-term safety, biomarker, and real- world efficacy data from a population that is not eligible to enroll in formal clinical trials. By providing a model for evaluating long-term safety, biomarker changes, and clinical efficacy, we are helping to treat participants in this project and also creating a blueprint for the design of scientifically relevant, patient-centric expanded access protocols.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Dentists can play an important role in expanding HIV testing and facilitating access to HIV prevention services for at-risk populations in highly impacted areas. This study will test two complementary interventions, rapid HIV testing in community-health center dental clinics and an interactive text messaging intervention to reduce HIV risk: supporting both the diagnosis and prevention pillars of the Ending the HIV Epidemic initiative. If successful, this model which engages the dental workforce in community health centers in Suffolk County, MA, a designated hotspot, can be replicated at low cost within other high-risk communities.

PHR: Exercising regularly is key to cancer survivors experiencing the health benefits of a physically active lifestyle. This project will evaluate novel interventions designed to assist African American cancer survivors in overcoming exercise barriers, developing a physically active mindset, and establishing exercise habits needed to exercise long term. We will generate new scientific knowledge on the factors most important in helping survivors successfully maintain a physically active lifestyle and gain a better understanding of how discrimination influences the outcomes of interventions promoting physical activity maintenance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reducing the number of youth at high risk for the development of cardiovascular disease requires synergistically addressing both mental and physical health in an appealing, accessible way that has realistic pathways to large scale implementation. We will revise, enhance, and conduct pilot testing on a well-liked afterschool program that uses mentoring to integrate social-emotional learning skills into physical activity programming to enhance its reach and impact at improving physical activity and depression among underserved youth at disproportionate risk for cardiovascular disease development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Neurons are heavily depending on mitochondrial trafficking for their survival and functions including synaptic neurotransmission. In this study, we plan to determine whether pathogenic LRRK2 mutations affect mitochondrial trafficking and dynamics in dopaminergic neurons and the underlying mechanisms in pre-clinical mouse models of Parkinson’s disease. These findings will help to develop early therapies for preventing and/or delaying onset of symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: U01 Narrative: To date, there is a lack of blood-based traumatic brain injury biomarkers that are linked directly to axonal injury and neurodegeneration after TBI. Based on collective literature and our own data, Tau protein and phospho-Tau (P-Tau) can provide following context of use: as prognostic biomarkers for complicated mild TBI patients at risk for persistent post-concussive symptoms lasting more than 3 months. The main objective of this proposal is to conduct analytic validation of Tau and P-Tau (at Thr-231) biomarkers on two advance assay platforms (Quanterix SIOMA, SOFIA-RCA). We obtained new preliminary data showing that both platforms have demonstrated assay sensitivity of measuring Tau and P-Tau in human serum and plasma samples.
PI_NAMEs: MANLEY, GEOFFREY T;WANG, KEVIN KA WANG (contact)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative CNM-Au8 is a concentrated suspension of catalytically active gold nanocrystals that has been shown preclinically to address multiple cellular deficits resulting from compromised energy metabolism associated with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), a relentlessly progressive neurodegenerative disease. Exploratory clinical results from two independent Phase 2 clinical trials suggest treatment with an oral 30 mg daily dose of CNM-Au8 is associated with slowed clinical worsening and improved survival, which will be investigated in a Phase 3 clinical trial anticipated to commence in 2023. In this study, Columbia University, Clene, and Synapticure propose an innovative approach to conduct an intermediate-sized ALS Expanded Access Program in 100 people living with ALS from across the United States with the goal of monitoring safety, survival and clinical worsening, as well as evaluating key biomarkers related to disease progression, to generate a body of real-world evidence.

PHR: OTHER PROJECT INFORMATION – Project Narrative The rising prevalence of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementia (ADRD) with an aging population represents a profound and emergent challenge for our health and long-term care systems. There are also unique aspects and potential barriers to providing healthcare to people with ADRD, who may be less capable of communicating their symptoms and health histories or following through independently on prescribed treatments, and who often rely on family members and other caregivers for support. The proposed research evaluates processes, tools, or policies that may improve decision-making, healthcare access and delivery, and outcomes for people living with ADRD.

PHR: OTHER PROJECT INFORMATION – Project Narrative The CMS database infrastructure managed by this core is among the richest resource anywhere for research on the healthcare and health of older Americans, including those with Alzheimer’s Disease or related dementias (ADRD). PHR: OTHER PROJECT INFORMATION – Project Narrative An emergency department clinician treating a patient with acute coronary syndrome (ACS) faces difficult decisions about whether to recommend invasive treatment. If the patient is cognitively impaired, assessing health risks and benefits is even more complex. This project will test a machine learning tool called HEARTSPOT that presents a report to help clinicians make this difficult decision. HEARTSPOT will examine each patient’s medical history faster and more completely than any human could and present a summary of its findings to the emergency department clinician in real time.

PHR: OTHER PROJECT INFORMATION – Project Narrative Provider/patient racial concordance and workforce diversity in medicine is an understudied topic, despite its importance for medical decision making and patient wellbeing. Concordance may impact trust and other social factors that may be particularly important for patients with ADRD because of diminished ability for self- advocacy. Prior evidence suggests that minoritized patients’ trust in medicine may be enhanced when they are paired with a race-concordant provider. This project will investigate the extent of racial concordance between providers and patients, drivers of concordance, and causal impacts of a concordant match on health care use and health.

PHR: OTHER PROJECT INFORMATION – Project Narrative This project uses innovative granular data on provider and patient activities in the Emergency Department to study health care outcomes for people living with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementia (ADRD) and the providers who treat them. We assess differences in provider practice patterns for patients living with and without ADRD, tie those differences to provider characteristics, and investigate the impact of provider fatigue and cognitive load on care patterns and health outcomes. This will yield insights into tools to identify and address the underlying drivers of the quality of care delivered to patients with ADRD and thereby improve health and reduce disparities.

PHR: OTHER PROJECT INFORMATION – Project Narrative People with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) face many administrative hassles when interacting with the healthcare system, hassles that are especially difficult for those with dementia to navigate. In this project, we document the exposure of people with ADRD to these hassles and use rigorous quasi- experimental methods to study the causal effects of administrative hassles associated with accessing care and accessing public assistance programs on access to healthcare and health outcomes for people living with ADRD.

PHR: OTHER PROJECT INFORMATION – Project Narrative Nursing homes are key sources of care for millions of older adults, especially those with dementia, but many facilities are unable to consistently deliver high-quality care for these vulnerable patients. To explore the role of payment rates as a tool to address these gaps in quality, this project leverages two recent Medicare nursing home payment reforms as natural experiments. We consider the effects of payment on the quality and safety of care for skilled nursing patients, the mechanisms like staffing that drive these effects, “spillover” effects onto long-stay patients, and the implications of payment changes for disparities in care access and quality. These results will show the benefits and potential unintended consequences of payment reforms and guide future efforts to improve healthcare quality and value for people with dementia and other older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity and its co-morbidities are major threats to the health of Americans: 42% and 9% of Americans are obese and severely obese, respectively. The Nebraska Center for the Prevention of Obesity Diseases through Dietary Molecules (NPOD) occupies a unique niche in the portfolio of obesity research centers, which is to harness the powers of bioactive food compounds to prevent, treat, and cure obesity and its co-morbidities, thereby leading to economical and consumer-friendly interventions. NPOD researchers have amassed nearly $200 million in research funding and leveraged these funds to document the feasibility of disease prevention through bioactive food compounds in 1044 publications and 758 presentations, as well as intervention studies in rural Hispanic populations in Nebraska and Native Americans in South Dakota.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Access to health care is a problem for rural youth in underserved communities. The proposed multi-institutional research project will explore the impact of School Based Health Centers on healthcare utilization and outcomes, and evaluate cross-agency collaboration to address social determinants of health. The project will take a multilevel approach to build individual, institutional, community and policy partnerships to address health disparities of underserved rural youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Social determinants of health influence the progression of Cardiometabolic syndrome (CMetS) disease among individuals with comorbid mental health challenges. Integrated care approaches that address the unique challenges of people with both mental health disorders and CMetS in a culturally relevant manner will likely reduce adverse health outcomes and increase effective disease management. The proposed research will examine the influence of social determinants on mental health and cardiometabolic syndrome risk factor measures among individuals with co-morbid mental health challenges and cardiometabolic syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study has the potential to impact both clinical and public health practice by improving minority health and health equality. Asian American women have the highest prevalence of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) among all racial and ethnic groups and there is substantial heterogeneity in GDM prevalence across Asian subpopulations. Applying an integrative approach leveraging metabolomics, lifestyles, and social determinants of health, the proposed study will elucidate mechanisms of the drastic disparities and heterogeneity in GDM and inform precision prevention to mitigate GDM risk and associated health sequelae for the high-risk Asian Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Nurses often use stigmatizing and racially-biased language in clinical documentation, which results in poor quality of care for minority patients. This project aims to design and pilot-test a technology-driven system, ENGAGE, that will help to identify and reduce the use of stigmatizing language among home healthcare nurses. Achieving this goal will reduce racial biases and improve the quality of care for patients treated in home healthcare settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One third of patients discharged from the hospital develop hospital-associated disability (HAD), defined as the new inability to complete ≥ 1 activities of daily living on discharge from the hospital. While it is well documented across a variety of settings that Black patients and those with social vulnerability have worse functional outcomes (i.e. mobility loss, functional decline) and physical therapy utilization, it is unknown whether these differences exist in Black patients hospitalized for acute medical illness. Given that inpatient physical therapy is important for the treatment and prevention of HAD, this career development award aims to elucidate differences, by race and social vulnerability, in hospital-associated disability and referral and usage of acute and post-acute physical therapy in patients hospitalized for acute medical illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Using a rigorous longitudinal design with participants from a large HIV clinic in Los Angeles area, this study will develop and test an integrated intervention program that uses the advanced ingestible sensor system to trigger intervention sessions in real-time when missed doses are detected to address challenges in social and behavioral determinants of health associated with poor adherence and viral suppression in a timely way. This enhanced intervention has great potential to improve adherence to antiretroviral medications in HIV treatment for those who have significant difficulties in adherence and are at high risk for virologic failure and transmission of HIV to sexual partners and others.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite growing policy activity to offer health care coverage to low-income, uninsured undocumented immigrants, there is only limited evidence on this population’s health care utilization in the context of expanded access to care to support these policies and guide their implementation. This R21 project will examine a long- standing local program that provides health coverage for ~130,000 undocumented patients annually to investigate how expanded access to care affects undocumented patients’ outcomes and health care utilization. We will use patient medical records, enrollment records, and Medicaid claims to provide evidence on the impact of expanded access to care on patient outcomes and understand ED, outpatient, inpatient, and prescription utilization over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study will to evaluate the role of structural racism and discrimination in cancer control behaviors as well as identify psychosocial moderators of the relationship between structural racism and discrimination and cancer control behaviors, in probability samples of African Americans from four focal states. Study findings have the potential to inform practice, research, and policy to improve the health of African Americans, with a particular focus on activities to foster cancer prevention and avoid cancer risk behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Traumatic injuries caused more than 200,000 deaths and the loss of 2 Million potential life years in the US in 2019, disproportionately harming health disparities populations. There is an increasing body of evidence suggesting systematic inequities in access to trauma care are a substantial driver of injury disparities. We aim to identify system-level causes of injury disparities and develop recommendations for interventions to mitigate injury disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Children with asthma from communities that experience health inequities frequently do not receive guideline-based asthma care, and as a result, account for a disproportionate percentage of asthma exacerbations, emergency department visits, and hospitalizations. Project ASTHMA (Aligning with Schools To Help Manage Asthma) tests the effectiveness of school-based health centers as a delivery model to improve health outcomes by providing children with guideline-based asthma assessments and preventive medication management, directly observed therapy of their preventive medication to support adherence, and self-management support. If successful, this multicomponent intervention will represent a cost effective and sustainable model to reduce asthma morbidity in historically marginalized communities, and has the potential to impact communities throughout the United States where over 2,500 school- based health centers operate.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Malaria remains a global scourge of with almost 50% of humans living in endemic areas. Several promising vaccine candidates work well in malaria naïve volunteers, but show diminished potency when evaluated in the malaria experienced populations. This application seeks to determine what features of malaria cause diminished vaccine responses and how these responses can be improved to enhance vaccine potency.

PHR: Project Narrative: This project will advance a novel MHC class II construct, DRhQ, that has the potential to treat people with progressive multiple sclerosis (MS) as well as other CNS conditions that are high priority research areas for VA Veterans including stroke, traumatic brain injury and methamphetamine addiction. The aims of this project are to evaluate multi-compartmental pharmacokinetics, validate relevant biomarkers, including infusion induced cytokine release, inhibition of phosphorylated extracellular-related kinase (pERK1/2) and related cytokines and inhibition of IL-2 secretion induced by activated T-cells, as well as potential neutralizing activity of anti-drug antibodies against DRhQ. These studies will provide critical preclinical data for an IND submission for FDA approval of DRhQ for Phase 1 and 2 clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will transform mental health care by addressing both supply and demand side barriers through provision of accessible and evidence-based care delivered by racially and culturally congruent providers; enabling care to be delivered regardless of a formal diagnosis; and empowering majority-minority, mostly first- generation college-attending students to acquire the skills to respond and become change agents for their communities in Texas, a region with some of the greatest unmet behavioral health needs in the country. Importantly, through specialized training, tangible Community Health Worker certification, and focused mentorship with a team of faculty from historically underrepresented race/ethnic groups, the academic and career trajectory of students at risk for prolonged undergraduate enrollment or, worse, dropout may be altered. This transformative project has important implications for further dissemination and widespread understanding of the organizational and contextual factors which act as barriers to implementation of evidence-based interventions and can serve as a blueprint for guiding Minority Serving Institutions across the country to address the mental health needs of racial and ethnic minority groups in low resourced communities who have experience disparities in access and outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Defects in the mitotic entry control system can lead to genomic instability, a hallmark of cancer, and cell shape changes are associated with multiple stages of cancer progression including metastasis. We will use the model organism fission yeast to define of the upstream signals that govern mitotic entry and polarized growth in eukaryotes. These findings will be important to understand the cellular mechanisms that prevent untimely and inappropriate cell divisions, which contribute to human diseases such as cancer.

ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Informed, shared-decision making is critical to ensure Veteran-centered, values-concordant care. This is especially important with regards to ICDs, permanent devices that require an invasive procedure for implant with intent to monitor and treat life-threatening arrhythmias. ICDs present a complicated balance of patient benefit (ie. treatment of dangerous heart rhythms), procedural risk, long-term maintenance and impact on psychological health (ie. PTSD, anxiety and depression from ICD shocks). Research shows providers overemphasize ICD benefits while patients overestimate benefit, poorly comprehend risks, psychological effects, and complications. The central hypothesis of this proposal is that the current ICD decision-making process is heterogeneous and lacks sufficient Veteran perspective. Aligned with the VA Strategic Plan, this work will shift this paradigm to a Veteran-centered, shared-decision making process. Broadly, this project can set the standard for Veteran-centered care with application to other invasive cardiovascular procedures.
