PHR: Elder abuse (EA), the abuse, exploitation or neglect of an older adult by another person in a trust relationship (e.g., family caregiver), is experienced by 10% of older adults annually in the US. Older adults who experience EA are more likely to have depression, injury, additional hospitalizations, and early mortality. With the US population aging and >10 million US Veterans over age 60, addressing EA and its consequences is both a national and VA public health priority. Unfortunately, an estimated 95% of EA cases go undetected, limiting opportunities to intervene and improve health outcomes. Therefore, enhancing detection is the necessary first step to improving care for older adults experiencing EA. This project aims to improve EA detection in the VA, the country’s largest integrated healthcare system, by assessing how EA screening can be improved and by leveraging medical record data so healthcare teams can proactively identify older Veterans at high risk. These findings will help the VA meet its goal of providing high quality care to older Veterans and their caregivers.

ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: To meet the growing demand for long-term care services while enabling veterans to receive care in their setting of choice, VA has tried, with limited success, to rebalance its long-term care expenditures away from institutional care and towards home and community-based services (HCBS). This CDA explores the role played by key patient, system, and family level factors in VA’s rebalancing efforts. The research aims apply recent innovations in natural language processing, risk adjustment, geospatial statistics, and causal modeling, and lead to an independent research agenda that will help VA improve its HCBS patient targeting tools, identify potential home health contractors, and develop appropriate supports for its informal caregivers. The proposed research addresses a key HSR&D Cross-Cutting Priority Area, Long-term Care and Caregiving, and will help VA operations make informed decisions about how to maximize the effectiveness and reach of scarce long-term care dollars.

PHR: I am applying for 5 years of support for mentored training and research. The proposed research projects address a key gap in care quality for smokers with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD): improving the reach of tobacco cessation treatments. Proactive tobacco treatment programs effectively engage smokers in care yet are rarely implemented. Smokers with COPD appear to respond particularly well to a proactive offer of tobacco treatment, suggesting they are a high-impact group to target. I propose to develop and test a proactive tobacco treatment program for smokers with COPD to be delivered electronically. We expect that an electronic proactive tobacco treatment intervention will increase utilization of cessation services with low associated cost. I will obtain mentored training in qualitative and mixed methods research, design and testing of behavioral tobacco interventions with a focus on mobile health, and cost analysis. This award supports my long-term career goal of improving Veterans’ health through increasing access to effective tobacco cessation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Raydiant Oximetry, Inc. has developed and patented a novel optical sensing technology to noninvasively monitor fetal oxygenation. This technology will enhance surveillance of fetal status during labor and delivery by improving the ability of clinicians to detect fetal hypoxia. This Phase II SBIR effort will advance the technology towards commercialization by the collection and incorporation of human data training sets for refinement of the computational algorithms for calculation of fetal oxygen saturation with subsequent validation of this algorithm to support an IDE application with the FDA.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative  Personality traits, executive function skills, and economic preferences that emerge in childhood impact children’s health and life outcomes, particularly through physical and psychological wellbeing, educational achievement, and workforce decisions. This study will collect and analyze data on traits, skills, and preferences that emerge in childhood and examine how these attributes evolve and co-evolve during adolescence. We will use survey and administrative data from schools as well as self-reported health measures to examine the predictive validity of the elicited measures in order to inform best practices for school evaluations and assist teachers in designing student-tailored curricula, which may also inform public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Secretory proteins responsible for essential cellular functions such as communication and defense are synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and then exported out of ER, a process accompanied by accidental export of ER-resident proteins, which poses a stress on cellular survival. These ER-resident proteins are retrieved back by the COPI machinery, which is hijacked by coronaviruses to traffic their spike protein for viral progeny assembly, thus presenting a pathway to advance our understanding of fundamental secretory protein trafficking and to identify targets for therapeutic intervention in COPI-associated diseases, COVID-19, and in future coronavirus outbreaks. The investigations proposed in this grant will provide mechanistic details underlying the hijacking of COPI by the spike and the atomic details of fine-tuning in this interaction, thus advancing the biological principles of secretory homeostasis.

PHR: Project Narrative The Appalachian Tobacco Regulatory Research Team (AppalTRuST) will investigate the impact of Federal Drug Administration Center for Tobacco Products (FDA CTP) regulatory policies in rural communities, a vulnerable and understudied population, through collaboration, education and pioneering regulatory scientific research. Our three projects and four cores are designed to bridge the knowledge gap in rural tobacco use behaviors, guided by a definition of rurality that accounts for heterogeneity. Our approach is designed to inform the use of a health equity lens in shaping current, proposed, and future FDA regulatory actions to reduce rural tobacco use disparities.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: RELEVANCE: OVERALL Significant progress has been made in reducing cigarette smoking in the United States, but notable disparities persist in menthol cigarette smoking and in the use of non-cigarette tobacco products, including little cigars and e-cigarettes. UNC TCORS will conduct four integrated Research Projects that will inform FDA efforts to communicate more effectively with the public about tobacco products (i.e., little cigars and cigarillos, menthol cigarettes, and e-cigarettes) and identify the public health impact and unintended consequences of an FDA flavored cigar ban. This new evidence will identify specific actions that FDA can implement to reduce existing disparities in tobacco product use.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of this R44 research is to test a new device to measure metabolite levels at home in patients at risk for metabolic crises. In the long term, home use of this device will enable physicians to better control patients to avoid metabolic crises and dramatically reduce the negative consequences of metabolic crises. Daily home monitoring of metabolic status will improve the lifelong outcomes of these vulnerable patients by enabling timely use of known and effective treatments for reducing metabolite levels to prevent or treat metabolic crises.

PHR: Project Narrative: Overall The overall objective of the Penn State TCORS is to provide a science base for reducing the harm from tobacco products. We are pursuing the Food and Drug Administration’s Comprehensive Plan for Tobacco and Nicotine Regulation by determining the toxicity of aerosols, smoke, and oral exposures of tobacco products that may be used as substitutions for cigarettes. This includes identifying the specific characteristics of non- cigarette products that can be regulated to reduce harm.

ORG_NAME: EDITH NOURSE  ROGERS MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSPITAL
PHR: Unrelieved pain is highly prevalent and devastating for Veterans in Community Living Centers (CLCs). This Career Development Award capitalizes on the imminent removal of pain as one of the CLC quality measures to develop new, risk-adjusted measures that more accurately characterize pain management. These measures will identify top-performing CLCs. By diving deeply into their unique organizational structures and processes for achieving high quality pain management, we can learn how to intervene. My background in gerontology, quantitative methods, and implementation science partially prepares me for this work. The proposed CDA simultaneously fills considerable gaps in my training—in risk adjustment, qualitative research, cutting-edge analytic methods, and intervention study design—and provides VA with rigorous, actionable research on which to ground future quality improvement efforts.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Research on clinical safety of prehospital emergency care, particularly for older adult patients, has lagged significantly behind other clinical domains despite being an essential component of the continuum of health care. In response to the urgent need for enhancing and supporting safety, and quality, and equity within pre- hospital emergency care, we propose to establish the Resilient_EMS Learning Lab. The Resilient_EMS Learning Lab is tailored to use systems and human factors engineering approaches to generate results salient to developing interventions to support `real time' cognitive work of emergency medical technicians/ paramedics, using a prospective systems-based approach in a variety of EMS pre-hospital care environments (rural, suburban, urban).
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Resilient EMS PSLL: Using a Systems Engineering Approach to Enhance EMS Cognitive Work and Safety for Older Adults During Prehospital Care.

PHR: This VA Career Development Award will ensure Dr. Woodward’s expertise in VA healthcare implementation research through formal training and applications of her knowledge through small research studies. Her specific training areas are on how to ensure effective treatments are used in routine clinical practice in VA healthcare, especially for Veterans who are sometimes overlooked in healthcare (e.g., racial minority, lower income). She will apply this knowledge to research studies that involve working with Veterans and their families and caregivers and using their feedback to best design VA healthcare, specific to suicide prevention in rural VA clinics.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - OVERALL The Yale Center for the Study of Tobacco Product Use and Addiction (YCSTP) will examine how ingredients in tobacco products, including nicotine and chemicals that produce cooling and sweetness, contribute to product initiation, continued use, and addiction. We also will investigate if these ingredients may help people switch from smoking cigarettes to using non-combustible products like e-cigarettes and oral nicotine pouches. Career development activities and collaborations will develop the next generation of tobacco regulatory scientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to adapt, assess and support scale up of a tailored, video-based counseling package for adolescents living with HIV (ALHIV): VITAL (Video Intervention to Inspire Treatment Adherence for Life) Start for Adolescents (VS4A), an intervention on the primary composite outcome of retention and adherence (viral load <1000 copies/ml) in a multisite cluster randomized controlled trial (CRCT) in Malawi. If effective, VS4A can be an innovative, scalable tool to improve service delivery for ALHIV while also liberating HCW time and reducing health system burden in Malawi. Building on a 15-year partnership with the Malawi Ministry of Health (MOH), a track record of excellence and innovation in service to ALHIV, and a robust implementation science research portfolio, our team is poised to successfully implement the VS4A study and program and to use findings to support rapid, wide-scale dissemination and scale up.

PHR: With a growing patient population and no approved therapeutics that slow or halt disease progression, Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a major national health burden. This Phase IIB proposal aims to conduct preclinical and IND-enabling studies on our novel lead and backup compounds that correct neuronal calcium handling and showed beneficial effects on learning and memory in an animal model of AD. Our previous Phase II research met our goal of identifying orally active development candidates, and this proposal aims to conduct required efficacy, safety, toxicology, and process research to support the IND application.

PHR: Project Narrative Worldwide and in the U.S. lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer mortality. Our proposal identifies risk factors at each step of lung cancer development to understand the mechanisms controlling and influencing its progression and to identify biomarkers that can be used clinically for early detection. We have also included diverse communities in our research program, in order to identify approaches to engage them in risk reduction strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Although use of interpreters is the “gold standard” in hospital and clinic settings for communicating with limited English proficient (LEP) patients, in prehospital emergency care interpreters are seldom used, and it is less clear when use of professional over-the-phone interpreter (OPI) services is appropriate or how 9-1-1 dispatchers decide on connecting to OPI during 9-1-1 calls with LEP callers. We propose a multi-method study to 1) Identify call characteristics that are associated with OPI use and associated communication and care delivery outcomes during real-life 9-1-1 calls with LEP callers and 2) Identify key dispatcher attributes associated with use of and time to OPI during simulated scenarios (developed based on information collected in Aim#1) with LEP Spanish, Mandarin and Cantonese mock callers. Third, we plan to translate and disseminate the results of the study via training opportunities and policy recommendations identified by emergency medical services (EMS) and community stakeholders, using a participatory Delphi technique.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic uncontrolled hypertension (HTN) impacts millions in the United States, with disproportionate deaths and morbidity affecting racially/ethnically minoritized populations, particularly Black and Latinx patients. Though the COVID-19 pandemic has prompted adoption of telehealth for chronic disease care, many racially/ethnically minoritized patients have inequitable access to health IT (patient portals, telemedicine video visits, and remote patient monitoring) due to structural, clinical, and individual barriers; addressing equitable telehealth access could reduce the “digital divide,” improve chronic disease self-management, and enhance health outcomes. Our team is located in a large, racially and ethnically diverse public health network, where we propose to implement a multilevel randomized controlled trial including clinic-level practice facilitation (learning collaborative, community advisory boards, and telehealth data dashboard), and patient-level health coaching and digital navigation, to enhance patient digital literacy, medication adherence, self-efficacy for HTN care and increase patient and clinician engagement with health IT, thereby improving hypertension control and reducing health disparities in care for Black and Latinx patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This research will increase knowledge about the regulation of gene expression, which underlies virtually every aspect of human health. By improving understanding of RNA polymerase, which is an established target for effective antibiotics, the work will aid in the quest for new antibiotics that can keep humankind a step ahead of microbial pathogens. The research also will elucidate complex connections between RNA synthesis by RNA polymerase, chromatin structure, RNA maturation, and RNA translation that are key to understanding the function of microbial communities in promoting both human health and disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One influential theory of how Alzheimer’s disease spreads in the brain is that toxic tau is transported through the brain’s white matter, along the axons of neurons; however, evidence for this model is incomplete. If axonal transport is a common mechanism of tau spread, it should leave behind a signature of tau accumulation and degeneration affecting the white matter networks that correspond to a patient’s primary cognitive symptoms. We will combine longitudinal imaging of tau progression and white matter change with postmortem histopathology to assess evidence for the axonal transport model in amnestic and non-amnestic variants of Alzheimer’s disease that are known to affect distinct cognitive networks.

STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Clinical Neuroscience and Neurodegeneration Study Section[CNN]

PHR: Project Narrative Preventing Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is arguably the most important approach to address the dementia epidemic worldwide because 99.6% of drug trials failed and no drugs can yet prevent, cure, or even slow AD. Growing evidence suggests that aerobic exercise and cognitive training, particularly in combination, are two such promising interventions to target cognitive decline in persons at risk for AD, however compliance to such therapies in the real world setting is poor due to travel and time barriers. This proposed project will implement and test a unique Virtual Reality Cognitive Training (VRCT) combined with concurrent cycling (Exergame) that seamlessly integrates specific cognitive tasks into a virtual environment and is synchronized with cycling to promote cognitive gains, in a home-based (asynchronous) telerehabilitation model in a 2:2 factorial design clinical trial in persons at risk for AD.

PHR: Project Narrative Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer death and results from interplay of environmental and genetic risk factors. This project seeks to use very large data sources to interrogate joint effects of environment and genetics that increase cancer risks for individuals to inform risk reduction and recruitment to and management of low dose spiral CT screening.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Stereotypic repetitive behaviors that are generally believed to be nonfunctional, are seen in a wide range of vertebrate species in blood glucose-inducing, stress-associated environments, and are reduced under ketosis-related nutritional conditions. Accordingly, this research program has two goals: the short-term goal is to address the genes and their gene co-expression networks associated with repetitive behaviors in an experimental fish model implementing naturalistic heterogeneity in the genome and behaviors. The long- term goal is to reveal the genetic and neural mechanisms of how repetitive behavior is chosen among other voluntary behavior types, particularly in terms of stress-associated and nutritional conditions.

PHR: Project 2: Integrating Biomarkers into Lung Cancer Risk Profiling Narrative Many lung cancers occur in individuals who are not eligible for screening with low-dose computed tomography (LDCT). The INTEGRAL-AT Project 2 will improve LDCT screening eligibility criteria by incorporating biomarkers in risk assessment and evaluating the user acceptability in a community-based screening program. We will also identify novel biomarkers for lung cancer in never smokers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE This project seeks to understand the role of serum advanced glycation end-products in the high frequency of tendon injury and impaired function in millions of Americans with diabetes. This critical project will use genetic mouse models and the study of people with diabetes to delineate the role of serum advanced glycation end- products in tendon injury and impaired function. With a long-term goal of developing new prevention and treatment strategies, this research will identify novel serum factors that drive tendon injury and impaired tendon function in the growing number of individuals with diabetes.

PHR: Project Narrative Lung cancer continues to be the most common cancer and the leading cause of cancer death worldwide, and the reduction of lung cancer death remains to be a global priority. While low- dose computed tomography (LDCT) can reduce lung cancer mortality by 20-30%, there are emerging challenges including how to optimize screening intervals, address issues of racial disparity, and possible overdiagnosis. To maximize the benefit-harm ratio, our project aims to optimize biomarker-informed screening pathway while focusing on under-represented populations such as African Americans and Asian never smokers.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will provide empirical data that directly speaks to the factors impacting the long-term psychosocial functioning of transgender and gender diverse (TGD) youth receiving gender-affirming hormone therapy (GAHT; puberty suppression, testosterone, estrogen), which is urgently needed to guide sweeping international shifts already occurring in youth’s ability to access this treatment. The proposed project will also help illuminate the bidirectional relationships between youth and parent functioning and as well as the impact of the escalating sociopolitical stress faced by TGD youth and their parents. In addition to providing policy level guidance, this information will strengthen healthcare providers’ ability to anticipate the needs of diverse TGD youth and families and individualize the care they provide.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to work with patients and clinical care team members to co-design and implement strategies to increase use of home blood pressure monitoring in culturally diverse and low-income patient populations. We will conduct a trial of patient-focused and clinical-focused implementation strategies and assess the impact on blood pressure control. We will assess the costs of these strategies and how effective they were at safely and equitably increasing home blood pressure monitoring.

PROJECT_TITLE: Implementation Strategies for Self-Measured Blood Pressure Monitoring in Racially and Ethnically Diverse Populations (InS2PiRED).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative A pharmacogenomics-guided drug policy includes the genomic profile of an individual’s drug response with other clinical characteristics and may improve the safety and effectiveness of drug therapy. In some instances, however, pharmacogenomics-guided drug policy may improve the health for some patients, while leaving out patients from demographics that already suffer from health inequalities. This project will elucidate clinical value with a racial fairness lens without yet implementing a new pharmacogenomics-guided drug policy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Smoking is associated with increased wound healing time, wound infections, and cardiovascular complications among surgery patients, leading to the implementation of policies requiring smoking cessation prior to elective surgery. These policies provide an opportunity for health care providers to assist patients in achieving both short-and long-term smoking cessation; however, the impact of these policies on socioeconomically disadvantaged patients, a population that experiences significant smoking-related disparities, has not been evaluated. Our mixed methods study fills this important gap by examining the impact of a policy implemented in Oregon in 2017 that requires Medicaid-insured patients to quit smoking prior to elective surgery on smoking (smoking cessation assistance and cessation) and surgery-related (receipt of surgery, surgical complications) among patients seen in community health centers.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to develop a mobile stress management program for hypertensive African American men to reduce racial and non-racial stress and improve blood pressure. Because most Black men have smartphones, this program can be easily distributed at a lower cost. For African American men, the skills contained in this program will help them reduce stress and the negative impact that stress has on blood pressure.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescents and young adults (AYAs) with sickle cell disease (SCD) are at high risk for disease complications, emergency room visits, and early mortality. These primarily Black AYA also face social determinants of health (SDOH)-related barriers which impede their disease self-management. We propose to evaluate an innovative self-management intervention (SCThrive) that combines telemedicine, peer support, and a mobile app to target individual and SDOH-related barriers to improve patient activation, self-management, and health outcomes.

PHR: Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is a common disease leading to dementia affecting millions of people worldwide. Amyloid has been implicated as one of the initiating factors in Alzheimer’s. Therefore, it is a target in the treatment of AD. Unfortunately, treatment options to date are limited or have limited effects. Recombinant Technologies (RT) owns a patent on an active pharmacological ingredient (API) with demonstrated proof of concept in a clinically relevant mouse model for AD. Incorporating the same API, RT has designed and developed an extra-corporeal device, namely, Amytrapper catheter to capture circulating amyloid. The device works similar to hemodialysis equipment that removes urea in patients with kidney failure. RT now plans to perform additional research and development to optimize and fine- tune the device, demonstrate proof of concept in blood samples from AD patients, obtain an investigative device exemption (IDE) classification from FDA and get ready for a first in human pilot study. The proposed innovative device may lead to achieving a novel treatment strategy that improves the lives of patients with AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intersectional stigmas due to black race, same-sex attraction/behavior, and presumed HIV-positive status threaten the HIV prevention uptake and well-being of Black men who have sex with men (BMSM). Building resilience to intersectional stigmas is critical for BMSM to mitigate psychological distress and enhance engagement in the HIV prevention continuum. The proposed project seeks to (1) define the nuanced resiliency mechanisms in countering intersectional stigmas at multiple socioecological levels; (2) develop and validate the first multidimensional stigma-resilience measure tailored for research conducted with BMSM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Public Relevance Statement The proposed research tests the effectiveness of an adapted evidence-based intervention for Black girls and male caregivers. Using a framework that speaks to the development of Black girls acknowledging structural violence (stereotype messaging and lack of protection), the PI will test whether an adapted family-based intervention, IMARA for Black Male caregivers and Girls Empowerment (IMAGE), will improve the sexual and reproductive health of Black girls by engaging Black men in their protection. We will simultaneously identify the degree of implementation success and factors associated with success across five community-based organizations serving Black families and youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The project describes a new mathematical data analysis approach, rooted on transport and related phenomena, which is aimed at greatly enhance our ability to extract meaning from diverse biomedical datasets, while augmenting the accuracy of predictions as compared to existing modeling tools such as deep learning. This period of the project focuses on generalizing our previous approach to virtually all data types in biomedical data sciences. We will explore proof of concept applications in cytometry, pathology, and radiomics.

PHR: Project Narrative: We seek to determine how myosin V motors choose the correct organelle cargoes, and deposit them at their new destinations. Mutations in myosin V underlie diseases in the brain, skin pigmentation and the digestive tract. Thus, insights into myosin V regulation, may provide insights into how to treat some of these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Our innovative experimental approach using nanopore sequencing provides an unparalleled opportunity to study complex epigenetics events at stem cell biology and germ cell biology. In addition, our sophisticated bioinformatics platform will provide a set of robust and handy tools to fully analyze nanopore sequencing epigenome data, such that this cutting-edge technology can be feasible in biomedical research laboratories of all sizes. The analysis of nanopore sequencing epigenome data can identify epigenetic events at each single long DNA molecules, providing a solid foundation for precision medicine.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: The Phase II SBIR goal is to enhance, validate, and commercialize Access-H2O, a sensor driven smart faucet to enable and empower independent drinking and grooming for individuals impacted by spinal cord injury. Spinal cord injury (SCI) severely impacts functional independence & ability to perform activities of daily living (ADLs) with those impacted above C8 having limited use of arms and hands for drinking, washing, and grooming. Therefore, commercialization of smart fountain faucets, to automatically deliver water in target temperature, force, & nozzle setting for a specific ADL have potential to empower individuals with SCI for greater independence & improved quality of life.

PHR: NARRATIVE For decades chromosomal aberrations have been useful biomarkers for mechanistic investigations of, diagnosis, and treatment decision making for liquid tumors. The utility of chromosomal aberration in diagnosis and stratification of solid tumor treatment options is limited by the fact that virtually all solid tumor samples are stored as formalin-fixed paraffin embedded (FFPE) tissue. In this proposal we describe a scalable proximity ligation sequencing method and analysis platform that can overcome limitations presented by the highly fragmented DNA found in FFPE tissue to identify chromosomal aberrations in solid tumors in FFPE blocks, enabling research and diagnostic applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Membrane proteins are embedded in the complex lipid environment of the biological membrane. Membrane protein function is often regulated by specific lipid interactions and, therefore, the identification and characterization of protein-lipid interactions is of paramount biological importance. This proposal seeks to apply highly innovative and integrative approaches, combining numerous biophysical techniques, to identify and characterize protein-lipid interactions at the molecular level.

PHR: Project Narrative Youth are increasingly living their lives filtered through social media account participation—a setting where marketers are constantly innovating to gain youth attention and influence. Effective e-cigarette control strategies for adolescents require a more comprehensive understanding of the potential impact of social media marketing on their attitudes and use. The current project will use state-of-the-art techniques to examine these questions and thereby increase the ability of public health officials and policymakers to develop appropriate countermeasures.

PHR: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is a feared complication of liver cirrhosis and has unacceptably high mortality. Prevention of HCC is a major need but a great challenge because it needs large, long trials. We will use a promising HCC risk marker as a surrogate to define the efficacy of statins for HCC chemoprevention.

PHR: 8. Project Narrative There is strong evidence of co-morbid pathologies caused by Aβ, tau and α-synuclein in Alzheimer’s Disease Related Dementias (ADRD) that account for up to 25% of all dementias in patients older than 65 years. Cognitive impairment is closely associated with synapse loss, which occurs significantly prior to neuronal loss, suggesting that synaptic dysfunction is the key treatment target and that ultimately synapse loss by multiple toxic oligomers must be stopped. Creative Bio-Peptides is developing the oral chemokine antagonist peptide RAP-103 to prevent or reverse early synapse loss and cognitive decline in mixed etiology dementias like ADRDs, and will determine synapse density PET imaging and histochemical methods in an animal model of ADRD.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Our innovative bioinformatics platform uses long reads plus short reads to provide an unparalleled opportunity to study the expressions and functions of repetitive genes and gene isoforms, which is important yet challenging “dark matter” in human stem cell transcriptome as well as the corresponding differentiations to different lineages. In addition, our sophisticated platform will provide a set of robust and handy tools to fully analyze long-read transcriptome data, such that this cutting-edge technology can be affordable and feasible in biomedical research laboratories of all sizes. The analyses of the expressions and functions of repetitive genes and gene isoforms at human stem cells and differentiations provide a solid foundation for precision medicine.

PHR: Project Narrative Older adults are disproportionately affected by falls. Older adults who have memory loss can forget to wear wireless alert pendants or wristbands that are used in case they fall in their home. Falls among adults 65 and older caused over 34,000 deaths in 2019, making it the leading cause of injury death for that group. Older adult falls cost $50 billion in medical costs annually. In 2019, emergency departments recorded 3.14 million visits for older adults for falls; more than 890,000 of these patients had to be hospitalized. People aged 70 and older constitute 13% of the population, but account for 20% of hospital treated falls and 70% of deaths. A low-cost, unobtrusive system capable of automatically detecting and alerting falls in the homes of older adults living alone or those with mild to moderate cognitive impairment, could help significantly reduce the incidence of delayed assistance after a fall.

PHR: Project Narrative Injuries in the upper and lower extremities equate to more than 40% of fragility fractures, resulting from a low energy trauma event (e.g., falls from standing height) which account for 87% of all orthopedic fractures among the elderly. Complication rates from the current standard of care – open reduction with internal fixation (locking plates and screws) – are as high as 36% and can involve the onset of carpal tunnel syndrome, complex regional pain syndrome, tendon irritation and rupture, deep infections, and the need for revision surgery which often can result in difficulty performing the most basic daily tasks, a reduction in quality of life, and even increased mortality. This project will support commercialization of Tetranite®, a novel, regenerative, bone adhesive for the use of extremity fracture fixation by demonstrating its safety and efficacy through pre-clinical research and a first-in- human clinical trial.

PHR: Detection of preclinical Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is considered a critical prerequisite for early, effective, and enduring AD treatment. This project will test a novel lens amyloid scanner (Sapphire II) with FDA Breakthrough Device designation that utilizes an amyloid-binding tracer (Aftobetin) and specialized eye scanner to measure β-amyloid (Aβ) in the lens for early detection and longitudinal monitoring of AD. We will test the project hypothesis that elevated lens Aβ burden is predictive of cognitive decline and early, pre-symptomatic (preclinical) AD in the longitudinal Clinical Core cohort at the NIA-funded Boston University Alzheimer’s Disease Research Center.

PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Little is known regarding the neural circuitry responsible for reward seeking behaviors in adolescence.  However, adolescence is characterized by an increased motivation to seek reward and is a time period  where several mental disorders characterized by alterations in motivational processes emerge. The  proposed projects seek to investigate how adolescent and adult brains differentially influence reward  behaviors and the impact of adolescent alcohol drinking on brain function and behavior.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE- OVERVIEW The Indiana University Melvin and Bren Simon Cancer Center is an NCI-designated Cancer Center whose mission is to create an expanding community of researchers and health professionals who conduct outstanding translational research, provide excellence in education, and deliver high quality patient-centered care. We will foster and promote an environment of cultural awareness, diversity, and inclusion as we contribute to the prevention and cure of cancer in Indiana. We recognize social injustices and discrimination exist, and we further our mission by embracing the rich perspectives and experiences that arise from racial, ethnic, socioeconomic, sexual, gender, and religious diversity within our community.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunoglobulin G4-related disease (IgG4-RD) is a systemic fibrosing inflammatory disease that frequently presents with an allergic predisposition driven by a TH2 response. We have identified two genetic variants in familial IgG4-RD. Here we propose to develop immunological models how these variants cause loss of tolerance and TH2 polarization that may be relevant for non-familial IgG4-RD and other polygenic autoimmune diseases.

PHR: Project Narrative Chronic exposure to drugs such as psychostimulants produces long-lasting molecular and functional changes in the brain, which in vulnerable individuals result in behavioral changes that further predispose them to loss of control in their drug use and progression of Substance Use Disorder (SUD). These drugs produce remarkably similar behavioral outputs and act on similar molecular targets in the nervous system (brain equivalent) of the simple yet powerful model organism Caenorhabditis elegans. In this proposal, we leverage the capabilities for high-resolution, large-scale, and rapid genetic analysis of the entire nervous system in C. elegans to identify candidate regulators of long-lasting drug-induced changes and open up novel avenues of therapeutic interventions for SUD.

PHR: Narrative The Training Program in Tumor Microenvironment (TPTM) is an interdisciplinary program whose central goal is to train exceptional junior investigators to address fundamental biological problems related to human cancer. The TPTM trains both predoctoral and postdoctoral scholars providing research opportunities focusing on a wide choice of topics in the field of tumor microenvironment as it relates to cancer biology and therapeutic response. Through selective appointments, didactic coursework, and transdisciplinary programmatic activities, the TPTM is creating a diverse pipeline of young investigators who will have a lasting impact on cancer research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Allergic and immunologic disorders continue to rise in prevalence and currently account for many of the most common and important diseases affecting infants and children. The need for cutting edge basic, translational, and clinical research in pediatric allergy and immunology is therefore greater than ever, although exceedingly few programs are equipped to provide the training needed to conduct this research. Support for programs like ours, that are not only equipped to provide the best possible training but also have a documented record of success in producing the leaders in pediatric allergy and immunology, is therefore more important than ever.

PROJECT_TITLE: Research Training in Pediatric Allergy and Immunology

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The HMI Training Program seeks to provide research training and professional development opportunities to talented and highly motivated students that have been recruited into our Trainers’ laboratories. Our Trainees gain clinical insights through attendance of Clinical Microbiology Rounds, learn programming and bioinformatics approaches, host a speaker and lead a journal club in an area of interest among other activities and opportunities. The Director and Associate Director are supported by a Professional Development Subcommittee and strong Internal and External Advisory Committees as they provide a program that will support Trainees as they launch the successful pursuit of biomedical careers that will positively impact the health of our citizens and those around the world.

PHR: Project Narrative Surgical oncologists have a long and important history of contributions to the field of oncology as translational scientists. However, surgeons are increasingly being underrepresented in translational research and there has been a call to address this shortage. This training program is uniquely designed to prepare surgeons for a career in translational science to maximize their ability to make meaningful contributions to society though advancing our understanding and treatment of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a highly morbid disease that leads to right ventricular failure and mortality. Pulmonary artery smooth muscle cells in pre-clinical models of disease have been shown to resist programmed cell death, a critical step in the development and maintenance of PAH. I will study the role of the proteins aquaporin 1 and caspase-3 in promoting smooth muscle cell resistance to death.

PHR: OVERALL COMPONENT NARRATIVE The TIME-AD Program Project brings together multiple large, diverse data sets and new methods to establish whether interventions targeting alcohol, depression or depression treatment, treatment of vision or hearing impairments, or social isolation could reduce AD/ADRD incidence or AD/ADRD inequities. By systematically comparing results from different study designs and populations we will provide more rigorous evidence than previously possible and help fill a priority research gap in the National Plan to Address Alzheimer’s Disease. The overall benefit of the proposed work is enhanced by synergies across shared cores, which provide expertise in the multiple data sources, analytic methods, health equity, and evidence dissemination and integration of evidence on four major, modifiable, risk factor categories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This application requests funds to support the training of six pre-doctoral students per year in the successful Infectious Diseases Across Scales Training Program at Emory University. Thirty-one training faculty from six graduate programs with exceptional strengths in infectious disease research will provide students with training opportunities across a wide range of biological scales, ranging from the immune molecules that dictate interactions between human host cells and pathogens, to the ecosystems in which humans share their pathogens with vectors and other animals. The over-arching goal of this training program is to provide students with the inter-disciplinary and cross-cutting skills and tools to better understand and control infectious disease, and thereby increase healthcare in the United States and beyond.
PROJECT_TERMS: Communicable Diseases;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Infectious Diseases Across Scales Training Program
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Microbiology and Infectious Diseases Research Study Section[MID]

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The Rehabilitation Medicine Scientist Training Program (RMSTP) aims to develop physician scientists in rehabilitation. The RMSTP will recruit a diverse group of promising residents and junior faculty in rehabilitation-related specialties to attend an annual Research Career Development Workshop and receive quarterly guidance through small-group teleconferences. RMSTP training is designed to help participants define their area of research interest, find appropriate local mentors, successfully apply for individual career development funding, and transition successfully to independent research careers.

PHR: Project Narrative The major goal of this Training Program is to provide an interdisciplinary research and training environment wherein trainees will be exposed to the continuum of technological development from conceptual idea to testing at the basic, small animal, large animal, and human levels. Trainees will be advantaged by community strengths in basic, translational, and clinical science, training in cardiovascular innovation and entrepreneurship, and industry interactions and mentorship.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: NARRATIVE – OVERALL PPG  Addiction remains one of the world’s greatest public health problems, yet its pathophysiology remains incompletely understood and available treatments for addictions to various drugs of abuse are inadequately effective for most people. This Program Project Grant focuses on mechanisms of transcriptional and chromatin regulation in drug action on a cell-type-specific basis in brain reward regions. Our work is contributing to a better understanding of the neurobiological basis of stimulant and opioid addiction, which we believe is necessary for the eventual development of definitive treatments and cures for these substance use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Diverse perspectives from diverse backgrounds and identities strengthen the research enterprise and enrich the research community, but leaky pipelines to advanced STEM degrees threaten our diversity goals. In this proposal, we address “leaks” or points where we risk attrition at each stage of neuroscience graduate education from precandidate to dissertation. Our focus on the intersections of diversity with mentoring, professional development, and advanced coursework and research opportunities helps us to “insulate” our pipeline, ultimately diversifying the field of neuroscience.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Chronic ocular surface pain is common, disabling, costly and treatments directed at the ocular surface are often ineffective. Instead, the source of pain maybe dysfunction of pain signaling and processing in the central nervous system similar to other chronic pain conditions, such as fibromyalgia. Our study seeks to define the role of central nervous system dysfunction in chronic ocular surface pain to impact diagnoses and treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many microbes under study at UTMB are potential biological weapons as well as naturally emerging/re-emerging pathogens. To protect the world from intentional release of biological weapons, as well as from naturally emerging/re-emerging infectious diseases of potential pandemic nature, improved diagnostics, therapeutics, and vaccines are needed. Our training program capitalizes on UTMB’s unique high containment facilities, multiple highly qualified, world-renowned faculty, and robust biosafety educational programs to train doctoral students to become future successful independent researchers in academia and pharma working to develop novel medical countermeasures to curb highly consequential diseases.

PHR: The Yale OAIC will promote the functional independence of older Americans by increasing scientific knowledge related to multifactorial geriatric conditions, by advancing the science of clinical decision making in multimorbid older persons, by educating and training early-stage investigators in aging research from a multifactorial perspective, and by developing and implementing innovative methods that will facilitate rigorous and high impact research on multifactorial geriatric conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Chronic pain represents a major public health problem, and an improved understanding of the biopsychosocial contributors to pain is critical to inform interventions aimed at pain prevention and treatment. At present, there is a need to bolster the dwindling clinical pain research workforce. To address this gap, we propose the University of Florida Partnerships Across Interdisciplinary Networks: Training through Engineering, epidemiology & Addiction Medicine (UF PAIN TEAM) with the long-term goal of creating the next generation of team-trained clinical pain scientists. Working in teams, the UF PAIN TEAM will move the pain field forward through cutting edge research designed to elucidate the causes and reduce the burden of pain.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The College of New Jersey in collaboration with Mercer County Community College and Brookdale Community college proposes an engaging, research-intensive experience in order to develop a diverse and skilled local talent pipeline for the biomedical sciences, an area of rapid growth in the New Jersey region. Our program initiatives will prepare trainees to gain the knowledge, skills, and identity needed for successful biomedical careers, which will contribute to expanding the public health workforce.

PHR: Project Narrative Literally hundreds of thousands of chemically distinct molecules are present in every cell in the brain and can be modified based on exposure to drugs of abuse, and yet the technologies to measure and elucidate this chemical complexity are not broadly available. Our Center offers unparalleled measurement capabilities and analytical support to a broad range of drug abuse and fundamental science projects, ensuring their success.

PHR: R25 MSK Computational Biology Summer Program: Project Narrative The MSK Computational Biology Summer Program (CBSP) aims to train the next generation of computer science savvy students in cancer biology. Biologists are trained to form a hypothesis and provide data to support it, but in the current big data era, many can’t find the insights they seek in the vast troves of data they’ve collected. CBSP participants, through exposure to cancer biology topics, can use their skills to develop new tools and mine big data towards finding the next generation of cancer therapeutics, patient diagnostics, and furthermore, can uncover novel biological and mechanistic insights into cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Cardiovascular Sciences Training Program is dedicated to preparing the next generation of scientists who aim to understand the normal and abnormal function of the heart and vascular system. Heart and vascular diseases remain a leading killer of Americans, and therefore, we need to have investigators who are well trained in this field. As cardiovascular disease has evolved and our understanding of it has changed, over this next training period, we have added mentors who are experts in bioinformatics and systems analysis to take better advantage of large biomedical data sets that will help us better diagnose and treat cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The focus of our work is to better understand the mechanisms of lysosomal glycogen metabolism. Our goal is to translate knowledge gained about lysosomal glycogen metabolism into better ways to diagnose and treat genetic diseases where lysosomal glycogen metabolism is dysregulated, such as Pompe disease and Danon disease, or metabolic diseases where glycogen metabolism is dysregulated including cancer, heart disease, diabetes, and brain disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of this T32 Training Grant is to educate and train basic scientists and physician-scientists conducting high impact and innovative research that will improve the health of people suffering from lung diseases. We aim to recruit and train trainees from diverse backgrounds, and provide multifaceted and personalized training opportunities that will endow our trainees with the skills required to become successful independent researchers, educators, and policy makers in lung biology and pulmonary medicine.

PHR: 8. Project Narrative This program aims to train a new generation of investigators to understand how behavioral, genetic and environmental factors affect risk of cancer incidence and survival, and to integrate the wealth of new methods in molecular biology (such as genomics and metabolomics), epidemiology, and biostatistics in this effort. Through multidisciplinary training, and leveraging the enormous resources that are available to our students and post- doctoral fellows, we believe that great strides can be made to reduce the burden of cancer in the US and around the world.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Eye disease screening of the general population is not currently recommended, but few studies have been performed to address screening as a strategy to reduce visual impairment. The proposed research is thus relevant for public health because it will determine the effectiveness of eye disease screening of the general population using optical coherence tomography (OCT), fundus photography, and intraocular pressure (IOP) assessment for detection of glaucoma, diabetic retinopathy, and age-related macular degeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The University of Michigan (UM) PAIN Cohort T90/R90 is ideally suited to train the next generation of post- doctoral pain scientists. The program proposes inter-disciplinary mentoring and training of individuals from disciplines not typically involved in pain research, with a heavy emphasis on training a wide variety of data scientists as well as trainees from our School of Public Health (including biostatistics and epidemiology) and College of Engineering (including computer science and biomedical engineering). By using a vast array of available and willing mentors at UM not formally named on the grant, we will be able to provide each of our Scholars both a junior and senior mentor, as well as an individual with learned experience, as part of their mentoring team.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The long-term goal of the SUNY Upstate Bridges to the Baccalaureate Program T34 training grant is to increase the number of under-represented students who transfer from three SUNY community colleges (MCC, OCC, WCC) and complete baccalaureate degrees in disciplines relevant to biomedical and behavioral sciences at Binghamton University. The inclusion of underrepresented groups in the biomedical and behavior science workforce is critical to reducing health disparities and improving the health of all people in the United States.

PHR: NARRATIVE This Program Project seeks to examine the impact of recent national policies and payment changes on older adults living with Alzheimer's Disease and related dementias (ADRD) in different states of disease progression and in different care settings. Understanding these effects is crucial to document potential unintended consequences and inform policies that enhance access to healthcare, reduce burden on patients and families, improve quality of care, and advance health equity.

PHR: NARRATIVE At present there is an enormous need for new safe and efficacious treatments designed to relieve the burden of chronic pain and substance use disorders (SUD). However, there is a deficit of scientists trained to conduct clinical research investigating pain and SUD that can move the fields forward. In order to address this gap, we propose the Promoting Excellence through Pain and Addiction Research Enhancement (PREPARE) Program with the long-term goal of creating the next generation of investigators who will advance science through cutting edge clinical research that helps relieve pain and ameliorate SUD.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neutrophils are primary cells of the innate immune response necessary for host defense to infection. We propose to understand the heterogeneity and metabolic regulation of neutrophils using human induced pluripotent stem cells. We will apply genomic and metabolic imaging techniques and zebrafish screening to identify neutrophils with improved antimicrobial function.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of this Research Education Training Program, Scholars in Oncology-Associated Research (SOAR), at the University of Chicago Pritzker School of Medicine (PSOM) is to inspire medical students to pursue careers in cancer research through exposure to the full continuum from basic science to translational settings and interdisciplinary collaboration needed to provide patient centered care for the 21st Century. To this end, we designed and implemented a 10-week period of intensive research experiences and related training that are not available through formal NIH training mechanisms. An overarching goal of this renewal application is to build on our success, enhance the program and further provide educational activities that effectively supports training of a physician workforce to meet the nation’s biomedical, behavioral and clinical research enterprise.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The removal of a tumor is an important stage of treatment, as it allows the extraction of a large volume of tumor tissue, the reduction of intracranial pressure, the decrease of neurological deficit and the establishment of an exact tumor phenotype to solve the question of further treatment tactics. Modern research has shown that the size of tumor resection is reliably correlated with the life expectancy of patients. In the case of diffuse astrocytomas with a low degree of malignancy, total tumor removal is a key prognostic factor as it effectively reduces the risk of malignant tumor transformation. For adult patients with brainstem high-grade gliomas, one of the rarest and deadliest forms of brain cancer, surgically removing the entire tumor may add many months or potentially years of survival beyond that offered by radiation and chemotherapy. The main paradigm of brain tumor surgery is the maximal removal of the tumor with minimal risk of damage to functionally significant areas of the brain. However, the extraction of a tumor in the white light of a microscope can only achieve a maximum resection in 23–50% of cases. This contributes to maintaining a high interest in the development of intraoperative technologies that allow the differentiation of tumors from surrounding tissues. In this proposed study, we aspire to develop, characterize, and evaluate intranasally delivered tumor-targeting polymeric micelles carrying a self-quenched near-infrared (NIR) imaging agent on its potential in brain imaging and neurosurgical guidance during brain tumor surgery. This system is designed to switch “off” fluorescence signals until the micelles arrive at tumor tissues and begin to release an imaging agent as a monomeric form, resulting in strong fluorescence (“on”) signals on tumor tissues. We believe that the polymeric micelles proposed in this study will offer high sensitivity and specificity in imaging brain tumor for distinguishing tumor tissues from surrounding white matter and ultimately improve surgical outcomes and patient survival, potentially adding decades of quality life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative / Public Health Relevance Immunobiological research findings have become increasingly relevant in surgical practice, influencing diverse surgical disciplines including oncology, transplantation, trauma, and critical care. Although the importance of immune manipulation has become an evident adjunct to the practice of surgery, and a necessary component of most advances in surgical disease, surgical training neither includes advanced immunology nor prepares surgeon-scientists to participate in immune-related research. This program aims to provide surgeons with training in advanced immunology and create surgeon-scientists capable of participating and leading in surgically relevant areas of immunobiological research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The overall goal of the Bridges to Baccalaureate Research Training Program at University of Memphis (UofM) is to prepare a diverse group of highly trained biomedical scientists to enhance the diversity of individuals entering the biomedical research workforce. The short-term goal of this Bridges program is to enhance research knowledge, skills, values, identity, and self-efficacy of Southwest Tennessee Community College (STCC) students from underrepresented groups in the biomedical sciences within a community of researchers. The intermediate goal is to inspire matriculation and persistence in biomedical science-related undergraduate programs at UofM, resulting in an increase in the number of students that transfer from STCC to UofM and complete the baccalaureate degree in a biomedical science.

PHR: Project Narrative Research using the amphibian Xenopus, because of unique advantages as an experimental system, has revealed key insights in many domains of biomedical research, including cell biology, development, neurobiology, physiology and signal transduction. This proposal seeks to generate and characterize different Xenopus mutants in key genes related to human diseases using new technology, which will help provide significant insights about the causes of these diseases.

PHR: Narrative The UNC Integrated Translational Oncology Program (UNC-iTOP) is a T32 training application from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (UNC) focused on training clinicians (MDs), basic scientists (PhDs), and MD-PhD candidates in clinical/translational disease based research at the interface of clinical oncology and cancer biology using patient samples. The UNC-iTOP is unique in its focus on developing clinician/scholars in translational oncology tissue-based research, integrating 1) physicians (residents and fellows) training in Medical, Surgical, and Gynecologic Oncology with post-doctoral fellows possessing PhD degrees and 2) MD, MD-PhD, PhD pre-doctoral candidates. UNC-iTOP will provide research training support for up to two years and will support two post-doctoral and two pre-doctoral trainees per year with an anticipated ratio of 2 MD/DO/MD-PhD: 1 PhD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Building on our previous work, we are proposing an innovative dual-mode breast cancer scanner combining positron emission tomography (PET) and x-ray tomosynthesis (XT). It has been shown repeatedly over the last decade by at least 11 studies that molecular imaging with clinical PET scanners can be used to gauge response of breast tumors to therapy within days. The high-resolution PET/XT scanner will provide quantitative assessment of response to breast cancer therapy for lesions <2 cm in size, which are are the most prevalent at breast cancer diagnosis, and if there is no response then there is time to test second-line and other alternative therapies and to guide the selection of an effective post-surgical adjuvant therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: CALIFORNIA POLY STATE U SAN LUIS OBISPO
PHR: The persistent lack of diversity among scientists in the biomedical field limits our ability to address the complex array of health problems and disparities that affect our nation and the world today. BtB at Cal Poly is a training program that incorporates best practices from evidence-based training programs, providing support for students attending community college to transfer and complete a baccalaureate degree in biomedical sciences. The multi-faceted program consists of one year of research skills training and academic support at a community college, followed by a robust curriculum post-transfer that includes mentored research experiences, didactic instruction on conceptual and technical research skills, mentoring teams, and specialized curriculum emphasizing the prosocial value of biomedical research, building identity as a scientist, fostering a deep understanding of health equity, and developing knowledge and skills to direct research towards current health challenges.

PHR: OVERALL NARRATIVE The mission of this Penn PO1 Center on “Mechanisms underlying heterogeneity of cognitive outcome in synucleinopathy” is to understand why the same underlying core pathology – inclusions of alpha-synuclein (aSyn) – can manifest in such different ways, leading to important differences in quality of life for patients with Lewy body disorders (LBD) such as dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB), Parkinson’s Disease (PD), and Alzheimer’s Disease with Lewy bodies (LBD+AD). By investigating both the characteristics of the disease protein aSyn and the characteristics of the hosts (individual LBD patients), and by using human tissues, neuronal models, and animal models, we aim to develop new therapeutic targets to delay or prevent Alzheimer Disease Related Dementia.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative There is an ongoing, severe shortage of veterinarian-scientists with the research expertise necessary to pursue careers as independent investigators in biomedical research. These individuals are critical to effectively translating biomedical research discoveries made in animal models into new methods for the diagnosis and treatment of human disease. This "Comparative Medicine and Pathology Training" program at the University of Minnesota will use and improve our established mechanisms of providing a robust research training experience to DVMsNMDs to increase the number of veterinarian-scientists working successfully in biomedical research fields and conducting research around the "One Health" concept for the ultimate benefit of human health.

PROJECT_TITLE: Comparative Medicine and Pathology Training

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Whooping cough (pertussis) is a re-emerging public health crisis responsible for the death of over 150,000 infants annually. We have identified a currently licensed drug that protects against disease, but has off-target effects. We have identified 3 proteins, one of which is produced by mice in response to this drug, the other two are blocked by the drug, which we believe may control symptoms associated with disease.

STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Host Interactions with Bacterial Pathogens Study Section[HIBP]

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Overall The Translational Research Program in Colorectal Cancer Disparities (TRPCD) will conduct innovative translational research that is focused on the development of novel clinically impactful strategies to eliminate persistent racial and ethnic disparities in colorectal cancer incidence and mortality. The proposed four research projects leverage large racially and ethnically diverse study populations and highly annotated biospecimens; are led by a world-class investigator team with expertise in basic science, epidemiology, biostatistics, clinical and translational research, minority health, and cancer disparities; and are supported by three critical cores. Through these efforts and future projects and investigators funded by our Developmental Research Program and Career Enhancement Program, TRPCD will actively pursue a robust set of horizontal and vertical collaborations.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Administrative Core (AC) The successful functioning of our Translational Research Program in Colorectal Cancer Disparities (TRPCD) is highly dependent upon a capable and effective Administrative Core (AC). The AC will be vital for providing the requisite foundation for effective implementation of TRPCD's scientific and translational goals. This Core will provide overall leadership and administrative support, program management, integration with existing programs and shared resources, infrastructural support, communication within and across TRPCD investigators and partnering institutions, and evaluation of all TRPCD activities and components.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE of Project 1 The systematically better performance of current polygenic risk scores (PRS) in non-Hispanic White people compared to other racial and ethnic groups creates a major ethical and scientific challenge with respect to their broad clinical dissemination, as they have the potential to exacerbate existing CRC disparities. We will use a novel strategy that leverages single-cell multi-omic data to develop and validate a PRS that predicts colorectal cancer risk across different racial and ethnic groups. We will also evaluate the cost-effectiveness of our PRS and estimate optimal screening strategies in terms of equity and efficiency for different risk groups that account for differences in CRC incidence, mortality, and risk factor profiles across racial and ethnic groups.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to discover novel spatially resolved biomarkers of lethal colorectal cancer and response to both first-line therapy and immunotherapy in racially and ethnically diverse sets of patients. It will also develop and validate predictors of colorectal cancer specific mortality and treatment response in different racial and ethnic groups.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The burden of colorectal cancer incidence and mortality varies greatly by race and ethnicity. In this project, we will examine the role of bacteria in colorectal cancer across population groups to identify differences in the presence and distribution of different bacteria – individually and in combination. The findings from this work will help us better tailor cancer treatments and early detection in the future to address colorectal cancer disparities across racial and ethnic groups.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Project 4 We propose to conduct a randomized controlled trial of time-restricted eating (TRE) during neoadjuvant treatment in 100 Alaska Native patients with rectal cancer at the Alaska Native Medical Center. We will examine whether TRE improves pathological complete response rate, reduces treatment related toxicities, improves health-related quality of life, and adherence. Changes in selected cancer-related blood-based and tumor-based markers by interventional arm, and differences across ethnic and racial groups, will be examined through a horizontal collaboration with the CHRONO Trial.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE of the Biospecimen and Pathology Core (BPC) This Biospecimen and Pathology Core (BPC) will develop a one-of-a-kind colorectal cancer (CRC) biorepository that provides the critical infrastructure needed for the collection, processing, management, and governance of biospecimens and clinical and epidemiological data from racially and ethnically diverse CRC patients and non- diseased participants. These biospecimens and data will be used by the SPORE projects, are available for use by Career Enhancement and Developmental Research Programs and can be used to support outside collaborations to advance the translational science for CRC disparities. The BPC will also enable access to state- of-the-art laboratory technologies and provide expertise in tissue-based assays and biomarker analyses.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE of the Developmental Research Program (DRP) The Developmental Research Program (DRP) is a key component of the long-term success of our Translational Research Program in Colorectal Cancer Disparities. It will swiftly fund innovative and impactful DRP projects focused on translational cancer disparities research with the potential to develop into full research projects. The DRP will be a catalyst to accelerate cutting edge cancer translational disparities research that aims to understand the underlying biological drivers for cancer disparities and develop interventions and treatments that will lead to reduction in the morbidity and mortality of cancer among a racially and ethnically diverse population.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE of the Career Enhancement Program (CEP) Our Translational Research Program in Colorectal Cancer Disparities' (TRPCD) Career Enhancement Program is an essential component of our SPORE. Its primary purpose is to attract and support new scientists from different disciplines (clinical, basic science, and population science) to the field of translational cancer disparities research. Cornerstones of our program include identifying and providing multi-disciplinary mentors, assigning sponsors, and providing opportunities for leadership development as appropriate.

PHR: OVARIAN CANCER SPORE: NARRATIVE This SPORE is dedicated to improving overall clinical outcomes in women who suffer from ovarian cancer, which affects approximately 23,000 women in the United States by delivering new approaches to ovarian cancer detection, prevention, and treatment. Over the planned 5 years of funding, each of these new approaches, as monitored using aggressive milestones/timelines, should move measurably closer to clinical application and benefit.

PHR: Project Narrative (Project 1) Project 1 aims to apply novel molecular assays to diagnose incidental occult ovarian carcinoma and its precursor lesions in fallopian tubes, the origin of “ovarian” high-grade serous carcinoma. We also propose to assess the most commonly amplified genes in the precursor lesions for their cancer dissemination phenotypes. Our expected results will empower a new diagnostic platform for high-risk women.

PHR: PROJECT 3: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it aims to develop novel therapeutic strategies for Type I ovarian cancers including clear cell and endometrioid subtypes which are enriched with loss-of-function ARID1A mutation resulting in reduced DNA repair efficacy and defective cell cycle checkpoint regulation. The proposed research is relevant to the NIH mission to develop fundamental knowledge that will reduce the burden of human illness.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most human diseases are complex, resulting from interactions between genetic loci. Human and Mammalian Genetics and Genomics: the McKusick Short Course will train a cadre of highly skilled, diverse young scientists on the genetics and genomics of human disease. With a combined focus on medical genetics, mouse genetics and model systems the course will forge a link between basic and clinical research enabling ongoing dialogue and thereby fostering productive clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Aggression accompanies a number of common human neurodegenerative disorders (e.g. Alzheimer's and other related dementias), with little understanding of how cognitive and aggression symptoms may be linked at the neuronal level. Aggression has been extensively studied in males of many species, but neglected in females (likewise, the interaction of sex and age is neglected). The objective of this research program is to identify the neural circuitry that governs female aggression (K99- mentored phase) and later transition (R00- independent phase) into discovering mechanisms of dementia-related pathology and how these changes affect aggression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We propose that the data, materials, and expertise of PIDTC be organized and made available as a resource (the PIDTC Resource) to the entire IEI community (patients, clinicians, researchers, clinical trialists) with key enhancements to expand the utility and quality of the resource, improvements to expand data access and interpretation, and improved dissemination of results to accelerate knowledge generation for the field. We will do this by 1) expanding the PIDTC Resource to increase its utility and improve the power to answer further questions related to the treatment of IEI's including particular genotypes or clinical subtypes of disease; 2) consolidating and building tools and infrastructure to accelerate standardized data collection from ongoing and future studies and trials that are contributing data to the PIDTC Resource; and 3) providing tools to make the PIDTC data more accessible to the broader IEI community including researchers, clinical care providers, patient advocacy groups, patients, foundations, and consortia. The major impact of the proposed resource will be establishment of an organization that facilitates the open use of existing and new data, infrastructure, and study design expertise to expand achievement of evidence-based advances in the treatment of patients with IEI.

PHR: Project Narrative Oncogenic human papillomavirus (HPV) infection is a necessary cause of 10% of all cancers of women globally, including 99% of cervical cancers. To help overcome disparities in primary prevention of cervical cancer, here we seek to develop an affordable HPV vaccine that both extends the breadth of protection to cover all cancer- associated HPV types, is stable at ambient temperature and only requires a single administration.

PHR: Project Narrative Here, we seek to develop a vaccination regimen that safely and effectively causes the immune system to eliminate otherwise persistent infections of the most dangerous types of human papillomavirus before women develop the precursor lesions of cervical cancer. This approach to cervical cancer prevention may also be effective for other anal, genital and oral cancers caused by these viruses.

PHR: Project Narrative Human papillomavirus (HPV) type 16 infection causes 50-60% of all cervical cancers (and ~90% of other HPV- associated anogenital and oropharyngeal cancers); HIV co-infection or immunosuppression after organ transplantation increases risk for these cancers. Here we test a candidate therapeutic and preventive vaccine for treatment of HPV16+ cancer precursor lesions in HIV+ and HIV- women, including HIV- patients waiting for a kidney transplant.

PROJECT_TITLE: A Phase I Open Label, Dose Escalation Clinical Trial Assessing the Safety, Tolerability, and Feasibility of pNGVL4aCRTE6E7L2 HPV DNA Vaccine Administration Via Intramuscular TriGridTM Electroporation

PHR: Project Narrative The current chemoradiation standard-of-care for inoperable, locally-advanced, stage IIB-IVA cervical cancer has shown limited success. Here, we propose to treat stage IIB-IVA cervical cancer patients with intratumoral vaccination of the therapeutic TA-CIN protein vaccine in conjunction to standard chemoradiation therapy for the secondary prevention of cervical cancer. We will subsequently evaluate intratumoral TA-CIN vaccination with concomitant immune checkpoint blockade therapy in a novel spontaneous cervicovaginal carcinoma model.
